150051097.review:
Impressions after the first hour:
Well, I'm glad there turns out to be a game in here after all these cutscenes... I get they're going for visual storytelling, but with how vague everything is, it just seems to be wasting my time. See Noita for a good mystical opening. Also, this game is pretty buggy. Managed to get stuck in a combat arena that wouldn't open back up even after I killed the enemies inside it, and the first boss's attacks, these jars, would disappear midair if I baited a melee attack, and I figured out after a minute you can bait him into meleeing over and over until the whole boss fight is just dash swipe swipe dash, dash swipe swipe dash. Not a promising start. The atmosphere is great, art is great, very good intrigue, but I get the feeling that will be of little comfort when I run into the boss that's harder because of the bugs rather than easier.

Finished the game, SPOILERS AHEAD:
I had this whole essay comparing this game to others of its genre, but the ending of this game sucks so bad I don't even want to think about it anymore. Nothing is elaborated on, nothing is explained, there is nowhere further to look for details about the world. There are no secret final areas, or bosses, or characters. The setup in the beginning of "go fix the four pillars and kill the boss" goes off without a hitch. The NPCs you run into are not characters, they're 24 pixels and a bit of fan art that invites you to imagine what a cool life they had before you started playing this game. This game is beautiful, with great art and visual design, but it has no story, just a bunch of setting and a puppet protagonist who kills the enemies, moves into the next room, and kills the enemies again. The most this game can do for puzzles are literally invisible platforms and perspective tricks hiding hidden paths. I don't regret the first three hours, but I sure as hell regret the rest of my playtime trying to find anything else to build on this world's lore. And now, having finished the game, I am not haunted by the protagonist's cookie-cutter sacrifice, I am bored.

Also, if you're in need of a laugh, read this game's wiki. Trying to make a story more complicated than "bad man killed people now kill him" out of Hyper Light Drifer's lore is impossible.

148512743.review:
An excellent game with only one or two annoyances preventing perfection.  I've nearly 100% it and loved my time in the world, with it's voiceless storytelling and beautiful art design.  Combat is pretty good, though sometimes you will dash in to enemies or objects and stick unexpectedly, and the aiming on game pad is wobbly at best. When you get in to the flow of dashing around swinging and shooting it is excellent!

I would say the biggest pain is when you have to focus solely on an element for completions sake.  800 dashes in a row, the combat arenas, the dash puzzles.  This game works best when you're exploring, fighting, and traversing the world hunting for secrets, but when you have to focus too much on any single element you start to see the flaws.

Thankfully you can finish the game without needing to engage any of this, and have a wonderful time in this beautiful and tragic land.  Absolute recommend, still holds up all these years later.

147570682.review:
This game would need two separate reviews: one for level design and visuals/soundtrack, one for story and map/navigation system.

The first two elements are excellent: levels are very well designed, with several secret paths that are (mostly) not impossible to find without being too obvious at the same time. The player needs some keen eye to find hints leading to hidden spots, but they are there and it feels very rewarding to discover new areas. Visuals and atmosphere are also very compelling and captivating, the game is overall very nice to look at as well as being somewhat chill and soothing to explore.

In contrast, story and navigability are among the worst you can find in its genre. The map is, without mincing words, the most useless I've ever seen in a Metroidvania and completely ruins any fun or satisfaction deriving from exploration; your exact location is never pinpointed but you can only get an indication of the macroarea you're currently in, then you're supposed to figure out the exact spot by looking at landmarks. This somewhat works while on the surface, but in the dungeons there are no landmarks whatsoever and it's nearly impossible to even figure out where the access to each subterranean area is located. Even worse, there's no way to mark places or keep track of found items. You're supposed to blindly return in each area to look for the stuff you've left behind each time you get some new key or powerup, and even then you have no way to know whether you've cleared a zone or not. There was absolutely no reason to make navigation and progress tracking so needlessly obtuse and inconvenient. Personally, I've only managed to complete the game by using [url=https://hyper-light-drifter-map.de/]this interactive map[/url] that makes everything immensely more manageable, but is it positive when you have to rely on the work of someone else other than the original developer to make a game worth playing? I really don't think so. This game's map is either a deliberate excercise in gratuitous crypticity or a massive design failure. Either way, it sucks on an astronomical level.

Then there's the story and worldbuilding, which can be summed up with: [b]go figure[/b]. Except for the intro and the ending cinematics you don't get a single clue about what the hell is going on throughout the whole game. There are some monolyths to be found written in a cyphered language, but even if you go through all the hassle of translating them - I didn't, I just googled - the only thing you're left with is an extremely vague poem about some immortal cell that got corrupted and is completely up to interpretation - which nowadays, is just the convenient excuse for not writing anything by yourself. But of course people LOVE to make shit up and have filled entire wikis with completely "inferred" -i.e. invented - facts. It's even worse than Dark Souls.

I haven't mentioned the combat system, since it's the part I find most basic; it's neither bad nor particularly good, it works most of the time but it shows its limits in the arenas. I still managed to complete them without too much hassle, so it's ok I guess.

Overall, it was very disappointing to see a game with such potential being wasted by a deadly combination of very bad design choices and lazy writing. If i had to be generous I'd say that Hyper Light Drifter is 40% good, 40% bad and 20% mediocre - which makes for a pretty mediocre experience overall. But there are no neutral or detailed options for the final evaluation, so it's a thumbs down for me. Pity.

147421004.review:
Hyper Light Drifter is a game developed and published independently by Heart Machine, which is the brainchild of Alx Preston. The game was released at the end of March 2016 on Steam and was developed on an old build of GameMaker. In the game, you play as the titular “Drifter”, dashing, shooting and slicing your way through a silent world, filled only by images and the occasional, meaningless grunts of nearby NPCs. The world is a dying, dreamlike Fantasy, somewhere between the neo-noire of Katana Zero and the colorful High Fantasy of Zelda, with an atmospheric soundtrack by one of gaming’s finest composers: Disasterpeace.

[h1]PROs[/h1]
+ Stellar Soundtrack and Sound Design
+ Stunning Visuals, Pixel Art and Cutscenes
+ An atmosphere that you could cut with a knife
+ Beautiful character and enemy designs, some complex, some perfectly simple
+ A great, rhythmic hack-and-slash combat system
+ A rich, main narrative metaphor and fantastic side stories, spoken only through a series of three images from a few, important NPCs and encrypted monoliths
+ Fantastic bosses
+ Fantastic feeling of urgency

[h1]CONs[/h1]
- Framerate drops and stuttering on modern systems (potential fixes in the comments)
- At times, finicky, unresponsive feeling controls
- Janky hit stun mechanics, that can lead to instant death by stunlock
- Inconsistent hitboxes, especially for enemies and objects that are below the player and up against a wall
- Repeated, unskippable cutscene (rather short, but meaningless)
- Missing QoL features when looking for secrets and some secrets not being at all telegraphed
- Bugs still left in the game, some game-breaking (my save was experiencing a fatal error of some sort randomly, prompting me to restart)
- Inconsistent Enemy Behavior and Dodge timings

[h1]Review[/h1]
You play as “The Drifter” chasing a cure for a mysterious corruption besetting him and slowly overwhelming his body, killing him in a war of attrition. You race through four different quadrants of the world, split in the four cardinal directions from the game’s main starting area (the town). Progressing ever farther through this strange and beautifully mysterious landscape, partly overwhelmed by technology, both dead and alive. The game is very somber all the way through, but in a deeply beautiful and affecting way.
The game starts off with a cutscene detailing all of the above, a cutscene that is unskippable, even on New Game+. Then you’re put into a tutorial, where, at the end, you’re attacked by a mysterious monster, who appears as a recurring, main antagonist, and the seeming cause of the world’s ills, and your own deathly ailment. The cutscene of this main antagonist encounter plays around five times throughout the game’s runtime, with only slight variations. This cutscene is also unskippable and is, unfortunately, the one place where the game’s audio balancing goes haywire, producing ear-rending audio, an odd, though ostensibly deliberate choice.
Over time, by picking up “gearbits”, which are yellow chips that drop from enemies, bosses and crates hidden in the game’s secret areas, you are able to upgrade The Drifter’s dashing, slicing and his guns, which you acquire more of over the course of the game. The upgrades are serviceable for a game of Hyper Light Drifter’s runtime, which is around 5-6 hours, when simply going for first time completion, without picking up everything in the game.
Some of the game’s side challenges, such as chaining your dash 800 times in a row and beating a comically strong, little hooded figure at football are shoddily built or simply annoying. The same goes for some of the game’s achievements, such as “One Shot”, which requires the player to beat the whole game without dying; a game where dodges, enemy behaviors, hitboxes and the ever-looming potential for cheap stunlocks leave much to be desired.
Animation, art, music, worldbuilding, exploration, character and enemy design and animation are all stellar, however, and the story is truly a thing of marvel. The audio design (apart from the one aforementioned cutscene) is equally great. It is a very special game, that I believe everyone should experience, while keeping in mind the caveats of its technical limitations, such as unstable framerates without workarounds on modern hardware, due to the game’s development on an early version of GameMaker, and all of the issues and jankiness mentioned throughout the review. There are community guides and stellar workarounds to some of the game’s archaic game design, such as the online locator for missing gearbits and a save file backup tool, that can replace the game’s lacking steam cloud features. Backing up your save in an extra folder, to potentially protect against game-breaking bugs, which still seem to infrequently appear, is strongly recommended.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Hyper Light Drifter is a labor of love, beyond the shadow of a doubt. A game and world conceived by Alx Preston, planned as a potential, final soiree to a life wrought with serious medical harships, that could end at any moment due to a deathly illness of the heart. The game plays with this idea of a failing core or failing heart a lot, and the concept is already ingrained in the studio’s name. It is a beautiful piece of art, one that I encourage everyone to experience, even if simply out of respect for Alx’s journey. Some additional materials will be included in the review’s comments.

[h2]Thank You To Heart Machine And Alx Preston For Sharing With Us Their Beautiful Vision![/h2]

Fun game that's fairly short and has a very strong, unique aesthetic. The story is almost entirely told through visuals and environment design, which is cool but also means that quite a bit of it is VERY open to interpretation. Depending on who you are, this could be a pro or a con, but I personally found it confusing and a bit frustrating in places, though not a deal-breaker. For instance, after finishing the game I went and read the descriptions on the steam cards for the game and said "wait, THAT'S what was going on?!"

What is more likely to be a deal-breaker to some people are the achievements, because there are some incredibly badly designed achievements in HLD. Several of them are infuriating and tedious, like beating the game without dying or chaining together 800 dashes without messing up once.

I wish steam had a neutral option... the game is far from bad the graphics are amazing and the music is perfect for the pixel'd environment but the story/lore is very lacking it required me to search outside the game on alternative sources to figure out what was even going on in the game. Most people's reviews claim this game to be challenging, but in my experience the only suffering I found was hunting for all the gearbit's to get 100% completion and having to farm 1000 deaths for another achievement. To keep it short, here is a list of annoying things: 
* map is unmarkable and shows only what room you're in. 
* gear has unique effects not listed in game.
* controls awkward and requires controller to chain dash effectively.
* no text, audible lore, or intractable npc's = no game immersion.
* uncontrollable screen shaking on some bosses.
*  spend hours dashing into every wall to make sure you don't miss a hidden gearbit, monument, key, gun, or vanity item.

146508265.review: Pretentious indie slop. The game features no words or writing, which on paper sounds like a cool idea. In practice this game desperately needed some entertaining writing because the world does nothing to keep the player interested or engaged outside of subtle "environmental storytelling". Aside from well designed cutscenes which perhaps resemble something from the SEGA CD/PC Engine, the ingame graphics are incredibly dull and lack detail. The blending of modern lighting techniques with pixel graphics is an awful look. The music is just ambient sound, and it exists just to fill the void. The gameplay is nothing to write home about, but nothing to complain about either. It is just a typical overhead action game with a dash button. When you reach the end of the game, you'll feel as though you have been suddenly awoken from some kind of insomnia, and won't remember a single thing about what you have been doing for the past 13 hours. I recommend you spend your money on something cooler like Magic Knight Rayearth for the Sega Saturn. There are a plethora of fantastic overhead action games out there, and spending your time and money here would be a complete waste.

this one is a winner. a wonderful, curious art style that begs you to explore this pixelated wastland and ponder a story shown and not told. combat is fairly fluid with a few kinks here and there but aside from clunky chain dashing every second of this very compact game's loop of dashing, slashing, and blowing your load while searching for secrets just works. 144680018.review:
My review is positive but a bit on the neutral or "not for everyone" side. If you love the mechanics of Hollow Knight you might enjoy this smaller and simpler adventure - But the lore and where this world resides and how it came to be is pretty intentionally vague, it's edging close to an art piece but it maintains the mechanics of a fairly challenging hack and slash game. I would love a sequel or a comic or something that would give this game more of a narrative, but I'm worried that that would also sort of defeat the point of this game...

Positive Qualities:
- Movement and attacks are satisfying and the battles can be pretty difficult at points.
- The ambience and aesthetic is mysterious and alluring, the color palette is vivid and gorgeous. Art direction and music is on-point.

Negative Qualities:
- My biggest gripe is about 60% of this game is entirely optional and composed of easter eggs, secrets and hidden areas. I had NO CLUE about this because the game doesn't tell you this, and I only learned what was under the surface when I wanted to start unlocking stuff and looked up a guide. Hidden areas are marked with symbols that could very easily blend into the rest of the scenery, and the game is entirely void of dialogue or overt direction (an intentional stylistic choice that is unfortunately to its detriment in this aspect). If you ignore all of the side stuff and play well, you can finish this game in a few hours.
- Completionist's hell. This game is already challenging, but due to what I illustrated above, you will have an extremely hard time completing this game on your own without a walkthrough.

143783471.review:
At first I thought I would be bored after 20 minutes of playing, the combat seemed basic and boring and I thought it would be just the same sword and pistol combo the whole time.

How wrong I was. The game does an amazing job of revealing things to you over time, but not in a clear way. It relies on the intelligence of the player to figure out what is going on, because nothing is explained other than giving a general direction of where you need to go. But eventually you start figuring out what the main objectives are, where to look to find secrets in the world, and what the items you collect do. There are a handful of collectibles and each one is a mystery until you happen upon an area where its function is made clear. For example, the yellow currencies build up over time, but I did not realize they were used to buy upgrades until returning to the village after the first boss.

The exploration is very enjoyable, however I think it becomes a bit too easy to find everything when you realize the trick. Most of the hidden things are just a matter of looking for a symbol on the ground to indicate invisible walkways or a platform out of sight. Although I say that and I missed a bunch of collectibles on my first go through. Also, it would be nice if there was a better in game way to track items found that makes it easy to go through and get the things you missed. The only thing that is marked clearly are the 8 nodes per area. I wish there was a way to easily find where I am missing keys and the yellow gear currency, as well as a way to mark doors that I have not opened, since it can be hard to remember where they are after the fact.

The world is also beautifully done in pixel art. Each area has an interesting color palette and regional style that makes them distinct, and they also have unique enemies to each area that provide a steadily increasing challenge that requires you to alter your combat a bit.

Finally, the combat feels simple but fun. Each hit with the sword gives a little screen shake and feedback so they feel powerful but quick. The weapons you unlock also give some strategy to how you want to approach fights. I wish there was more upgrades available for them besides bigger ammo capacity though.

This ended up being a great surprise and high on my list of the games I've played this year. Among my favorite indies for sure, and I hope I find time for more playthroughs in the future, to collect everything and maybe a speedrun.

142839811.review:
A stunning love letter to the SNES-era action RPG, Hyper Light Drifter presents a beautiful neon world mid-apocalypse and suffering from an event that has left its inhabitants decimated and beset by monsters. The incredibly detailed and well animated pixel art is accompanied by an equally wonderful score by Disasterpiece that captures the ethereal decaying atmosphere perfectly.

The story is intentionally enigmatic with only the animated intro providing context and while it leaves us with more questions than answers thankfully we don't need any to progress. Four directions to go in and by the time we reach the end any one we understand the game's logic - explore, fight, gather collectibles, beat the boss, grow in power.

Combat is reactive and punishing as you master dashing, slashing, and shooting. It's a volatile playstyle that lets you be aggressive - too much though and you can lunge right into attacks. The enemies are also completely different in each area offering a variety of tactics that keeps things fresh. Each boss also acts as a 'super' version of the monster faction that will test your skill against their unique style of fighting.

The world is genuinely beautiful and each biome is uniquely distorted by the on-going corruption, from crystalline forests and flooded ruins to polluted factories and frozen mountain caverns, and more. The soft world building lends to the world's mystery only offering glimpses at the larger goings on with sights that had me genuinely pause to take it in. It's also filled with secrets and collectibles that invite you to explore every inch.

In conclusion, the game is an artistic masterpiece and while combat is challenging throughout it does borrow a little too much from Souls with the narrow health, hefty damage, and instant heal mechanic (as many games seem to aim for now days). That said combat never gets tedious even if it can be repetitive, and that's a small blemish on a vast canvas with so many more positives than negatives. High scores for the grand vision and overall execution.

142709051.review: reminds me of the good old days where, me and my friends, playd and loved the big box games from the SNES, like Secret of Mana/Evermore, Illusion of Time, Terranigma and so on. i loved these games and missed all the years something similar. There it is "Hyper Light Drifter" but it plays so much smoother bcs it's not running on the SNES ^^ The art design is very unique and thoughtful put together. When you know how the gameplay and worldbuilding works, you can rush like crazy through the game. But for many of you and for me, it will take some time to get into, especially the chaindashes. 141658824.review: A masterpiece action-oriented Zelda-like with some of the most powerful environmental storytelling I've ever seen. Heart Machine knew what they were doing with the rough pixel art style and the non-verbal communication. Two early examples that are burned in my memory: Ran into a drunken, homeless creature in an alleyway of the hub town. Through a couple of picture stories he tells me how he was beaten and his body broken by a gang of locals. Then exploring the upgrade shops I notice the gun store owner is the same character prominently featured as one of the gang in his flashback. Now I feel inspired to play with the basic pistol upgrade to avoid that thug. Next, I head to a gorgeous waterfall and aqueduct dungeon area with artifacts of the lost civilization that built it, a race of sentient ferrets who decorated their land with gorgeous fountain statues and tile mosaics depicting their kind. Continuing to explore the first enemy I run into is a shuriken-throwing ninja toad tossing the body of a dead ferret on a pile of corpses. The deeper I go the more of these toads I see with the pelts of ferrets staked out to dry by their tents. The game never said a word or displayed any lore text; these things I saw in the world touched me more deeply than that.

I went into this game with a high expectations, the pixel art was really pretty and the combat felt nice at first, but the more I kept playing it the less I started enjoying it. 

As I went around the map I hit what felt like dead ends, which were really frustrating as the solution would often end up being some super hidden area, often this was due to the perspective or due to other map elements hiding it.

Another thing I noticed was whenever I got hit was barely having "iframes" or invisibility frames which lead to me getting hit over and over again while getting stuck on everything. The guns feel nice, or most of them atleast do, but I found myself only really using one of the piercing weapons since it far outperformed every other weapon in most combat situations.

And don't get me started on the dash mechanic, at first it's like "woo I'm going fast" but it's super jank and required for most of the game, it's esspecially bad once the game expects you do have an optional upgrade to complete puzzles required for beating the game, an upgrade which I could've just not gotten at the shop which would've locked me behind grinding. Once you finally do get the upgrade you'll quickly find how it's even more jank than dashing by itself.

The last gameplay related thing I wanna mention is that I often found myself hitting the menu/map button and die during combat since opening the menu doesn't actually pause the game and just lets you die while you panic.

One of the ups the game does have for me is that the music is and sound fx are really nice and well made, but the glaring problem is that you have NO way of turning down the cutscene volume in the settings so it just blows out your ear drums every time.

Overall I'd give the game a 3.5 or a 4/10, if you think it's a game you might like due to it's metriodvania / zelda like gameplay as I did then please take my above points into account before buying it, and remember you can get a refund if you play less than 2 hours within the first 2 weeks of you buying the game.

English is my third language, so I hope this kinda made sense.

141219139.review:
I have this game on Epic as a freebie and completed everything it has to offer. I bought it here. That should be an indicator of how good this is. If you want to dodge my lengthy writing style, the TLDR is that it's well worth your 20 dollars and your time.



Hyper Light Drifter may be the best experience I've ever had in any game I've played. Note that word "experience". It's not any individual aspect of Hyper Light Drifter that made me love it so much, but how it all culminates in a near-transcendent experience that completely floored me with its quality. I've never in my time playing games been so taken aback by a non-story related event in a game that I had to stop playing and soak it in. It happened two times within the span of half an hour here. This quality makes it difficult to explain convincingly, but I promise that if you dig what this game is putting down on a surface level, you will see what I mean after giving it a chance to do its thing.

As far as a basic synopsis of systems go, it's got simple yet satisfying and responsive combat based around comboing gunshots from a handful of varied weapons and a small pool of blade related attacks to regain ammo. The general gameplay feels like a mixture off Zelda and Metroid, focused around exploration of absolutely stunningly rendered pixel art environments. The music is some of the best I've heard in any game when taken within the contexts it's presented here, and each and every track is a masterpiece, albeit not half as traditionally earwormy as what rises to the top of game music discussion. The story is told wordlessly through environment and small picture based dialogue from a small handful of NPCs, and despite its cryptic nature (which provides solid reason to replay among many other things) ends with a heavy impact. As I said before, while solid, none of these elements [spoiler] Except the music, and you can fight me on that. [/spoiler] alone is the best of any game I've played, but it absolutely smashes [u] every single game I have ever played in my life [/u] with the finesse it displays when weaving it all together.

As a closer, I'm going to discuss playtime since I have relatively few hours here compared to my Epic account. In total between the two platforms I have about 40 hours. I think this is a relatively accurate pin on what you can expect if you do everything this game has in each of its alternate modes starts post-finish. It's nothing of a cost to playtime ratio compared to the forever games common these days, but I promise you that the experience this delivers will stick with you far longer and far stronger than the hundreds of hours you pour into a roguelike or multiplayer title. It's easily worth the entry cost, and I doubt many interested in the systems I described briefly earlier will have anything but a fantastic time with it.

140878171.review:
Hyper Light Drifter is a game that wants you to get lost, on every level. And that's great.
The story is abstract to the extreme. I would argue against trying to read up on it. It's interesting to try and interpret it yourself, to take it at face value and get lost in it.
The world is intricate and obtuse. You'll never be quite sure where you are or where you're going. Which means that the important part is always to go somewhere. It can give you the feeling of being turned around in the wilderness, of thinking you might know the way forward or the way back, and only being bale to know for sure by taking a path. Every secret peppered around the place feels like a discovery- and even on my third playthrough, I'm still finding places i haven't before.
I struggle to say much about the art, music and combat when it comes to this central idea of being lost, but suffice to say they are all beautifully done.

In short, this game really makes you feel like a hyper light drifter. If you think you can enjoy things making little sense, then go for it- you probably won't regret it.

140758375.review:
Playtime is roughly 9.5 hours at time of writing (Steam does not display Offline Playtime)

This is one of those masterpiece games that you get hooked on for a couple of weeks and feel deep in your bones that something about your existence has changed. Hyper Light Drifter is a culmination of so many excellent and unique ideas, on every level of its design and execution, that you can't help but feel it's some higher level of art that can only be experienced in this medium of video games. 

I think something that immediately stands out right from when you start the game is that there isn't any voice acting... and there isn't any dialogue or readable language anywhere in the game beyond the start menu and the pause menu. The story is masterfully crafted and told through visuals alone, and the environmental storytelling is so rich that you can clearly connect some dots with the world building, and the ancient civilizations, and the struggles of the inhabitants of the land. It is hard to explain without playing it, but it's something I really appreciated because I felt like I was the one putting the puzzle pieces of the narrative together as I recall flashes of images and the environment and string it together into a crazy weaving plot. Very cool.

Speaking of environments, these are breathtakingly beautiful. All the sprite work is phenomenal as well. There's some spots where I just sat looking at how pristine the landscapes were. Man. They did such a good job. Very beautiful game.

The soundtrack is another thing. Incredibly atmospheric. Sets the tone exceptionally well. You'll hear a few background instruments hum mysteriously as you traverse the dreary land, you'll hear a couple more frenetic yet excellent sounding battle tracks, and a couple of tracks in between. In any case, you can be certain that your time in Hyper Light Drifter will be well accented with appropriately delectable music.

And what is it that you'll do in Hyper Light Drifter? I've yet to mention the combat, and besides exploring and some simple platforming puzzles, it is the bread and butter of the game. It's simple to learn, but hard to master. You have limited ammo and a couple gun types for long range attacks, and you have a sword for short range attacks. Landing sword hits returns ammo to your equipped gun. There's also a dodge that makes you briefly invincible. You'll traverse the world fighting enemies and getting upgrades (in a very very loose metroid-vania fashion), with your main task being to collect 4 of an item, in order to face a final boss.

Combat is fast and fluid. The enemies are unique and it's fun learning to counter each one and their individual move sets. Bosses and mini bosses abound and they are really fun to challenge. But if you find this to be too easy, you get a much harder difficulty after your first completion of the game. I found the difficulty curve on normal to be perfectly paced, and when I finished I did think I was well prepared to try the more challenging difficulty.

Ultimately, I really fell in love with Hyper Light Drifter and would recommend it to just about anybody. These days you can find it for pretty cheap, as it is quite a number of years old now, but it is such a good game that  I think it's well worth your time, and your money. If you're on the fence get it! I really believe it is worth the journey and experience, and I hope that many more people continue to get the opportunity to play it. Thanks to my bud for gifting this to me over the holidays! I played literally all of it on plane rides lol (hence the offline playtime that did not count)

140738657.review:
Hyper Light Drifter is a truly stunning game that I highly recommend to anyone who enjoys exploration and challenging gameplay. The game takes place in a beautiful, vast and ruined world filled with dangers and lost technologies.

One of the things I love most about Hyper Light Drifter is its level design. Each level is intricately designed and offers a unique challenge to players. The game's puzzles are also well-designed and offer a perfect balance of challenge and reward.

The game's music is also fantastic. The soundtrack perfectly captures the mood and atmosphere of the game, and the music is both hauntingly beautiful and perfectly timed. The sound effects are also well-done and add to the immersion of the game.

However, the one downside to Hyper Light Drifter is its somewhat stiff controls. While the game's mechanics are well-designed, the controls can feel a bit clunky and unresponsive at times. This can be frustrating when trying to navigate through difficult levels or engage in combat.

Overall, Hyper Light Drifter is an excellent game that I highly recommend to anyone who enjoys challenging gameplay and beautiful visuals. While the controls may take some getting used to, the game's level design, music, and overall atmosphere make it a must-play for anyone who loves exploration and adventure.

139704633.review:
[h1] A Post-Apocalyptic Wonderland [/h1]

After three tries, I was angry at the bird-like sorcerer that just would not die. After 10, I had made up a few new curse words and temporarily damaged my gamepad. By the time I stopped counting I was just running through the motions, but was inching closer to finally beating him. Finally, I landed the death blow – but was killed at the exact moment that I killed him. I respawned, angry but determined to finally take him down once and for all. But he was already dead. Apparently, I had killed him just before he had killed me, and although I respawned, he did not. The win felt hollow. Unearned. I believe this may be the first time I have ever been disappointed after defeating a difficult enemy in a game.

This was the first and only moment of disappointment I felt when playing Hyper Light Drifter.

To call Hyper Light Drifter a good game is a disservice. It is enthralling, spellbinding, captivating, and any other multi-syllable complimentary term you can think of. “Retro-inspired” independent games are hardly rare, and yet the “inspired” part more often than not applies primarily, if not exclusively, to the art style. While Hyper Light Drifter has stunning pixel art, the game itself, its very essence, draws inspiration from some of gaming’s greatest pioneers. The unforgiving difficulty, fantastical setting, and wordless story blend together seamlessly, marrying the novel with the familiar with the type of synergy that that many have attempted and few have achieved so effectively.

When the game opens, you don’t know who you are or how you found yourself in this neon post-apocalyptic wonderland. Your enigmatic protagonist is alone, wandering aimlessly on a desperate mission to find something. The land is ruined, and the few who remain seem as lost as you. The story is not explicitly spelled out, rather serves as the implied tale of a mysterious figure desperately trying to survive both his environment and his own body and mind. There are no conversations – any stragglers you attempt to interact with respond with incoherent shapes (a foreign language, perhaps) or short, one sided pictographic conversations. Not a word is uttered, to you or to your character. Rather, the tale unfolds using the dystopian atmosphere as the sole means of conveying the narrative – a daring approach, and one that would likely fail with lesser titles. This particular game, however, delivers masterfully, grabbing me from the first scene and holding firm until the finale.

Exploration is key in Hyper Light Drifter, from the overall goal – which you don’t know – to which way you are supposed to go – which you also don’t know. You’re almost immediately greeted by multiple paths, which each individually lead to more paths, dead ends, and a fair amount of backtracking that manages to never feel irritating. The landscape dances the line between Escherian and Hyrulean, splattered with a seemingly unending swarm of hellish beasts and savage post-apocalyptic soldiers. There is no “empty space” in the game. Even dead ends hold the possibility of finding a much needed health pack or an additional piece of currency. The four main areas of the game have both a distinctive aesthetic and unique adversaries – which leads us to the best part of Hyper Light Drifter: the combat.

Combat is equally frantic and methodical, with your character balancing calculated evasive dashes with desperate swordsmanship. Button mashing will land you in a grave, with the game giving you multiple weapons and demanding that you master each of them. Slashing with your sword is limited, requiring specific timing and cool-down periods. Firearms have limited ammunition, which can be recharged by either cutting down items (like bushes, pots, or crystals) or by slashing enemies. The type of enemy you will face, and the density with which they appear, changes rapidly. It’s not uncommon to be trapped in a cordoned off area with ten or more enemies with varying movements, skills, and threat levels. In every different encounter you have to quickly assess the situation, size up the movements of the enemies you’ll be facing, and determine which weapons to use, whether or not you have time to carefully aim a firearm, when to dash, and most importantly, who to take out first.

The environment itself poses just as much of a threat as your rivals, with disappearing sections of flooring, crystals that spring from the ground and impale you, and flames that shoot from vents should you step just a bit too close. Both combat and navigation call for precise refinement and finesse that, somehow, does not feel suffocating. The game is punishing, but it is also fair. If you think health packs are going to carry you through the game, think again. Your health is limited, and even packing away a few healing agents will do you no good when you’re facing off against swarms of enemies without a plan in place. However, when you are killed you will respawn nearby with all of the items that you had prior to dying.

Upgrades are available for purchase, and range from the ability to carry additional health packs to improved dashing techniques. In order to obtain these upgrades, you must collect the in-game currency, which presents in the form of small golden chips. Four individual chips fit together to create one piece of currency – think The Legend of Zelda‘s heart containers – and most upgrades require two or three pieces of currency.

The stunning aesthetics and spellbinding journey are emphasized by evocative music. For a story that is told without words, music is paramount. Exploration is accompanied by somber tracks which build organically as you approach an enemy, culminating in a grand, urgent score for boss fights.

The only true complaint I can muster is that the keyboard and mouse controls are terrible – however, you are advised when the game is booting up that it is best played with a controller, so to hold this point against Heart Machine would be a bit unfair.

Throughout the first few areas I was completely lost, with no clue where any particular path would lead me, what would greet me at the end of the path, or whether or not I would succumb to external or internal forces. Shortly after I found myself engaged in frantic combat, immersed in an inscrutable yet downright captivating story that held strong right until the satisfying finale. It is an enchanting, haunting title that masterfully captures the excitement and the fear of the unknown. My time with Hyper Light Drifter feels more like a place that I once visited than a game that I once played.

Hyper Light Drifter is a breathtaking game that draws heavily from gaming’s most prominent pioneers without relying too heavily on their influence. It is an eclectic masterpiece that feels more like an experience than a video game.

139229240.review:
Hyper Ligth Drifter es una aventura de acción en 2d con perspectiva cenital (o eso se dice aunque al ser ligeramente inclinado pensaba que es un picado) con mucho énfasis en el combate. 

Si vemos solamente imágenes y rascamos la superficie nos puede recordar un action rpg futurista en 2D al ver escenarios y alguna pelea. Este juego propone un combate con un alto ritmo, nos espera una alta cantidad de enemigos con  mecánicas diferentes cada uno a la vez que ofrece al jugador herramientas variadas para enfrentarse a ellos combinándolas siendo realmente muy satisfactorio acabar con una sala llena de enemigos y trampas. Y funciona bien el combate? FUNCIONA MUY BIEN, retante, divertido, con posibilidades. Hay algo mas aparte de luchar? Bueno, algún interruptor escondido o trampas pero son minoría.

Como contrapunto no profundiza en la parte rpg. Solo tenemos un pueblo, no hay diálogos (de esto hablo luego), hay pocas mejoras del personaje. Esto no es malo, es una decisión de estudio imagino que también condicionada por el presupuesto (vienen de un Kickstarter).

Ofrece un mundo de fantasía futurista muy chatarrero, unas razas que someten a otras y sufrimiento por doquier. Combina un 2d con una gama de colores limitada que luce bien (me gustan especialmente las zonas norte y este) y muy bien animado. Algún personaje canta un poco (ese perro de la plaza central lo he visto en la Atari 2600) pero son los menos.

Es minimalista y parco en palabras, no hay diálogos ni apenas mensajes en pantallas, los pocos NPCs con los que interactúas te muestras unas escenas para explicarte algo. Yo personalmente encuentro a faltar un poco de explicación de que efecto tiene un traje o una pistola que recoges, e incluso desbloquear algo que permita entender que dicen los NPCs. Un mapa que permitiera dejar notas o con más datos tampoco iría mal.

La música no sabría clasificarla pero parece una mezcla de lofi con algo de synthwave. Me gusta, tiene personalidad y se disfruta fuera del juego.

Juegazo de un estilo que aunque siempre divierte no todos lo hacen tan bien. Recomendado. Me lo volvería a pasar.

Cosas a destacar positivas:
•El combate es un vicio, querrás repetir la sala sin gastar curación solo por demostrar que eres capaz.
•Buena música.
•Trabajo artístico diferencial y llamativa ambientación.

Cosas a destacar negativas:
•Demasiado minimalista, un poco de texto explicativo no vendría mal a su lore (en los detalles están los recuerdos) o saber qué narices hace exactamente tal arma.
•No sé qué clase de mente perversa a diseñado el dash/esquivar encadenado(juego con mando y tengo la sensación que sigo sin entender ni su tempo ni cómo funciona) ni en qué hora propuso esas salas en las que debes usarlo. Me he pasado algunas a suerte y todas muriendo cientos de veces. Apunto que las difíciles no son obligatorias para terminar el juego.

138791770.review:
Man thought he could remake paradise, and exile God from his self-made Eden, by stealing one more bite from the fruit of the Tree of Knowledge. Now he must traverse the devastated world wrought by his vindictive hubris, scraping a meagre survival in the utter damnation of his second Fall. This is Hyper Light Drifter: a game full of death, and anger, and loneliness, and the minute hope to be restored to Glory. Let it patiently tap its way into your imagination -- let it breathe its chilling environments and music, outstanding enemy and sound design, old-school timing-based combat, cheeky secrets, and labyrinthine Metroid-esque exploration into you -- and you'll realize how few action-adventure games can equal or compare to this. Soulful but self-effacing; provocative but empathetic; silent but complete.

[i]He said to the woman, “Did God really say, ‘You must not eat from any tree in the garden’?”

The woman said to the serpent, “We may eat fruit from the trees in the garden, but God did say, ‘You must not eat fruit from the tree that is in the middle of the garden, and you must not touch it, or you will die.’”

“You will not certainly die,” the serpent said to the woman. “For God knows that when you eat from it your eyes will be opened, and you will be like God, knowing good and evil.”[/i]

I really wanted to like this game. 
Maybe it gets better- but first impressions are what counts, and my impression is that I'm getting a refund.
The controls feel really clunky, it feels similar to input lag - though there is none. I get what they're going for, something soulsy, sure. But in Dark Souls i still feel [i]in control.[/i] 

I tried playing with keyboard at first, but i prefer controller for these types of games, so I switched to a ps4 controller. This is when I realised this game has little to no actual settings. Personally, I really don't like the way the controller vibrates when on one hit point. And guess what? Cant turn it off. Worse still, the heartbeat rhythm that it vibrates in really sets off my anxiety. If you want people to play your game, you have to make it accessible.

I found the way that the camera doesn't really track the player very disorienting as well. Didn't help that Hyper light drifter's idea of difficulty is throwing you in a cramped space with a million things going on.

Also, I get the whole artistic view and stuff, but its so overwhelming having to navigate shop menus and things with no dialogue explaining what stuff is. Pixel art is really pretty though, and the animation at the beginning was stellar, though it did drag on a bit. I find the way some games present you with 10 minutes of lore before you even get to play really frustrating. You need to earn my investment in your story, not force it.

This is actually my second time trying this game; had it on switch a few years back. Gave up then, gave up now.

This game boasts impressive visuals and a captivating soundtrack, but its gameplay leaves much to be desired. As a 3-4ths perspective RPG, it's often unclear whether the game is tracking your movements based on your character's feet or their entire body, leading to frustrating inconsistencies in navigation. In contrast to a game like "Hades", which offers fluid and responsive mechanics, this game's movement and combat feels sluggish and heavy, even with upgrades.

The game's difficulty often feels more like a punishing slog than a rewarding challenge. Instead of providing an exciting experience that encourages exploration and experimentation, it seems designed to make you want to give up. This game highlights the difference between genuine difficulty and simply fatiguing the player with what eventually dissolves to feel like tedious obstacles. 

Gorgeous game, amazing music, but a pain to play.

136447854.review:
I must express my absolute adoration for the soundtrack of the game. The electrifying tunes captured me from the first minute and never let go. It reminded me a lot of the music from Boards of Canada, which is one of my favorite bands. Moreover, this kind of music suits the setting of HLD perfectly: a cyberistic, post-apocalyptic world where beauty still exists amidst death and decay.

In terms of gameplay, it flows smoothly, and the fights have a good variety to them. You have many weapons at your disposal, and it feels great to mix things up with slow and heavy attacks, dashes, and gunshots. However, the balancing feels a bit off, as I felt too powerful after some upgrades, particularly in some of the boss fights. I think the developers could have increased the damage of some bosses to make them more challenging, which apperently is a thing in NG+.

HLD also has a fantastic feature where you can chain up dashes by pressing the button at the exact same millisecond. At first, I thought it was impossible to do it more than three times, but with some practice, I mastered it. It's such a rewarding feeling to almost fly through the beautiful world in hyper speed.

While I don't have particularly strong feelings about the pixel aesthetic, it's pleasant to look at and fits the setting. However, I wonder how it would look with the same art style as Hollow Knight.

The story of HLD is cryptic and only shown, not told. I enjoyed it, as NPCs tell their stories through pictures in their heads, and players can fill in the gaps with their imagination.

136444695.review:
El arte pixelado que tiene es vibrante y evocador que crea una atmósfera emocionalmente intensa. La paleta de colores brillantes y saturados del juego genera un ambiente oscuro y misterioso que es único y cautivador. 

Además del estilo de arte, la música es también una parte esencial de la experiencia del juego. La banda sonora del juego es emotiva y cautivadora, con una mezcla de sonidos electrónicos y acústicos que complementan perfectamente el estilo de arte y la narrativa del juego. 

En cuanto a la narrativa del juego, esta es sutil y emotiva, y sé no se cuenta de manera directa, si no en gran parte a través de imágenes y entornos. Por lo que debes explorar y descubrir el mundo del juego por sí mismos y la historia del Drifter y su enfermedad se revela de manera gradual a medida que avanzan en el juego. 

7/10, ya que más de una vez te vas a perder en su mundo

135939448.review:
HLD has a lot to love about it. The level design is gorgeous and overflowing with secrets that reward skill and exploration in equal measure. The overall atmosphere and completely wordless storytelling really works for me, and I overall very much enjoyed my experience. The levels had enough variety to them to not feel same-y and the characters you meet along the way are quite endearing. 
It took about 7.5 hours to beat, with me finding about half of the secrets and taking 1-3 tries to beat each room. After beating the game you can go back into your save just before the end to hunt secrets, which is always a good thing.
There's also a fair amount to dislike, though. The combat is fairly jank, with your character getting stunlocked a lot. The difficulty is at a good level, but skirts the edge of bullshit sometimes, especially in some bossfights. There's an upgrade that allegedly lets your dash absorb bullets that would help for some of the bullet hell sections of the last level, but for whatever reason it only works if you [i]start[/i] your dash near enough the oncoming fire, which often means you confidently dash forwards into some lovely damage.
These issues only really are a problem in boss fights and are otherwise not super noticeable, but if you're prone to frustration it will definitely sully the experience. This is otherwise a really great game

135201979.review:
Hyper Light Drifter is pretty fun as games go.  It's the kind of game that takes a lot of influence from classic titles like Zelda and Metroid. As a matter of fact the game plays like someone shoved both into the same room and what emerged was a singular gestalt entity. Stronger than both, but also a little deformed. Sadly, as we all know, fusion dances between games often result in debilitating illnesses. Like tedious challenges, underwhelming rewards, and thanking Anita Sarkeesian in your end credits.

I do want to clarify at this point: this is a *GOOD* game. But it is also a game of many petty frustrations. So let's get my gripes out of the way.

The story is kind of useless. Even years later no one knows what happened outside of some broad speculation. There are only a couple paragraphs of text in the whole game explaining anything, and even those are hidden and need to be decoded. And even then they tell you next to nothing. So don't go into this expecting a good story - this game operates purely on vibes. And to be fair, the vibes are pretty nice.

For what it actually matters, the story is such: You're a traveling magician dude infected with sentient super cancer. Journeying to a post apocalyptic land that is trying to rebuild after a war with some giants, in search of some crystallized chemo. Sadly, even when 90% of the world is dead and endemics of sentient super cancer on the rise, the local furry community can't get along with eachother and are in a constant state of genocide, slavery, and light cannibalism. 

Fortunately, as a magician you have many tricks up your cloak, which include but are not limited to: an arsenal of guns, grenades, a sword that can cut missiles in half and deflect bullets, and the ability to drift faster than the speed of light: a hyper light drifter, if you will. Using these tools, you must travel in the four cardinal directions and reactivate your local cancer treatment facility. While expanding your tools and equipment to handle each challenge you face.

On the subject of challenges: be sure to unlock your chain dash first and foremost. The chain dash is a finicky and unreliable move that requires fairly exact timing to pull off consistently. However it is also essential for combat, movement, and exploration. I honestly don't know why you even have to unlock this move - as you're pretty much useless without it. Sadly this is a common theme for most moves and equipment in this game - they range from nearly essential to profound waste of time.

Secondly: head east starting out. You won't be able to appreciate this suggestion until you beat the first boss, but trust me: you want to head east.  This is another design choice I'm not fond of, and it ties into my previous complains about the unlocks and the story and well... everything. 

This game loves secrets. There are secrets and goodies all over the place, but the problem is that you don't always have the means to access them. Or the game hits you with a big challenge inside a hard to find secret. OR you didn't have the means to access them so you have to come all the way back and your map is practically useless for memorizing layout and... you get the picture. 

I suppose that brings me to my *big* complaint: there is very little reason to explore. The gear you find in secrets are underwhelming, the lore you find in secrets are underwhelming, the guns you find are objectively worse than the ones the game gives your through story progress, the keys you find (four to an area btw) don't unlock anything of use when compared to the time spent pressing your face to a wall, even the module crystals - these ancient and mystical pieces of tech that are core to the game's story. You only need to find 4 in each area out of 8. Finding the other 4 in each area just gets you more of the underwhelming gear I had mentioned. 

Normally a game like this would have a good ending and a bad ending depending on how much of a completionist you are. Like you would get half the MacGuffins and you'd see the villain twirling his mustache at the end slate because you didn't find them all. The game doesn't do that. Finding all is exactly the same as finding the bare minimum - so again, no point. Even if you play the game on NG+, there is no change.

All this suggests that this is a game that really wants to sell itself on the visual presentation and challenge of the mechanics alone. And while the visuals are very nice, some screen shots of pixel art (stellar as they are) does not a 20 dollar game make. 

So all that leaves is the combat. This part is admittedly pretty good. You have a fast and fluid combat system that rewards on the fly thinking, aggressiveness, and twitch reflexes. The problem is that it is still unpolished with very clear violations of its own rules. So while a singular playthrough is fun, maybe replaying it again years down the line when the memories have faded - it is not the kind of game conducive to repeat plays.

Also the dash challenge is one of the most boring and pointless time sinks I have ever seen in a game. Worst part is that the devs were very clearly showing *restraint*. They wanted to make it 1000 dashes but settled on 800. Why not 200? Seriously, you made us do 100 for the first reward, why not 200? No one likes the dash challenge - it isn't fun or interesting - it is literally pressing a single button in a metronome. It's funny because they put the only *GOOD* reward behind a challenge no one likes.

I've been pretty negative, but I do recommend this game. It has a lot of flaws but it is presented so well and does so much right that I'm inclined to forgive it. It just goes to show that sometimes it pays not to look too deeply at something, otherwise you start to see the pimples and pock marks. Keep it simple, stupid.

135116678.review:
I was fairly excited to finally play this game but I'm incredibly dissapointed.

I decided to use M+KB after googling around for what people preffered.
I enjoyed the first hour or so.

After that it was made obvious that it tried to be a "hard" soulslike in all the wrong ways.
Combat feels bad in this game. It's not difficult but you're locked into almost anything you do for a couple of frames so if you do a bad dash/hit you will get punished, chain hit and die.
At the same time most enemies get stunned when you hit them so if you line them up right you are the one chain-hitting them to death.

This wouldn't feel so bad if the dash didn't feel like utter garbage to use. After dashing you stop/slow down for a second or so which makes everything feel less fluid.
There's an upgrade you can buy to "chain" dash, but they decided to make it a frame perfect thing that is unintuitive to get used to.
I assume the devs didn't want people to just spam dashes, but this is the worst way to go about solving that "issue".

To make it worse, a fair amount of optional "purple things" are behind dashing puzzles.
My original plan was to at least collect all of those and beat the main story.
I tried for some time with one of the dashing puzzles, got fairly close until I realized that it's not even fun getting good at it.

[u] Bossfights suck in this game. [/u]
They get worse and worse as you progress and essentially turn into using your best gun as much as possible with a few slashes in between to recharge it.
Hitboxes are wonky and difficult to eyeball.
The worst offenders when it comes to the bosses are the west side one and the final boss.
I felt nothing beating the final boss, it took me about 5~ tries but none of the deaths felt "good" due to the strange hitboxes.

I do really like the artstyle and the atmosphere of the game.

The story didn't really do anything for me with how vague it was, but that's not a major issue for me.

It's truly a shame because this game could have been so very good, but because the devs wanted to make a "difficult" game the actual gameplay suffered.

Hopefully the next games from this developer do not retread the mistakes of this one.

134859770.review:
No time for a review so I give this game a rank B.
Good game - if you have time give it a chance!
See my profile for more details about my reviews.

Additional notes: well I am glad I bumped on the stupid controversy some young people are creating regarding the 3rd, Breaker! I thought it was weird young generations confused general anthropomorphism with weird modern fetishisms, so I checked Drifter... and I had bought that game 5 years ago! I thought it was time to give it a chance, and I did well! This little indie game is remarkably good and unique! Imagine a souls lite (quite hard) mixed with Zelda but without much puzzle, no dialogues, dark atmosphere of a sci-fi/dystopian fantasy... First, the game is a bit hard indeed, but it still only took me less than 10 hours to finish it. Also, I won't bother with all the secrets, but DAMN is this game PACKED with secrets! In old Zelda, you knew where to look for secrets as there would be about 1 in each level, on average. Here? There is one secret EVERY SCREEN. Crazy generous. Talking about generous: my goodness is this game pretty. Beautiful illustrations full of dark yet colorful pixels, in the same vein as a Crying Suns and all this dark pixelized school. Sublime.
The gameplay is a bit tough to manage at first, but then you get used to it, and all the upgrades in a zelda/metroidvania fashion make it easier. Tough (you can die in a few hits, it is a Souls lite after all) and brutal, but never unfair.
Did I mention the music? the sound effects but especially the soundtrack are AMAZING. How modern and advanced is that writing, very dark but very rich and harmonically very deep. Congrats to the composer.
Overall, all these positive things come together with one final, remarkably unique touch: the lore. The world of this game, its creatures, its narration (without words!), its scenery, characters, villages, monsters, ruins... EVERYTHING is so unique and beautiful (a bit reminiscent of Caves of Qud, Ashen, Shadow of Colossus etc) that I would accept any comic, manga or anime in this world. For now, I am just very eager to play the spin off they did, and am super excited about their next one, Breaker!
The only reason this game did not get a A for GREAT game for me is mostly the length (finished in 2 days), and the content (it is very pretty, unique and atmospheric, but its depth and reach are limited - poetic, just not on the long run enough). Aside from that? A fantastic, artistic, generous, authentic studio with a very good game here.

133252067.review:
This game is hard to recommend, but ultimately quite worth the time you put into it.

The game is an absolute masterpiece when it comes to storytelling, it leaves a lot open to interpretation and is able to convey an extremely compelling story through zero spoken or written language at all.

The music is sublime. There isn't a single track I'd dunk on, the credits music is just fantastic (also extremely high quality recording).

The gameplay is a bit less fantastic.
+Combat is fun and satisfying. Despite being very simple, the enemy variety and different special abilities allow for quite deep combat mechanics.
+Enemies are largely unique to zones which allows for a fair bit of variety in a single playthrough. The handful of enemies that aren't unique to zones are never annoying or difficult.
-A lot of bosses feel extremely unfair due to their random sequence of abilities. Sometimes that's fine, like with the last boss where all his abilities are properly telegraphed. Other times it just means you get to restart, like on the crystal forest boss if he decides to summon friends three times instead of once.
-The save points the game gives you are absolute bullshit half the time. You cleared out a massive area that took you 10 minutes, one stray bullet hits you at the end and you get to do it all over again. Just collected a couple of hidden items? Do that again too.

What's weird about these issues is that they seem to be completely absent in the final area in the south of the map. All of the bosses have fairly telegraphed moves, save points are abundant and it's generally a very rewarding area to complete.

I recommend this game to anyone looking for a mild challenge and compelling retro graphics.

After completing HLD, I realized that this is one of the best games I've played in a while. I'm not huge on the low-poly pixel art style, but I still think it's a one of the best atmospheres I've seen in a game. The environments are quite beautiful and interesting and the story (told through visual images only) is engaging. The soundtrack is probably the highlight of the game IMO and introduced me to Disasterpeace which until I looked up on Spotify I didn't realize he had done the It Follows soundtrack. The gameplay is a mix of exploration and having to figure out the upgrade mechanics without being told where to go next (which I love) and average difficulty combat. I saw another reviewer describe it as souls-like but I don't see it at all. When you die, you don't lose anything except whatever you might've picked up since your last save which is usually only a minute so ago.

My only gripe with the game is the random stutters I had in the southern area that I didn't really experience elsewhere.

I definitely recommend this even at full price and I'm looking forward to seeing what Heart Machine does with HLB as long as Gearbox doesn't get their dirty hands on the development process.

131848852.review:
My one complaint is that I wish it was longer.

The art style is lovely, the the world design is immersive, the lore is interesting, and the gameplay--the best part of this game--is perfect. Having to refill your ammo by doing melee attacks is ingenious and leads you in to a natural rhythm, and the snappy dash helps to perfectly maintain the momentum of the fight. As you get more weapons and upgrades, you get to change up the rhythm you've been playing into your own special dance. Save for the South Zone, the game is largely nonlinear in its progression, but as you get used to all the controls, you can definitely feel yourself getting stronger with every zone you clear. But by the time you feel like you've mastered the controls, the game is already at its final stretch.

I've only finished the game once, as of writing this, and I want to finish it again, over and over. I want to master it until I can get the deathless achievement, and still play it even after that. This game really is something special, I just wish that initial rush of the first playthrough wasn't so short lived.

131354933.review:
1) Story: 3/5. I honestly had no idea what was going on since it's a minimalist story, but I still liked the story telling aesthetic and style. I was able to put more and more together as the game went on, but by the end of it I still didn't have a full picture other than you got ghosts in your blood.
2) Characters: 2/5. Again minimalist story, so minimalist characters, also there were no real major characters other than the main one. The most emotion I got from the main character in this game was him doing a fun flourish with his sword after you clear a boss or a challenge encounter.
3) Setting: 5/5. Very interesting world to explore and to find what's out there. I guess that's the trade-off of a minimalist story is that most your experience if shifted to the setting and gameplay (DS1?). I'm normally not a fan of sci-fi which worked out since there was good blend of natural into the unnatural, and how you can infer the unnatural has corrupted the natural leading to the events of the game.
4) Music: 3/5. It fit the mood as it was some low-energy, ambient synth music. There was no differentiation between ambient and combat music, which worked well in this case to not break the flow. The game flowed nicely as you moved from room to room, fight to fight, and the music helped keep it all contiguous rather than feeling like a dungeon crawl.
5) Gameplay: 5/5. I think this is the main reason why everyone would play this game. Outside of boss fights, the movement and combat was pretty smooth. Combat could definitely get challenging at times, but was always very reward and felt really good. You only ever have 5 health over the whole game so you can't take much of a beating. You definitely learn and get good with the controls over the game so the health isn't so bad of hurdle to get over. However, I'm not sure why but the controls during boss fights specifically felt off. They were always infuriating, as if there was pre-programmed input lag and end lag to add artificial difficulty, I just never understood it. That controls issue with bosses persisted the whole game, but outside of bosses, the controls were totally fine for some reason. As the name of this game implies, I do recommend getting the chain dash ASAP so you can go whoosh-whoosh-whoosh-... for forever in a blip of light until you smack into something with a loud thud and your character just plops on the floor. It's pretty funny and you don't take damage, so worth it.

All in all, I'd give it a 72%, C-, yeah that feels about right. It's more worth it if it was slightly cheaper.

Aside from the beautiful art style to capture the gamer's attention, the game was very difficult to learn gameplay strategy, what you're doing, and best upgradeable abilities. I needed to watch a simple "how to" video after a couple of hours to playing to adjust my mindset on how to play the game. I knew that once I got the gameplay mechanics down, I could finally enjoy it for the game's full potential.

I wish the story was more telling. But the lore can be surmised through the different areas and themes of each map area. I knew some of the history of the developer and that helped with the meaning of the game. 

The game's map is just good enough to show you the routes but not exact locations of objects. The map is a guide but not for exact directions. I like to collect 100% of items in games so I knew I was going to be following a guide eventually.

The art style, enemies, and weapons and the "timing" mechanic are what sold it for me. I enjoyed the different enemies and their abilities/weapons and different bosses in each area. It really made the game special and memorable. More games like this please! 

The two areas that could use improvement are the chain dash and quicken the "timing" mechanic on firing the weapon and movement--may be has something to do with the game's animation? For the chain dash, please make the button pressing less time sensitive. I felt it spoiled some of the gameplay and enjoyment, and it left me at a 9/10 at times for ranking the game. Though ultimately, the game can be considered a 10/10. I am happy to pick up the game and finally set time to play through it.

Hyper Light Drifter, while beautiful, is simply too difficult to be fun for the average player. 
 They have no easy mode that allows casual players to enjoy the game. The "normal" difficulty is unacceptably hard and the controls are really clunky. (can't place my finger on why, i just never feel fully in control)
 As for the story/collectables, literally NOTHING is explained. just random images and repeated cut scenes that could honestly mean anything. i could put up with the vague story telling if they would explain the objectives or gameplay, but there's no way of knowing anything in this game. You don't even get to know what you're buying at the shop you just buy stuff based on a 3x6 pixel image and its almost never what you thought it was.

130717811.review:
To state it briefly, Hyper Light Drifter crafts an immaculate atmosphere while having the dense gameplay to keep things fun and interesting the whole way through.

The beautiful pixel art, ambient soundtrack, and minimalistic storytelling come together perfectly. The game's plot can be intentionally vague at times and leave things up to interpretation, and while that isn't for everyone, I think it does an excellent job at conveying all it needs through through the visuals and feelings of its events. It commits to having zero in-universe human writing beyond its tutorial, explaining everything through its visuals in a way that makes you feel like a stranger adrift in strange lands. You have to figure things out for yourself, and are mostly alone. Luckily all the important things are easy to grasp, but the effort it puts into conveying how Hyper Light Drifter makes its world feel cannot be understated, and this small touch really adds a lot to the immersion. Every area feels exactly as it needs to, be it the remains of a once-thriving civilization that has been all but slaughtered, a forbidden mechanical facility with dangers so great it had to be hidden from the rest of the world, or just a small haven in the wilds where another wanderer can offer you a moment of respite.

But how does it play? Luckily, Hyper Light Drifter is no slouch in its gameplay either. Combat is snappy and challenging, but always feels fair. All of your options are simple to understand, but have a lot of nuance in use. Each of the main areas of the game has multiple unique enemy types, and it feels rewarding to learn their patterns and when to dodge or attack. Combined with a slew of upgrades and weapons you unlock over the course of the game, fighting always feels fresh and interesting. You can even play the main areas of the game in any order you want, for a different perspective on their difficulty on multiple playthroughs.

This game also loves hiding secrets everywhere. It's very satisfying to piece together clues and figure out things suspicious about the surroundings in order to find treasure. Some of them get extremely convoluted, like fake walls within fake walls within fake walls. It's great.

Overall, Hyper Light Drifter is a very special game. On top of its satisfying combat and beautiful world, it's really just the kind of game that says a lot without needing to say anything at all.

I had to come back to this a few times before it worked for me. I backed the original kick starter and I only just finished the game this last time around after trying it again on my steam deck. I'm not sure if they patched the game to make it easier but it definitely seemed that way with this play through. It could also just be that after playing a few souls type games this does not compare in difficulty to those.

This is truly a magnum opus of a game, Preston and everyone who worked on it should be proud. However, I still would say that I wish it had more story to it. Even considering the "abstract" way it attempts to tell the minimal story it has, it is still lacking. Its fine, as I get the "impression" of a story, but it doesn't seem like it would've taken too much more effort here to improve it. I understand they were trying to emulate a general  SNES type game's storytelling, but I can think of more than a few SNES games I played that had full text conversations and lore and did not actively try to obfuscate the plot. 

The map stands out as the worst single aspect of the game. Any information it might have is obfuscated to the point of uselessness. 

It does seem like handheld is the best way to play this. If you have a switch and have not bought this on any platform yet, the switch version is apparently the way to go as it has exclusive content. 

Overall I would recommend this if the art and game play appeals to you.

129225294.review:
Hyper Light Drifter is solid. It does so much good in its visual and gameplay elements. The world you explore is beautifully designed. The gorgeous pixel art makes the world pop in a unique way that makes this game’s visual style one of a kind. It has this vibe of “Modernized Retro” it's a nod to SNES and Genesis graphics without holding itself back. The color palate is vibrant and makes every area feel distinct. The game just looks wonderful. It's the part that sticks out the most to me. The gameplay is like souls combat + zelda world exploration. But the games don't copy the mechanics and designs from games it takes inspiration from. It turns the ideas into something wholly unique. The combat hits similar beats to Dark Souls but there’s a lot to make it feel different. I have 1 big complaint however. 1. The story isn’t very compelling. In fact there isn’t really a story to speak of. Like I could summarize the story in a sentence. On a surface level there’s nothing there. It kinda feels like the story from Hollow Knight but without any of the plot elements. Just the background lore pushed to the forefront. There’s no dialog, Just pictures and cutscenes showing you stuff that’s occurring. When the credits rolled I was just confused on what the point of my journey was. Not to say that there’s nothing pulling and compelling you to explore each area. But the story just… wasn’t there. I’m sure that it was an intentional decision and it might be something you enjoy. But I just didn’t understand what I was experiencing. But the gameplay and visuals carried it for me. I highly recommend checking this one out. It looks and plays fantastic. Worth checking out if you like engaging combat and exploring beautiful environments. 


4/5 A short and sweet adventure
