129123441.review:
I wish I liked this game more than I do, but it's just not fun for me.  So far, enemies either come one or two at a time or as a swarm in a locked room, and there's no element of challenge to either.  Especially with the swarms, there's no sense of tactical choice for the player; you just keep trying over and over and hope you get a lucky enemy flow where you don't die.

Then there are other non-combat parts of the game, where you need slick movement and timing to get to your target.  If you fail, no problem, you respawn - except sometimes you respawn in a different spot, and sometimes you just teleport to a respawn point without actually dying, so now your progress is saved with fewer resources and the objective still unaccomplished.

You can tell a lot of work was put into the visual side of things, but the mechanics keep the game from actually being fun to play.  And a game I don't enjoy playing is a game I'm not going to play.  I have no desire to continue, and I wouldn't recommend Hyper Light Drifter to others, either.

129121690.review:
Yes, I recommend this game.

I bought this initially just because it looked cool. I wanted another game to break up my nights from repeated losses on Civ5. I am a noob at any form of gaming, but particularly PC gaming.

Hyper Light Drifter took me 6 hours to initially get the hang of. I had many questions like: where's the verbal dialogue? what are the names of these things? what the hell is wrong with the map? why can't I go south?

As someone who's not at all used to WASD/mouse gaming - this took some getting used to, along with the dash function. The game does provide enough spaces for you to learn. 

The incorporation of multiple regions of distinctly differing aesthetics and challenges, in terms of enemies, also made it very enjoyable, it felt more like 3 games than 1. I could pick and choose which route I wanted to go down on any given day, and I liked that. It wasn't fixed.

My second play through took 11 hours (still on newcomer, because I am still a newcomer) and with 18/32 pink triangles (name?) collected, I didn't do amazingly - but I didn't fail, evidently. The final boss was a pain, but it's meant to be, right?

If you can't get over the controls, or the lack of a solid story line (it's not necessary for this game IMO), and are unable to find the symbol that leads you to health/tokens/gearbits etc., you have to admire the graphics/artwork within. It is incredible, and honestly the main reason I bought the game initially.

Whilst when you go on a first date with someone and you need to force yourself to go on a second because "it was the first date, they'll get better" and they go and have sex with your best mate, this game will only grow on you and get better and better with each play through. I'm sure there's going to be >9000 more secrets to discover once I get back into it.

Hope this helps!

129068654.review:
Hyper Light Drifter is a good game overall, but it does have some notable rough edges. Before I get to those, let's start with the good stuff.

This game has [b]amazing[/b] presentation. Gorgeous pixel art, a fittingly melancholic soundtrack, and almost completely wordless visual storytelling all come together to create quite the vibe.

Then there's the combat. After the initial humiliation that comes from being killed in less than 5 seconds, you'll eventually work your way up to wiping out groups of hostiles equally quickly. The combat's progression mostly comes from the player getting better at it rather than boosting stats, which makes it extra satisfying.

That all sounds pretty good, so what rough edges should you be aware of? For me, the most notable problem is the game's pacing. It's easy to tell that some areas got way more developer attention than others, and the gaps between these content-rich areas can be rather boring.

Another problem is the map. While it's aesthetically pleasing, its different layers are either too vague or too difficult to read to give specifics for getting from point a to point b. This is kind of cool in the sense that it forces you to figure it out, but it can get very tedious when you just want to quickly backtrack to a specific spot. There's also no way to place map markers.

Lastly, the movement can feel clunky at times. Not enough to ruin the combat experience, but more than enough to make [spoiler]playing soccer against that stupid little goblin thing[/spoiler] a test of patience rather than skill. [spoiler]That little shit will stun-lock you any time you try to go after the ball while he's near it[/spoiler], highlighting the movement system's shortcomings.

Overall, I enjoyed the good parts of Hyper Light Drifter enough that I was willing to put up with its more tedious aspects. I recommend it as long as you're also willing to exercise some patience along the way.

128391506.review:
Pros:
- the pixel art and the animations are so nice
- the atmospheres are varied and immersive
- the cut scenes are cool
- the story is intriguing and just vague enough to keep you engaged
- the enemies are varied

Cons:
- the combat is a tremendous pain
- the sound design is okay but I wish it gave more info

So this game has a very nice art direction and the story is mysterious in a good way. But I really disliked the combat, and some design choices frustrated me to the point where it ruined my experience. Combat is very unforgiving, your character commits suicide way too easily, and checkpoints are sometimes very mean. All that would be okay if it didn't take 10 seconds to retry after dying, and if you had clearer sound design to help you. I don't know, some people like this kind of demanding gameplay, but I find it unnecessarily excruciating. Although I guess it fits with the mood of the game: this fragile character struggling through a hostile environment while being ill.

I'm happy to have played it and I don't think it's a bad game in any way, but I can't recommend it either.

128338887.review:
I enjoyed this game very much. The combat was fun, and I liked trying out all of the different guns. I also enjoyed the limited resources to upgrade your gear and abilities so you either had to make sacrifices as to what you choose to put upgrades into, or take the extra time to explore every nook an cranny.

I also enjoyed the visual storytelling, which is one of the main draws of the game. Not a single piece of dialog, just images and environments. It was fun to think about what might've caused this world to end up how it did, the origin and demise of the giant creature/statue things, etc.

I do have a few criticisms though. It was too easy to get stuck sometimes looking for modules or secrets if you didn't check every single tile on every single wall, and that got frustrating at times. I only used a guide once, and it was in the western area when I KNEW there was a module in one dungeon area but could not find out how to reach it, and it turned out to be in the very back corner in a cell of a room I had already checked dozens of times. Things like that happened less and less as I progressed, but it was still cumbersome at times.

Also the final boss was extremely underwhelming. I beat it in less tries than the western boss and some of the southern bosses as well. I was expecting there to be another phase of it or [i]something[/i]. Especially with all of the imagery of giant godlike monsters sprinkled throughout the game, the scary things in the tanks of the southern area (giant beating cyborg heart?!?!), and stuff like that. The climax was not very satisfying.

128090159.review:
I'm just gonna lay in on straight. I enjoyed the artwork, exploring the world, and the collectibles, but the negatived kept adding up for me. The combat was fine at first but got stale quickly, and was difficult to control at times, especially in fights with way too many enemies. There is also the issue of not being able to keep track of what you have and haven't collected on the map. I know this is a bit of a personal issue, but it is the main reason I will not be getting all of the gear bits (one of the 4 main collectibles).
The boss fights are fine, but a huge part of the game I just genuinely didn't click with was the story. It starts off confusing and ends with just as much explanation as it began with, a little bit of cutscene telling nothing. Characters do not talk in this game, they show you pictures that have very little direct meaning, and while this is normally a fun way to tell a story, I felt it was done poorly in this game. Barely anyone explains anything and even the pictures were extremely convoluted. I ended this game just thinking, "Why did I just do everything?". 
In the end, I have to say I do not recommend this game for someone looking for a solid experience to play to 100% completion. Story can be breezed through in like 2 hours if you get a handle on the combat, 4-6 if you struggle. The achievements are normal for the most part but there are some that are just so ridiculous (like dying one thousand times!!!) that are obviously there to garner play time. One day I will come back and get the rest of the achievements, but that day is not today. Horde mode was awful and I really hope the devs take the time to rework the really bad achievements (and add a collectable tracker on the map).

128041528.review:
Absolutely love the game and probably one of my favorites. The visuals and music are phenomenal. But I definitely can see how the game can turn off anyone.

The game is non-verbal. There are still cutscenes and some NPCs who will describe events through images. Much is left to the player's interpretation. There are also some cryptographic tablets hidden around the world which I assume offer some lore when deciphered. It does make combat a bit weird since you're not told the specifics of abilities and upgrades (notably, Chain Dash and Bullet Absorb) so when something doesn't work, you're just left wondering why.

I like the combat, it feels smooth and tight but it's not lenient. Chain-dashing is pretty hard to get accustomed to, there's a window after each dash during which you can perform the next dash, i.e., you can't just quickly press the dash button immediately one after another. The window decreases as you keep dashing but I'm not sure if there's a cap. There are even two achievements dedicated to dashing, one of them for reaching 800 dashes. 

There are no invincibility frames except for when you fall off a platform as well as one upgrade that lets you block projectiles when you dash but it seems like it only activates under certain conditions and not necessarily for the entirety of the dash.

There's also an impressive enemy variety. The only issues I see are that some areas are claustrophobic and most enemies have very low attack cooldown. Because there are no invincibility frames, there are some times where one hit is all it takes to get wiped out when confronted by multiple enemies within a small/enclosed area. The bosses are also pretty neat as long as you're used to the combat.

The game is also basically riddled with secret areas and collectibles. I did like trying to find them although I wish there was some way to mark stuff on the map because of the backtracking and how minimal the map is.

My favorite atmosphere. 

-This game has one of the best soundtracks. Very fitting to atmosphere that was built.

-Upgrades to Weapons-Health-Movement are available through exploration of the map (finding Credits? or what ever currency it is.) 

-Some parts of the map are available after certain progression of the story. Which makes backtracking a common thing in the game(For the first play through that is.). After a while you learn which way you need to go for necessities.

-Story is very indulging by being vague, you better explore thoroughly. I usually don't bother with stories that are this vague but this game has everything in it that it catched my attention. From the opening cutscene to end it was a great experiance.

125143841.review:
The prettiest pixels that you ever did see.

Very atmospheric and fun to explore, visuals and soundtrack and world are all great. 
It's definitely immersive and intriguing; there's a lot of the history of this world left up to interpretation but if anything that just adds to the mystery. Storytelling is entirely visual too, which I personally really liked. 

The en masse ambushes (which there are a lot of) can be a little frustrating at times, but you get there eventually. No problems with controls, but if I could change anything, it'd be the time it takes the character to stand back up after getting knocked over or running into a wall. (I died more times to that than I'd like to admit, be it from the vulnerability or accidentally falling over the edge of a cliff.)

I first started this game back in 2017, got almost to the end, but never finished it for some reason and lost all progress. Decided to pick it up again recently, determined to fully complete it this time, and I can honestly say it's just as good the second time playing.

The actual story part isn't super long, maybe 6-8 ish hours, but if you're trying to find everything there is to find or complete additional modes of the game then you can spend far longer discovering secrets and stuff, even if seemingly hours of that time may be spent attempting to win an infuriating soccer game against a tiny irritating creature who you're not allowed to destroy...

Recommend! 
(but if I see one more sheep demon with a rocket launcher, I'm out)

124849918.review: An absolutely fantastic game. The amazing artwork provides a unique and mystical atmosphere while the ambient and dynamic soundtrack create intriguing, gut wrenching, and pleasant scenes all the more worthwhile to experience. This game is art, art that has many interpretations, yet none seem correct. It creates a story and fills the world with characters that seem somewhat relatable, or at least able to empathize with, despite the lack of dialogue. Throughout the game, the story unfolds under your nose, and I feel like every time I play this game I discover something new about it. It's short, sweet, filled with secret puzzles, unlockable areas, and even bosses that you won't find on your first playthrough, climaxing in a multitude of awe and a rollercoaster of emotions upon reaching the end. I won't spoil the game, but you will be compelled to replay it once you've finished your first playthrough. This is by far a 10/10, and the game that inspired my love for Indie titles. Can't wait to see what this studio brings, especially with another Hyper Light game being recently announced.

123982845.review:
Hyper Light Drifter is a fine game, that fails to leave any lasting impression among a plethora of similar games.

To sum things up: You explore 4 different locations, where you fight enemies, unlock pathes and slay a main boss. Then you fight a final boss at the end of the game.
To fill things up, you can also find many secret pathways and hidden loot along the way. Although, at least after unlocking the handul of useful upgrades, these things do little more than satisfy the "completionist compulsion" or give your pixelated outfit a different color - yay..

The locations themselves are well done, within the limitations the game set itself. They are each distinct from one another and home to different inhabitants. However, since you always do the exact same thing in those locations, the variance in style does little to give a sense of true change. 

The soundtrack doesnt help either, which I can only describe as a mix of "it's there" and "boring", and I feel like a lot of potential had been wasted here (I actually ended up playing my own music over the ingame sound and it made things better. Still, my wistful thinking of "Ruiner" remained).

This leaves the fights themselves. After all, the "main course" of the game. And they are well done, even fun, at times - until the controls ruin it. In defence of the game, I have to clarify, that I played the game with keyboard+mouse. The game recommends a controller, but that's just not for me.
There are about 3-4 different enemy types per location (and one that seems to be everywhere) and the fast paced fights never really get to the point, where things start to feel repetitive. The bosses, however, are a let down. They all die extremely quickly, have little if any remarkable moves and no additional phases, but at the same time, can kill you in what feels like a single hit (the game has no real i-frames and damage taken briefly staggers you, which can lead to chain of attacks that quickly depletes your small health pool). 

A story is basically non-existant. There are some super short, non-voiced, cryptic and honestly uninteresting cutscenes and that's all there is to it.

Ultimately, I can barely recommend the game. 
It is obtainable for a very low price (I paid 5€) and does what little it does well enough to potentially be a good experience.
At the same time, however, it fails to deliver anything new or unexpected and can not leave a lasting impression. 
If time is a limiting resource for you, you will be better off looking for a different game.

The map is horrible, even maps in roguelikes are better than this. Fighting again and again in same rooms with same enemies that you've defeated 5 times, and I'm talking about this cases where you are forced to fight with enemies on small arena in order to pass. In game you feel like you didn't progress at all, because map doesn't show, environment doesn't show it and you don't know where to go, cause most of parts of areas are forgettable, so you won't remember to check them later.  Also game respawns you in which state you were on checkpoint, so could end up respawning with 1 hp, no heals next to the combat room. And this is frustrating for how much of useless backtracking you need to do in this case. 
Although I was mad and harsh, I'm need to say that combat system is good, enemies' attacks may not be 100% readable, but that's fine. Visuals and audio are outstandable! But issues that I listed won't engage me to play this game further. I might adapt to bad sides of some games and still enjoy them no matter what, but not in this case.
So, how to fix certain issues to make experience a bit better? Idk, but I provide 2 solutions for 2 problems. Devs could make variables that will count if you have fought on this arena and simply don't lock you away and let skip enemies. Game should respawn you with 5 health and with 0 healies no matter what to have consistancy.

122322446.review:
I find these kind of games very boring and I picked up this one because I saw some interesting things written about it.
The gameplay is generic and mostly boring but I found some positives here.
This game's strong points are great atmosphere, great music and sound design in general and beautiful visuals.
This game has more horror elements then most of games that try to achieve that feeling of dread, despair and fighting demons. In this one you are fighting monsters but through out the game you are wondering what is the meaning of all this.
I think you can interpret the story and message of the game in your own way and you wouldn't be wrong, All great games have one thing in common and that is to make the player think. The fear of unknown is bigger then any other and Hyper Light Drifter manages to create that feeling. Great sound design is vital here and this OST is not something you will listen in your free time but neither is Silent Hill 2 s. 
This is a great game that everyone should play, even if you don't like the game play (I don't) you should pick this one up and play it on easy difficulty.
Well worth the full price. Stunning atmospheric game that doesn't hold your hand. Telling a story without words is not easy so it is up to you (your brain/intelligence) to create one.

121971794.review:
I ended up playing this during some of the worst days in 2020, and the bizarre, other-worldly aesthetics were the perfect way to escape during that time. The art and music is my favorite part (awesome soundtrack), but the gameplay is solid too, with fun and challenging boss fights, and secrets that are satisfying to uncover. I actually enjoyed how the map and upgrade systems are a little cryptic, and you have to work a little to understand them. Same with the story, since it's only told in pictures with no dialogue at all.

If playing a SNES-era action-adventure turned up to 11 sounds like your thing, then I'd highly recommend Hyper Light Drifter.

121846445.review:
This was probably the first proper 'souls-like' game I ever played and boy was it a brick wall for me for a long time. It took me a few years to chip my way though this game and get to the final boss, which seems funny now because afterwards I cleared the game again with the new character in a day. It's really a game that goes from tense and mysterious to a relaxing vibe as you master the combat and exploration. It's very good, is what I'm saying

If you're going in as a total rookie like I did, just remember that button mashing is bad and you need to practice just pressing your various buttons the exact number of times you need to do your thing (true of basically all souls-likes). If combat is too tough, try mixing your gun in with melee attacks and you'll see your damage go up a lot. Last, all the secrets I've found so far (and there are a lot) were telegraphed through environmental details so really keep your eyes peeled for little runes on the ground or places where a path through a 'wall' is implied with floor tiles and the like

121756725.review:
[h2]Unexpectedly Overwhelming[/h2]
There's no doubt that this kind of games are not uncommon, nowadays. For the indie landscape, that is. 
But there's [i]something[/i] about Hyper Light Drifter, something which I didn't expect to find... that resonated within me. 

Maybe it's how everything seems correlated to the developer and his health. I don't know, but I'm sure that this has been an immersive and quite long experience, at least for me. 

[h3]Let It Speak[/h3]
One of the things which I did like was the actual narrative structure. You start off with a brief tutorial which teaches you how to play, and then you're put into this decadent, mysterious world filled with a somewhat melancholic feel. 

If you've ever played [b]Dropsy[/b] (if you didn't, I would highly recommend you doing so!), you may be familiar with how dialogue is presented here. Characters don't actually talk, but rather make a bunch of noises. The actual context is shown to the player through the use of flashback images, which sum up what the NPC is talking about. 

Needless to say, it [b]works[/b]. You're never disconnected from your surroundings, and for me it's really important. Other than that, the stories told by the few characters you'll encounter will be brief and concise, with not much to interpret. 
I'm not saying this should be the structure of every videogame ever, but sometimes letting the game speak for itself is the best way to catch the player's interest. 

[h3]Surroundings (And Your Ears)[/h3]
In fact, I've been invested in the places I was exploring. Much like [b]Hollow Knight[/b], I've spent quite some time running around finding hidden items or simply admiring what the environment had to offer. That and HLD's eerie soundtrack, made by Disasterpeace. 

Even when fighting, your ears will constantly hear the relaxing yet heavily melancholic music of that given level, and that'll create an interesting contrast which will inevitably stick around in your head. The composition is clearly excellent, and there hasn't been a moment where I didn't like what I was listening to.

As for surroundings, environments are rich and full of personality. The overall tone is decadent and arid. It's almost like there's something constantly fading away. You'll clearly remember the various biomes you'll stop by. On the other hand, the game kinda encourages you to walk around and search for secrets, so eventually you'll get to know each room pretty well.

Artistically, I'd say that the only thing which I didn't really find that interesting was the enemies' design. Although some are easily recognizable, others feel somewhat flat compared to the global art direction. Not that it's negative in any way, it's just that I would've liked something with a bit more personality. Bosses are well made, though.

[h3]Synchronized[/h3]
I'd say that gameplay wise it's a solid game. You can slash your enemies with your sword and dash to dodge the enemy attacks. You can also fire with your weapon using RT. During your journey, you'll come across some items which will let you upgrade your skillset. With certain upgrades, you'll be able to do some combos which will consume your stamina. 

You'll eventually arrive at a point where your set of skills will be varied, but you'll still have to use your timing right in order to fight well. I thought that the game's commands were clunky at first, but soon realized that in order to do even basic combos, you'd need to time your button presses accordingly. 

That's interesting, since it creates an actual learning curve even with the simplest combos, but doesn't even lose all that accessibility since the game is not the hardest out there, and it'll mostly be you and ordinary enemies. There are some bosses, sure, but even they are not the most challenging ones. If you complete your first game, though, you'll be able to experience New Game+ with some added difficulty.

So there's a lot to praise here and there. Mastering the gameplay's flow feels really rewarding, and if that's what the developers had in my mind, they totally nailed it. With that said, good luck with the dashing challenge.

[h3]Tidbits[/h3]
Last but honorable mention, additional challenges and hidden areas. If you're a curious player and scavenge around to find items as me, then you'll be accurately rewarded. So, if you're a completionist, you'll be pleased to know that there's some work to do here. If you're not, but still curious, you'll find yourself in some interesting situations.

[h2]Panacea[/h2]
With this song now stuck in my mind, I'd say that going blindly into Hyper Light Drifter was an incredibly good thing. The whole exclusives deal with the EGS kinda made me a little sad, but Solar Ash and Hyper Light Breaker are eventually coming to Steam, so we'll see.

With that said, I would recommend this game even at full price!

121755263.review:
Hyper Light Drifter is extremely "built-to-purpose." It knows what it wants to be, and executes on that nearly flawlessly. It isn't particularly long, especially if you go straight for the ending and ignore the wide array of goodies and bonuses hidden away, but the gameplay is more than good enough to give you your money's worth.

If you are a fan of 2D adventure games, especially ones with a good deal of secrets to find, you can't go wrong with this game.

121730636.review:
Una maravilla a la vieja escuela. Hyper Light Drifter tiene todo aun mostrándose tan sencillo.
Un juego de accion con bases de Hack´n Slash, con tintes de rol y exploración que aun con poco por aprender, te permitirá hacer mucho y cautivarte con su jugabilidad.

[h1]•HISTORIA[/h1]
 Este título es muy vago a la hora de contar su historia, principalmente porque los diálogos son inexistentes y todo se basa en la interpretación del jugador basado en imágenes que reemplazan diálogos, acciones del personaje en momentos no jugables y cortos clips de video, los cuales aumentan aún más la calidad de este juego.
 Encarnamos a "Drifter", que vendría a ser "Vagabundo", personaje que es poseedor de conocimientos y habilidades del viejo mundo. Dichos conocimientos le son ajenos completamente a los seres del nuevo mundo y por ello, sus vidas ya son parte de él.
 Drifter sufre de una misteriosa enfermedad (aparentemente cardiaca, inspirada en los problemas de salud de su desarrollador y creador) contra la cual lucha día a día, aparentemente buscando una cura [spoiler]sin embargo, tras terminar el juego, esa idea puede volverse confusa y puede que sea errónea[/spoiler]. Para ello debe de recurrir y enfrentarse a los vestigios del viejo mundo y también a las amenazas del nuevo mundo. Una suerte de guía espiritual o alucinación (o no tengo idea que) en forma de coyote o perro, aparentemente guía a nuestro personaje, mientras que por otro lado, visiones de muerte o de su misma enfermedad le atormentan y debilitan mientras más se acerca a su destino. Sin embargo eso no lo detiene, y aun sufriendo, sigue adelante.
 En el camino se topara con otros seres, probablemente con las mismas habilidades y conocimientos que él posee, ya que se destacan en combate y hasta en apariencia al igual que Drifter. Aparentemente, esos pares también sufren de la misma enfermedad y se encaminan en su duro camino en busca de una cura.
 Poco más se puede decir de la historia ya que es muy libre a interpretación. Lo que he narrado aquí es parte lore oficial y parte interpretación, pero esto solo hace que el juego sea mejor aún, puesto que las teorías y versiones que la historia pueda contar podrían ser muchas.

[h1]•GRAFICOS, FISICAS Y SONIDO[/h1]
 El juego tiene una estética 2-D al estilo de las viejas consolas de 8 o 16 bits, usando notorios pixeles para dar forma a todo. Esto, al principio, puede ser confuso, ya que es difícil saber distinguir formas, elevaciones o caídas y hasta proyectiles. Sin embargo, apenas unos minutos de juego y ya sabremos entender todo y, no solo eso, sino que podremos apreciar lo hermoso de este estilo.
 Los colores son suaves, color pastel y muy definidos, así como los brillos y destellos, los cuales están muy bien contrastados y hasta ayudan a guiarse. Cada movimiento del personaje es muy bueno, así como los de cada enemigo. Que los movimientos estén tan definidos ayuda a predecir patrones y suma mucho al agrado visual. Los entornos son dignos de apreciarse y, habrá muchos lugares tan detallados y llamativos que, gracias también a su estética, se vuelven aún más cautivadores. No existe pixel al azar, todo aquí está hecho para agradar y lo logra.
 Las físicas son perfectas, aunque para los disparos, la perspectiva podrá eclipsarlos, pero eso es intencional creo y hasta resulta mucho mejor. Las hitbox están muy bien hechas y se respetan las distancias según el golpe.
 En cuanto a lo sonoro, cuenta con música la cual es monofónica, cambiando según la zona, pero siempre será muy suave, ambiental, y por sobre todo, agradable, dulce y al mismo tiempo sombría, con aires de tristeza. Es muy difícil reunir tantos sentimientos en unas melodías monofónicas, pero el juego lo logra y con ello transmite ese halo de misterio, paz y dolor que transita el personaje en cada etapa. Los sonidos, por otro lado son precisos y muy originales. Cada ataque, movimiento e interacción cuenta con su propio y distintivo sonido. Incluso el ambiente cuenta con sonidos que, además de dar ambientación (valga la redundancia), también ayudan a la exploración, guiándonos hacia lugares que, de no ser por el sonido, no encontraríamos a primeras.
 En resumen, lo audiovisual, pese a lo pudelado y monofónico, abunda de hermosura y precisión para el título en cuestión. Excelente.

[h1]•MECANICAS Y JUGABILIDAD[/h1]
 El juego mezcla las mecánicas de un HnS, permitiéndonos el cuerpo a cuerpo y el esquive junto a los disparos, así como el rol, ya que podremos hallar puntos de mejora a lo largo del mapa que podremos después gastar en más habilidades de espada, esquive y hasta mejorar la capacidad de curas, así como cambiar y mejorar nuestro arma de fuego. Al mismo tiempo, la exploración es necesaria para hallar dichos puntos y, en esto hay que sacarse el sombrero, puesto que existen muchos caminos ocultos que tomar y rincones difíciles de hallar, pero hacerlo, es muy bien premiado. Sin embargo, algo que no termino de convencerme es el mapa. Es muy difícil de interpretar bien, sirviendo como guía básica pero sin ninguna precisión. Esto es intencional, lo sé, pero el mundo es muy laberintico, grande y, gracias a su estética, muy difícil de leer de por sí. Por eso creo que dar vaga información en el mapa también es algo innecesario. Basta con decir que me tomo la mitad de la campaña leerlo como se debe (puede que sea solo yo, pero no creo).
 La jugabilidad es muy simple,  moviéndonos al clásico  "W;A;S;D", el esquive (dash) que al mismo tiempo es el salto "Espacio" y ambos clics, siendo uno el ataque a espada y el otro a distancia. Parece muy fácil, pero todo dependerá de nuestras habilidades y armas, así como los reflejos y lectura de patrones de los enemigos y el entorno, que puede ser muy reducido, con vacíos o hasta con trampas. La combinación de los movimientos es indispensable para un buen combate. Otro detalle es que el cursor estará en pantalla y será el punto hacia donde irán nuestros ataques (como nuestro punto objetivo y mira), por lo que deberemos también prestarle atención en combate.
 Cada enemigo cuenta con un moveset propio y variado en relación a qué clase de enemigo es (un enemigo inicial apenas y tendrá uno o dos movimientos), y cada vez aparecerán enemigos más duros, en mayor cantidad y combinados, lo cual aumentara progresiva pero notoriamente la dificultad, lo cual es genial.
 El juego, por sus básicos controles no requiere de extrema habilidad y hasta permite dejarlo a medias y regresar mucho tiempo después sin necesidad de reiniciar, ya que en un minuto le agarras la mano de nuevo. Es el juego perfecto para todo jugador, tanto casual como dedicado, y se disfruta sea cual sea el caso. Lamentablemente es algo corto, y se hará más breve aun si eres bueno en estos juegos de agilidad y reflejos ya que casi no morirás.

 En resumen, el juego es una joya y merece cada centavo de su valor. Sé que cuenta con un Coop para jugar con un amigo, pero aún no lo he probado y no puedo opinar de esto. Por otro lado tiene un extra al terminar la campaña que te permite ir contra todos los bosses a elección para revivir los trepidantes y rápidos combates.

121721366.review:
Hyper Light Drifter is a brilliant game with strong themes that I'm too dumb to understand because there's no dialogue.

Fun game though.  I would recommend getting it when it's on sale, but honestly, it's probably worth full price.

The mechanics are amazing, from the dash, to the weapons you unlock later on in the game, everything just feels very snappy and responsive.  Not too sensitive though.  You won't go flying off the edge of a platform because you accidentally moved the mouse wrong.  The game recommends that you use an XBox controller, but I honestly found the keyboard controls to be more comfortable.  They do take some getting used to, but once you do, they feel incredible.

I won't go too much into spoilers, but I can tell that this is an allegory for something, and though I think I know for what, I'm just way too much of a moron to fully grasp everything because there's no dialogue.

All in all, 8/10, absolutely recommended.

121686527.review:
Hyper Light Drifter is an extremely charming indie game 
The bosses are so different from each other, I love the sense of variety and its a real fresh breathe of air. Finding and exploring secrets are extremely rewarding and satisfying and left me wanting to go back to already finished areas to find fun little side areas. Sometimes there are big chunks of really cool areas you can just completely miss. It's one of the few areas where I can say the side content is as good and fufilling as the main content. The enviornment is beautiful the way it does enviornmental storytelling makes the game all the more charming and there are certain points in the game where you will just stop and admire how pretty it is. The customization is very flexible for guns. I wish the melee weapon had a bit more variety because I loved trying different guns so much but it's more of a nitpick. Most areas I loved except for one of the later areas on the north side of the map. It was difficult in a unfair and unfun way but this was very infrequent. This is overall an extremely charming retro game and I reccomend it to any one who can handle a challenge

121597415.review:
Exquisite classic indie title. Beautiful pixel art, atmospheric soundtrack, mysterious story. But most importantly, the combat design is the best of any game I've played. The game is built around teaching you the mechanics, making you into a master of it's combat. Every ability requires you to learn it, like a real-life skill, requiring timing, precision and strategy. Levels are designed to take advantage of that, and keep you on your toes so you are constantly switching fluidly through your weapons and abilities based on the environment and foes you're up against.

I completed the base game in about 10 hours. I have yet to try the extra content, but I am very interested in the boss rush mode, and I'm sure NG+ is where the combat shines even brighter.

121580328.review:
Hyper Light Drifter is a bit of a cult classic. I've known about this game for a long while. I had never played it, but always heard it was a good game. I do dare say it met my expectations. The game is fun and definitely interesting to say the least. I can see how newer games may have drawn inspiration from Hyper Light Drifter. The environment and story have a certain mystique, and being able to master combat is quite satisfying (though quite hard sometimes). The soundtrack is also really good as well, and really adds to the atmosphere. I was a big fan of the game Fez and its soundtrack, so this kinda brought me back.

My only gripe is with the story - I get that the devs wanted to keep it mysterious and vague, perhaps for the community to connect the dots in different ways (with for example the in-game language being deciphered). But perhaps they overdid it a bit. I could appreciate it, but maybe it would have been better to keep at least the main reason why you're doing what you're clear for everyone, but keep all the extra stuff hidden the way they wanted it. That way you don't ostracize people that don't feel like having to google the story because it was too vague for them, and they had no idea why the protaganist was had to jump through all these hoops in the first place. At the same time you can keep the hardcore fanbase entertained with a deeper knowledge of the in-game world and its happenings.

120714002.review:
TLDR: I loved the art and sound of this game, clearly a ton of work and care went into it. However, I do not like the controls or upgrade mechanics. I played on the standard difficulty using an Xbox One controller. I am not particularly good at hard games anymore so this review is through that perspective. These are my thoughts alone on the game and your mileage may vary.

Pros:
You will die to dumb things, but it is okay because the death system is extremely forgiving. You do not lose anything you had before entering a room, which is a good thought considering how fragile you are. Traversing the world hits that nice balance of making you feel strong but vulnerable. 
Health is abundant in the world but you have to try and earn extra. The forgiving death system feeds into this.
It's very beautiful. Clearly a lot of work went into making this game and the dev team should be very proud of the final product.

Slight complaints/Constructive criticisms:
The map is cool, but very rough around the edges. A simple legend would have helped to let me know what was checked off and what was not in the early game. The character marker could also better reflect your position in the room.
Story is unclear at best if playing casually without the intent of hitting every collectible. Some games like JOURNEY thrive with minimal narrative, but this did not feel like one of them. For comparison, I think Hollow Knight suffers from the same problem. I like a story to be explained somehow, and this game's plot feels like it was not explained to me. In comparison, JOURNEY felt like its background was conveyed just enough.

Cons:
The game often feels like BS. The following points are why.
You will die to dumb things because the controls are slow to respond and you are fragile.
You can dash multiple times, but any dash beyond the first requires a specific timing which is slower than the game operates at. This can be waved away with “git gud”, but I thought it felt wrong with the game’s action pace.
Bosses can hitstun you and continue to pump damage. With so little health and slow healing, this feels cheap at best.
The gun I was using has an audible sound to let you know when you can fire again, however, this sound is often drowned out (especially during boss fights) and I was left guessing for the timing.
Healing is slow but also limited. This is great until some boss fights when I was unable to heal before the next attack. This is another “git gud” situation where I feel like the pace of healing does not match the pace of the action. With healing being SO limited, I’d like it to be automatic or nearly so.
There are a few upgrades which help tremendously and many which do not feel like they matter. A game which has an intended way to play is not inherently a bad thing, but many of the upgrade options are so feeble compared to the good ones. Once I had the best ones, I did not feel like I was upgraded at all when I bought the rest.
Being able to accidentally dash off the edge of a stage is annoying and makes me feel like I'm playing a silly version of Soul Caliber where I jump off the stage instead of rolling around the enemy.

A masterclass in visual storytelling and level design, Hyper Light Drifter makes you feel like a badass AND a genius. 
The level design is immaculate; the visual language of the game makes finding your way around and discovering secrets immensely satisfying, without being frustrating or obtuse. The combat took a minute to click, but once it did I was in love with how smooth, balanced, and visceral it felt. 120416086.review:
Hyper Light Drifter is a very artsy top-down hack & slash game with some metroidvania elements, somewhat inspired by 2D Zelda and Dark Souls, and set in a post-apocalyptic world with some cyberpunk elements. But make no mistake, the main appeal is the trippy visuals and the oppressive ambient soundtrack, the combat can be fun, but the game is not much of a challenge if you play a lot of action games.

The story is extremely vague, the protagonist is a katana wielding masked swordsman roaming the world looking for a cure for his sickness, but beyond that it is all up to interpretation, as the game is entirely wordless, with no dialog or any other text, not unlike games like [url=store.steampowered.com/app/638230]Journey[/url] or [url=store.steampowered.com/app/304430]INSIDE[/url]. It all essentially boils down to a giant metaphor for a heart condition because the lead developer is sick in real life.

The combat is your average Souls inspired "slash twice then dodge". The rhythm is pretty unique though, your walking speed is quite slow but you move very fast when dashing and the first dash upgrade allows you to chain dashes indefinitely. The drifter can also deflect projectiles with his blade, as well as wield a variety of guns, from a basic pistol to a shotgun and various energy weapons. Ammo is in short supply but you restore it by slashing at the enemies giving the formula a certain ebb and flow.

Personally, I had a lot of fun hunting for secrets, because the game has tons and many of them are very sneaky and require thinking outside the box. Things are often obscured by the game's top down perspective and you basically try to break out of bounds to get them. You can find currency for upgrades, keys for optional areas and even alternate outfits that provide a variety of passive buffs.

The game is quite short, with only 4 main areas and 8 bosses. A completionist playthrough will take about 15 hours, and if you don't care about secrets, it will be around half that time. Check out [url=store.steampowered.com/app/894020/]Death's Door[/url] if you want a similar game but a bit more modern and less artsy.

120294723.review:
Pushed through 3/4 of the zones but was never gripped by the game. 

The no text pictures only way of storytelling was an interesting idea to [strike]save money on paying a writer[/strike] have a unique narrative experience, but it never hooked me in. 

The combat starts pretty slow but by midgame its pretty fun. Having to time your dashes in order to take advantage of chaining them rather than just spamming the button is really cool. The different guns are neat. Too bad there's a very small amount of bosses, they're all too easy, and regular enemies are unfulfilling. I don't need it to be bonecrushingly difficult, just enough to keep my brain engaged and have a satisfying victory. I never once died in combat, only from the 1 shot traps. That's ok though, because that's not what you'll be doing in Hyper Light Drifter.

The gameplay loop, and 90% of the experience, is painstakingly checking every single ledge, wall, breakable, open air, pretty much every square inch of the environment for stuff. Many of the items needed for progression are in hidden areas. Upgrade materials are in hidden areas. Keys for special rooms are in hidden areas. You'll comb an area for hidden areas, go down a rabbit hole, fight a room of enemies, comb the room, find nothing, backtrack to the other area you didn't search yet, and do that until a zone is clear. Then you still missed a bunch of stuff. So you'll do it again. 

Exploration would be more fulfilling if there was some sort of puzzle element rather than the tedium of reverse engineering the art designer's fever dream. If it were just upgrade materials and optional items behind this sort of exploration than it wouldn't be so bad, but it's needed to actually progress the game.

120252401.review:
Hyper Light Drifter is all about exploration and secrets with a splash of hack and slash. There is something to find at every corner of the beautiful pixelated world and getting lost is the correct path.

This game doesn't tell, only shows. There won't be any dialogue but illustrations of the lore and your story explained in the background. There's not even a mission popping out telling you what to do, only a diagram. This forces the player to take the initiative and explore at their own will, some games want you to keep going right or up, here however they're all the correct way to go unless you're not ready yet.

HLD rewards a great amount of exploration, if you don't find any secret in a dungeon then you probably missed a dozen of secret rooms. Noticing that weird square tile on the ground should be a second nature to you because a lot of the main quest is hidden behind them, including upgrades or optional keys. Some progression pieces are put right before your eyes while some are in the more obscure part of the map, however you're not required to get every piece of this main quest which allows you to progress however and whenever you like.

The combat is unforgiving at first, there are barely invincibility frames when you dodge or getting attacked and you're very prone to danger if you get surrounded by multiple enemies (which happens a lot). However you can continue right before a battle sequence start if you died, and you're free to find another path and upgrades until you're ready to tackle this harder part of the game. But When you do get used to the combat it can be very satisfying to pull off, juggling between your sword and guns while chain dashing in rhythm to dodge incoming attacks and projectiles. Although don’t worry if you’re here only to enjoy the world as there is an easy difficulty to pick.

The game recommends you to play with a controller, however what they should've told you is that the game MUST be played using a controller. Keyboard and Mouse is simply not optimized for the combat, it is clunky and just gives you a bad experience overall. Most of the negative reviews are complaints about the controls, the developers should've paid more attention to it considering this is a PC release in a PC store and players should not be expected to own a controller. So be wary if you're trying to play with KBM, it's possible but may hinder your adventure. I’ve actually played it using KBM several years ago but had to put it down due to frustration.

The hand-crafted world and soundtrack is beautiful, you can't help but to keep taking screenshots and hang around to submerge yourself in the 16-bit atmosphere. However you need to bear with the difficult combat and cryptic nature of the game. If you're a fan of the classic top down adventures like Zelda then this is a must play.

120030955.review:
Hyper Light Drifter is exactly what an action RPG or action adventure game should aspire to be, but nothing more. It follows a very simple but tight gameplay loop where you repeatedly explore an area, which is to say fight groups of enemies and discover secrets while progressing on the map, and then fight a boss and get an upgrade. While there are other action RPGs in the same vein which distinguish themselves in some manner, Hyper Light Drifter only makes simple, straightforward design choices which prove to be correct. It takes Link to the Past as its model, and as a result naturally follows the Miyamoto school of design. Overall, I'd recommend it to somebody who already likes these sorts of games and knows it.

I was bothered by the map, which was difficult to read and not very helpful, and by the health upgrades, which are basically worthless (they give you extra storage for health replenishment items, which sounds great in theory but in practice I never needed to use more than 3 health replenishment items at a time). Neither of these things was sufficient to call it a bad game. I've heard complaints about the difficulty, but on normal I hardly had any trouble at all so I wouldn't call it a difficult game personally.

120016288.review:
TL;DR: I would only recommend this game if you are running out of things to play in these genres. If you already have other widely praised fast-paced 2D games, metroidvanias and hack & slash games in your "to play" list, then skip this game for now. Or buy it on sale and play it later. The game has a fun world to explore but the map is quite shit. Your combat abilities are nice but enemies are boring and ganky. Atmosphere is superb

Long ass review ahead.

Hyper Light Drifter is a metroidvania at its core, but it has a different approach for its level design than more traditional metroidvania games like Hollow Knight or Rabi-Ribi. Rather than having a huge interconnected world, it has 4 main regions. These regions have lots of different shortcuts, alternative paths and branching roads (much like how Dark Souls areas are designed), but they don't connect to each other. Instead, there is a hub in the middle of the map, connecting all 4 areas. Basically, don't go into this game expecting Hollow Knight. While technically a metroidvania, it differs a lot from the mold. Not to imply that that is a bad thing. I enjoyed exploring the world, even if it was quite small.

The main problem with the game's world in my opinion isn't actually about level design, it is about the map. I get that this was an aesthetic choice, but your map really sucks at being a map. It only shows what room you are in and not where you are in it. Considering how big some rooms in the game are, finding out where you are exactly can be a chore. It is hard to deduce where you should go or how you can get to a certain place. The map already shows every room when you get it so you can't check whether or not you have been to a place before either. I just really didn't like the map, and it is the main reason I won't bother 100%ing the game. I can't visualize the game's map in my head without getting a headache. There are too many shortcuts and branches for that, not to mention different parts of the map can only be accessed through underground areas (and the map for those areas sucks as well). I think a map like Rabi-Ribi's would have been leagues better than the current one. Also they should have added more than 1 warp for each region imo. 2 or 3 would be a lot better. Backtracking is a huge issue in the game.

The combat is pretty good, but it has some flaws. The major one is enemy design and placement. The game would have benefited from more variety in enemy types, as there are only 20 enemies in the game. Some of them have very similar functions too, and some are practically reskins. Enemy placement is a mess and relies a lot on swarming you. You'll often be forced into a tiny room with a dozen or so Dirks trying to gank you at once. Or 20 Vultures harassing you. Or 10 toads endlessly throwing crap at you from far away. It seems like when the devs realized their enemies are dull and too easy to fight, they decided to fix that; not by making more complex enemies with better AI, but rather by turning every third room into a gank fest.

Bosses are meh. They just didn't click for me. All of the bosses in the game are pretty mundane and none of them really feels like a boss, they are more like glorified minibosses. None are very memorable. That isn't to say they were all very easy, I died a few times to almost all of them, partly because I almost always managed to enter with low heals, mostly because I suck. 

Looking at the players moveset, you have some fun tools. Your default attack with the sword is always reliable and feels great to use. Your guns are nicely balanced, you can't just shoot everything from a safe distance. You have to get up and personal and hit people with your sword to get more ammo. All of your sidegrades are fun too. The charge attack is extremely satisfying to use but getting interrupted can be a bit frustrating. But that (and the severe mobility penalty) is the tradeoff for a whopping 5 damage with a huge arc that can one shot most enemies. Your dash attacks are a lot more situational but make you feel like the coolest fuck out there when you pull them off. And your grenade is a nice tool to deal with big groups or far away ranged enemies. My only major gripe is with the deflect ability. I feel like it should already be a part of your core moveset and deflecting things can be a bit wonky.

Movement... is weird. And by movement I mean dashing. The weird delay you get after a normal dash feels... off? It doesn't feel like a set cooldown like you have in most games. The time between dashes almost feels random. Like the game isn't reading my input correctly sometimes. I don't know how to explain it, maybe I'm doing something wrong, but it caused a lot of problems in combat. Chain dashing is the coolest shit ever when you pull it off. Zooming across the map just feels good, but getting cockblocked by ledges and obstacles sucks ass. For some reason, your character does this slide once you stop chain dashing, which causes you to fall to your doom 9/10 times. Your character also can't dash through breakable objects and gets completely wrecked if you chain dash next to an object and your collision hitbox collides with a single pixel of said object. Just why. Also fuck the 800 dash challenge, I stopped trying after 769.

Artistically I have no complaints. The game looks wonderful, what is there to say? Even though the themes of sci-fi/cyperpunk stuff and old temples/ruins aren't really my thing, they were still great to look at. I love me some pixel art. The OST, while nothing amazing or above and beyond like the art, was pretty nice too. The story, I didn't really understand, and that is more on me than the game. I already struggle getting a grasp of Souls-like story telling, and in a game that didn't even have item descriptions, I was quite lost despite all the cutscenes.

While thinking about this game, though, here is what I realized. Other than gorgeous pixel art and the games unique atmosphere, this game doesn't really have a strong suit, especially when it comes to gameplay. 

Do you want to play a metroidvania with breathtaking exploration? Hollow Knight and Rabi-Ribi are some of the best metroidvanias when it comes to huge interconnected worlds and their non-linear world design gives extreme freedom to the player. If you want something more linear, the Ori games are a great pick and Souls games need no explanation. 

Is hacking and slashing everything like butter your thing? Katana Zero is far more fluid and faster paced with great enemy placement. If Katana Zero is too simple and/or you want isometric gameplay, Hades is a great game with far more variety in both enemy types and weapon options. 

Are you really into the bullet hell aspect of the game? Rabi-Ribi comes to mind again. If you want isometric gameplay with scattered enemy placement, go for Enter the Gungeon, Binding of Isaac, most roguelikes/lites really. If you aren't really into roguelikes/lites, you can always pick up an actual bullet hell game. The newest Touhou game and some old classics like Ikagura can be bought on Steam.

Hyper Light Drifter is one of those games you play after you finished pretty much every revered title in the genre you like.

120014646.review:
SPOILER FREE

Ok so just after beating this game I have two big things to talk about, but just keep in mind I still haven't touched NG+ or a lot of secret stuff or anything like that. 

THE VIBES

The entire soundtrack and artstyle for this game is amazing. When I first looked at the game and the beginning cutscene was playing, the first thing I said in a discord call with a friend of mine was that I already knew that I was going to love the game unless the actual gameplay was really terrible. The soundtrack and visuals stay consistently great throughout the game, and the storytelling through images really adds to the experience. 10/10

THE GAMEPLAY

Alright, so the gameplay is where things get a little more rough for me. While I enjoyed the combat at its basics, there were a few problems I had with it, although they were by no means dealbreakers, and I still overall enjoyed the combat. My biggest gripe with the combat comes whenever you take damage. Taking damage knocks your character back and to the ground, but does not give you I-frames to get up and react, which leads to many cases of an enemy, boss, or environmental hazard throwing you into something and cause you to essentially get partially stunlocked. Maybe I'm bad, but this kept happening during a few of the bosses. A much smaller gripe I had was from a lack of auto aim on the gun. This is mainly a skill issue, but I wish there was a soft auto aim because it's difficult to aim with precision while dodging attacks from bosses and such. This leads to many shots fired missing by an inch, which soft auto aim would fix, although admittedly this became less of an issue as the game went on. Overall though, the cycle of combat using a sword and a gun with dashes is very satisfying, so I can't dock the combat too hard. 7/10

TLDR / OVERALL

I personally value the experience with a game much more than the core gameplay, as long as that gameplay is at least okay, which Hyper Light Drifter surpasses. Because the atmosphere of the game is so perfect and the gameplay is pretty satisfying, I'm gonna have to give Hyper Light Drifter a 9/10.

119693068.review:
This game could've been so good, the story is interesting, the art style and cutscenes are beautiful, the music is amazing, but the controls on keyboard and mouse are just so awful and it makes gameplay so much more annoying and unfun. Like, the game definitely has its moments, but there are many points that are just so frustrating because your character does things that feel like they are straight up out of your control. If you choose to set it so that you dash in the direction you are facing using WASD, you miss out on a LOT of the finer movement when using the infinite dash upgrade or when platforming due to the 2d nature of the game, but you can dodge and do combat better. HOWEVER, if you choose to have it so that you dash in the direction of your mouse cursor, you get way more accurate movement BUT, because placement of your mouse cursor is also the direction that your character swings their sword, it happens to make you have much less control during combat. This tradeoff with the two dash control styles between movement and combat just makes the game so much more draining and unfun and it makes me sad because I really thought I would love this game. If the mechanics of hyper light drifter were slightly tweaked in a way that made the movement/combat more intuitive on mouse and keyboard this would most likely be one of my favorite games of all time. However, this game has been out for years and that is not going to happen; the story, while interesting, (despite how vague it is) the art, while beautiful, the music, while great, are altogether not nearly enough to justify the gameplay being as unintuitive as it is at times given that it's the main reason I bought the game thinking that it would be extremely satisfying. This game is like on the very edge between casual and not casual and it's really not a good balance. It isn't so much hard as it is annoying, the combat and movement can be picked up and have the basics learnt pretty easily but you have to master them to enjoy them. Many times the only reason you take damage or die is because you do not have complete comfortable control over your character and you end up just brute forcing your way through it and playing carefully,(which is stupid because the game is based on fast paced movement) so it feels like you're just cheesing the entire time. This would be justified if the game was longer or had more replay value so you got better the more times you played but given that that you can discover most things in one playthrough if you just spend time looking for them, this is not a good approach for it as there's really no reason to play after you beat it. If the controls were at least hard to pickup and easy to master it would probably make learning them satisfying but in the state they are, it really isn't and given that the combat and movement are two of the most important pieces of the game and pretty much the main reason I myself bought it, the game is spoiled due to said controls as they are pretty much the only thing that makes the game 'difficult' imo, the bosses and enemies are otherwise fair if you fix the controls.

Oh yeah also, another annoying thing about the combat, there are two dashing attacks in the game that you can buy, and they are both some of the best upgrades in the game, one requires you to press attack and then dash, dealing an AOE attack, and the other requires you to dash and then attack, knocking targets back in the direction you hit them and dealing extra damage to them if they bounce of objects or other enemies. This would be fine if the timing on these attacks wasn't so bad and made it so half of the time trying to use either ability in combat would make your character do whichever of the two attacks they felt like, causing you to get punished as a result.

119553312.review:
A world ridden by death yet so beautiful. It's grim and vague, yet inspires wonder and curiosity.

There's a lot to love in this game; if it isn't absolutely obvious, the art direction, animation, and music (more Disasterpeace!) are all top notch. 

Combat feels fantastic as enemies have good wind-up animations with many upgrades allowing you to more easily manipulate arenas and deal damage quickly. The greatest part? There's enough high-end technique (even with the starting kit) that you can really master it. There's the normal game, a new game+, a boss rush mode (with three difficulties), and a horde mode in the normal game, which means there's a lot to challenge yourself with— I recently completed a no-death run, which was actually very fun because the game is very nonlinear— there's four zones, with three of them being completely open to begin with.

This is a game for explorers. You are [b]heavily encouraged[/b] to explore every nook and cranny to get upgrades. This is fantastic because the game hints quite clearly where secrets are by a symbol that once you see once, you'll never unsee it. The healing system is forgiving, with three full heals (which can be upgraded to five) and with the amount of exploring to do, you'll find an abundance of resources to keep you topped up.

There's no text in game (other than the tutorial and a language to translate/google), and the game heavily relies on cryptic storytelling— the world and its few characters that talk in pictures are all there are to go off of, which means there's a lot to interpret. With just how beautiful the world is and how you're asked to fill in the gaps (or ignore entirely), there's a story to make your own with enough retrospection. I really enjoyed Harrison Consoli's "The Beautiful Metaphor of Hyper Light Drifter," a near hour-long interpretation of the game and its themes, which I highly recommend after you've beaten the game and digested it.

For its one downside, its cryptic nature can [i]really[/i] hinder a player who doesn't know some of its strange quirks, for example:

Gear can be unlocked in many ways, with the cloak, weapon, and robot all being separate— and each set can provide different buffs. So it's possible to have three bonuses from three different sets by equipping one of each, which is never told to the player. You'll have to google the benefits of each as well, as the game won't tell you.

A fantastic game in all of its parts, while it can be difficult, the game really gives you many avenues to explore to gear up if you're ever stuck. Worth recommending as a piece of art alone.

119394751.review:
This is an engaging game for what it is--a modern homage and reawakening of older-school games like the original Legend of Zelda or Link to the Past, with a serviceable combat system and entertaining fights. Compact and tightly paced, there's an even spread in the sense of exploration and combat; I particularly like how all upgrades are up to you to get and prioritize, making the gameplay system catered to your interests (even if a few upgrades stand out much more than others). 

The real standouts are the graphical direction, visual storytelling and OST, however; especially the OST, which perfectly sets the game every step of the way of this ominous, dead world and mysterious main character. There's no words either; only illustrations and environments, which prod at your imagination and let you come up with whatever you think the game is about (I think it's about a post-nuclear apocalypse, personally). 

It's got some flaws, however; the combat system is missing some juice to really make it engaging, some of the content feels a bit repetitive, and the game doesn't have as much underneath the surface as it presents. Still, it's an enjoyable game that doesn't overstay its welcome, and still has some good content to chew through if you want to 100% it. I personally recommend the experience, but if you're someone who needs their money spent to equate to a particular number of hours, you'll probably want to wait for a sale.

I pulled away from this game a few years back when it was still going through various upgrades and trying to find its footing. Couldn't really get into the swing of thing when everything was in flux. Came back to it recently and once I got into the swing of things on Newcomer mode, I started to enjoy it. 

Admittedly, I didn't 100% this and have no intention to. I mostly wanted to experience the story, worldbuilding, and music. I'm not really here for the whole chain-dash challenge and 8 module door kind of thing. Not really how I play games. That said, I don't think the Newcomer mode does much to make the game approachable, so if this style of play isn't for you, you're still better off going to watch a Let's Play if you find this genre of game frustrating. Another strike against this game is the sound mixing. I had the game on 1:1 SFX/Music ratio since it was *very* loud to me, and this did *nothing* when the flashback scenes happened. I ended up having to take my headphones off and I could *still* hear it blasting.

Overall, a good game if you like top-down action and don't mind a bit of difficulty. Good music, good art, pretty fun core gameplay.

119095905.review:
Pretty damn good!
Exemplary sound design, very pretty graphics, and tight snappy gameplay.
Exploration ias, for me, just okay. You know that old cliche of "treasure chest behind a waterfall"? Well, imagine if every part of the world was a waterfall. Being hyper-vigilant and checking every corner is rewarding but gets tiring pretty quick.
The story was surprisingly well done. It was a bold decision not having a single spoken or written word (beyond tutorial text), but I think it was executed perfectly.
I really appreciated the game's "play as much or as little as you want" approach. I didn't have the desire to unlock everything so just went through the main quest, which took around 5 hours. Much longer and the game would have overstayed its welcome for me, but at 5 hrs it was short and sweet. That said, you could totally dump way more if you want to find every doodad and get every upgrade.
I'd say the $15 asking price is fair already, but if this goes on sale make sure to snag it, even if you don't intend to play it immediately. It's been sitting in my backlog for years and I'm very happy to have finally gotten around to it.

While I absolutely love the art-style, narrative, and atmosphere this cyber hellscape/dreamscape provides, I cannot recommend this game on the basis that the combat and movement feel more sluggish, clunky and frustrating rather than polished, fluid and difficult-to-master.

I've tried to play the game 3 different times, twice on normal and once on easy. Easy was definitely the smoothest experience but making the enemies easier really only helped me highlight problems I had with exploration or challenge solving. I want to say that enemies play by different rules, but I think its more that the rules your character plays by don't feel up to par with what I want or expect from a fast paced game like this. Enemies attacks felt faster than my dodge can handle and it made for an experience that felt like I was being cheated rather than challenged.

For a Dark Souls reference point: The fluidity is similar to Dark Souls 2 where it can feel like you are being cheated a lot of the time by enemies or the environment, as opposed to Dark Souls 1 or 3 where the rules your character and enemies live by are on the same level. 

If you can adjust and be in tune with the mechanics and pacing of your character in relation to the enemies, you might like the combat. I could not get in tune with it, so it is not for me.

118586516.review:
I really want to like this game, I really do. When I first got this game, I played for about 3 hours and stopped. Now, a while later after playing a similar game I absolutely adored, I returned to try it again, and I still struggle to have a good time. The game isn't really bad, but it's just okay. 

It feels unrefined. It heavily lacks visual clarity in what of the decoration does and doesn't have collision, many enemy encounters just toss a ton at you with no real coordination that just serve to swarm you until you get lucky and manage to slice through them before they take out all of your health, attacks can vary in the amount of damage they deal with no visual indication to how much they'll do until you learn from being hit by them, bosses do their little animation every time you challenge them which really adds up over time, and my greatest concern is that nothing ever really tells you what to do or how to do it, nor does it show you. It's very difficult to pick up because nothing is explained and, unlike other games that don't use dialogue, it doesn't really show you how to do things either. It just adds up to a great laundry list of things that collectively bring down the experience until it stops being enjoyable.

This game has its moments where it feels good, of course. Arenas that are more carefully designed and complex usually have really fun encounters, and in terms of visuals, it looks incredible. However, there are so many flaws that add up over time that it's hard for me to enjoy.

If you love the genre, this game probably won't disappoint you too badly so long as you find the option to make dashes go in your movement direction rather than your mouse direction, but if you haven't played a similar game such as Death's Door, this game would serve as a very poor introduction.

Addendum: I finished the game, and I had a good enough time with it, though I spent 75% complaining to my friends in a group chat about questionable design decisions. Most of the game's presentation is great, albeit vague, but the at times awful level design coupled with somewhat clunky controls really brings down the experience. It's not a bad game in any sense, but it could be so, so much better.

118479269.review:
I wanted to like this game due to the art and atmosphere and I did enjoy it in part but overall I would not recommend. "This is way harder that it needs to be" is something I heard about part of the game and honestly it sums up the entire frustrating experience. 

The art style and direction is gorgeous and the worldbuilding intriguing and mysterious. However that's kind of how it stays. The story, whatever it might be, is told entirely through a few images with pretty much no explanation as to how or why anything is like it is. After I beat the game I have literally no idea what happened, what my goal was, if I accomplished it and if things are better or worse for the world now.

The world is small but surprisingly frustrating to explore as the entire games is filled with hidden paths with little to no indication as to where they are. This means that you have to spend the entire time headbutting every wall, bush and tree to see if maybe there is a path there, dashing off cliffs to see if the other side is close enough, or if there is a hidden panel to land on. There are two maps to help you along this way and both are equally useless.  

The gameplay and combat is simple but fun for the most part except where the game decides to be difficult. Then the whole health mechanic is shown to be a poorly thought out afterthought. Healing in the game is hard to find but dying has no penalty and usually spawns you right before you died so what's the point? Not to mention that you can never upgrade your health but enemies do get increased damage to the point where you have to heal after taking a single hit just to be safe but even that is thrown out the window when the game decides to introduce knockdown. Then the game just stunlocks you until you die making the whole health question irrelevant in the first place.

Overall I feel it was a good idea for a game but filled with what I see as design blunders that make it fall far short of what it could have been.

118188371.review:
Hyper Light Drifter is a difficult top-down hack and slash game where you play as the titular Drifter. From the moment I started the game I was already blown away by the incredible artwork and music, which made for this eerie and kind of somber atmosphere.

Throughout the entire game the amazement at the environments stayed present. Every area has its own identity and all of them are a lot of fun to explore. You'll be moving through a number of zones to activate beacons and eventually... do something.

In terms of story this game is a bit unclear. It starts out strong and mysterious, but it never really gets any more clear. There are NPC's in the game that tell you small stories through images (there is no dialogue at all, which is pretty cool) and those stories are pretty intriguing. There are certain secret paths to what seem to be lore tablets of sorts, but there was nothing I was able to gain from that. Maybe I just haven't been interpreting it right, or maybe it's just purposefully very vague, but I think if it was a little more clear it would be even more compelling.

Then finally the gameplay. Hyper Light Drifter can be quite tough. You're going to be dashing around rooms, dodging attacks and bullets while slashing back at hordes of enemies. Throughout you'll gather materials for upgrades so you can get extra skills like a chain-dash or deflection of projectiles. The boss-fights are pretty vicious but not insanely hard. Still, there are some moments where your dash isn't working with you which makes some hits feel a little unfair. It doesn't happen a lot, but when it does it's frustrating. Overall though, the combat is smooth and traversing the world works very well.

I would definitely recommend it to anyone who's interested, as long as you realize it can be difficult and the story is a bit too vague, but outside of that those 8 hours I spent to beat it were all worth it.

Cheers, big ears.

117388466.review:
Hyper Light Drifter is a really, really, well made game. It stands out from the crowd of other pixel-indie titles with it's zero-dialogue story and it's exceptional atmosphere.

[h1] Combat [/h1]

I really enjoyed the combat of this game. It's the first hack and slash I've played where the rhythm of your actions benefit you, which I found very engaging. If you dodge multiple times in sync with the dodge sound effects, you have less time in between your dashes. I really enjoy this mechanic, as it takes away a bunch of the mindlessness that tends to arise from hack and slashes. 

Enemies were also a joy to fight. Only two enemies are repeated between areas, so enemy variety is quite high, and they are all different and fun to fight. My only gripe is that the respawn points for some encounters could be better. Having to open a door every time I die or wait through the 2 second respawn animation gets quite tiresome, especially when I want to get right back into the action. There are also several simple, yet challenging bosses. You can fight 3 right off the bat, but some are certainly more challenging than others. I fought what I considered to be the second hardest boss in the game as my first boss, which made the later bosses kind of disappointing. Spending >15 tries on one boss only to first try the next left me quite irritated. After all, I play these kinds of challenging games for the challenge.

[h1] Exploration and Story [/h1]

The environments of Hyper Light Drifter are extremely well done. There are secrets all over the place, and you always feel really clever when you discover them, as there are very well done indicators of their locations. The post-apocalyptic civilization that you traverse is vivid, each area is distinct and yet all feel part of the same kingdom, and the synth soundtrack just pulls it all together so perfectly. The story, a minimalistic, zero-dialouge one, fits these environments and music near perfectly. Hell, it's worth playing this game just for the environments and story alone. Especially for the pricetag.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

Hyperlight Drifter is an exceptional Hack and Slash with incredible atmosphere that I recommend even to those that don't particularly like difficult games.
