HLD is a gorgeously-designed, lovely-sounding pixel art game with, for me, not quite enough actual guidance on the lore. I can get some fun ideas from what I've seen so far, but it doesn't feel... particularly inclined to assist you, if that helps. 

The gameplay can be fun, the sounds are chunky as hell, but my main frustration is with control latency and deeply unforgiving stun-lock. Dashing doesn't activate for at least 0.2 seconds after you hit space, which is extremely frustrating at times as there are sections where precise dashing is absolutely mandatory and will result in insta-kills otherwise. Attacks will stun-lock you for up to 1.5 seconds, during which time you can be targeted and hit by almost everything and almost everything has a ranged attack that does at least 2 hp each time. In a game that spams enemies at you, that's simply brutal to deal with, and has made me quit with frustration at least twice. 

Enemies are well-designed, with great telegraphing and easy reads. This is vital: as mentioned, enemy spam is a big part of this game and that telegraphing makes it possible to dodge otherwise-undodgeable attacks. That said, there's not a lot of guidance on enemy mechanics at first, so there's a slight learning curve around that. Stick through it, I do think it's worth it. 

Battle arenas will dynamically change around you, which is absolutely fine except occasionally the shifting-walls animation will lock your character in place without locking enemies, leading to unavoidable insta-kills. I'm fairly certain this is a bug, and I'm also fairly certain it will never be fixed. It's not common, but it's frustrating as hell.

SWITCH. TO. MOVE-DASH. By default, you dash to where your cursor is pointing: this is lovely for allowing you to move and dash in separate directions - how often do you actually do that? Not often, as it turns out - and for allowing precise dashing... but that's it. For sections where precise dashing is needed (which are several, even in early game), switch to mouse-dash... but combat flow is severely disrupted without move-dash. Turning around to slash with your weapon while running the opposite direction, hitting dash to dodge the enemy's projectile and... dashing right INTO that projectile?! Deeply frustrating. Move-dash is in settings and is absolutely necessary to avoid getting bodied by enemy spam. 

All around, I really enjoy this game. It feels chunky, it feels like a classic hack-and-slash with some gorgeous stylings and excellent music and sound design. Slashing every box to find a treasure makes me feel good! That said, control latency actively killing me literal dozens of times, slow and annoying respawns in sections where latency kept killing me over and over, and stun-locks that make death literally unavoidable unless you are sub-pixel precise, means that there are frustrating elements to this otherwise-outstanding game. 

I still recommend this, but go in with a warning that if control problems are not for you then this game will make you rage-quit and wish for a refund. If you can work around it or are willing to retrain your brain a little for it, then this game is absolutely worth it on sale.

There are very limited opportunities for regaining health, so when you get to a hard section and died to some dumb shit beforehand, realistically you have to port back and do everything again in order to have a bit of a health buffer; that's not in the fun roguelike way either but more in the annoying misplaced-my-save feeling way.

Too many elements required for progress are a bit too hidden. Nps can give you map hints, but those will only tell you the location and not where whichever secret path it is branches off. There aren't very good indicators for hidden passages either, which is to say absolutely none i could see sometimes. I don't know, maybe i'm just stupid, but if you walk down the the same path for the 10th time because you missed something to get to the first boss.... There are also plenty of non mandatory hidden rooms, also with zero visual hints for their existence, and when you find yourself crawling along the walls in every room on the off chance for an elusive health regen pickup.... yeah, not really having fun here.

An absolute gem. I have played through and enjoyed it several times for its beautiful style, color palette, music and atmosphere, but also the gameplay is so crisp, challenging but fair and well designed enough that it would probably hold its own even without the visuals and music.

Do not expect the game to hold your hand though. The tutorial shows you the basics, but onwards from there, the story and mechanics of the game are completely non-verbal and somewhat non-linear. This game is a unique favourite that I always look back on fondly and can play through again and again and each time be just as absorbed in as the time before. I highly recommend it.

114542796.review:
[b]There aren't many games that manage to successfully combine pure artistic aesthetics with combat mechanics. Strong emotions with brutal kills. Exploration and relaxation with the struggle to improve your skills and reflexes. "Hyper Light Drifter" is a game that does all these along with a technical perfection. It offers gorgeous pixel graphics, a majestic multilayered world, fantastic music, fluid gameplay, fast combats, good rhythm, deep emotions. A game that can be both challenging and poetic. A masterpiece not only for hack n' slash funs that you have to try.


Manometer: 9/10[/b]


The good
- It's pure art. Outstanding orthographic, pixelated graphics with tons of nice details. Gorgeous CMYK chromatic palette with touches of neon lights.
- Fantastically designed post apocalyptic world. Strong dystopian atmosphere full of misery and dirtiness. Great level design with lots of different locations to discover in a multilayer array that encourages you to explore more. It feels full and alive, populated with various animals, NPCs and enemies.
- Pleasant gameplay. Movements with great flow along with fluid animations. You'll never get bored of dashing forward. Tensive, fast paced battles with great rhythm. It gives you the ability to shoot and slash at the same time so you can try various attacking approaches.
- Extremely rewarding kills even when you're dealing with the smallest and most insignificant enemies. Destroying objects around you is satisfying too.
- It's a clever idea to tell you a story just with pictures without a single world. Although it gets too abstract it mostly relies on you personal feelings and interpretation replacing the traditional narratives with moods.
- Great, unforgettable music. It's mostly calm and ambient but has something weird in it giving the game an out of space and time atmosphere.
- Good, minimalistic audio design. The environment feels alive. Enemies' sounds are convincing. Electronic sounds at the menus fit perfectly to the cyberpunk mood.
- Gorgeously designed protagonist. You'll love him, although he doesn't say a single word and you barely see him closely. But everything he does seems heroic as he struggles with his illness.
- Good variety of nicely designed enemies. Each of them seems unique both visually and at their movements. Bosses are great and memorable too.
- The world has so many hidden things to discover. Extra levels, guns, clothes, collectables, upgrades and more are scattered everywhere in a very creative way. You will want to explore more.
- Well balanced difficulty. At normal level it's challenging enough without getting too harsh. By the time, as you get used of the enemies and the controls everything becomes easier.
- There are some nice upgrades to acquire and improve your skills. It hasn't the depth of an rpg but the upgrades can affect the way you play pretty significantly.
- At the beginning it throws you inside the game without explaining much. You have to figure out by yourself how everything works and what you are looking for. This makes it even more mysterious and gives you a, kind of, survival feeling.
- It's fairly cheap for a perfect indie art / combat combination. Also it has good duration and decent replay value.

The bad
- Deceiving perspective. Trying to decode the 3d environment can be confusing. A lot of times you're not sure if beside you there is an upper or a lower level, if there's a passage or not, if you're seeing an actual wall or the projection of something at the background. It would be very helpful if there was some kind of (at least prefixed) camera rotation.
- Story is too abstract to motivate you play. It gives you some undefined strong emotions, but you don't care about what's really going on. Your main purpose, to collect the scattered pieces in order to open the door and fight the final boss, is too generic and well worn at platform / metroidvania games.
- The map could be better. It shows your character in a general area and not his exact position. Also it isn't clear what is connected to what.

114516202.review:
With this game following along RoR in bring a 3D version, figured I would go back and drop a review while I am finally finishing it. 

Literal diamond in the ruff here. Art 10/10, music 10/10, movement 10/10, level design 8/10 as is a little hard to follow with lax world map, but makes all the more for exploring every little section of the world to find new weapons, armor, currency, keys, and ultimately, the shards that unlock the end game. Game play itself is very fast paced, hack slash, light bullet hell, very similar to the more retro arcade style.

As someone who grew up on pixel art games like pokemon and super mario for GB, this art style brings a sense of nostalgia, while revealing the level of detail and beauty only a few pixels can still give. Every zone feels alive in a different way, noises and actions from the environment and npc's will quickly swallow you in this brightly colored, yet rather bleak world. You WILL find yourself drifting while running about high mountain tops, sprinting through tree lines, or strolling over bridges above calm waters. The 2D platforming and odd edges can be a little frustrating, but allow for some very sneaky hidden zones and small puzzles that give the player a reason to want to explore everything.

Worth every penny and second.

This game was overall an engaging and highly challenging experience. The arena at the end of the game is absolutely brutal, and sadly the prize you get for it is extremely lackluster. New Game+ is fun with the alternative character, however after playing him and switching back to the normal one for other late game modes (boss rush, etc.) - it really takes the fun out of the game because the alternative character is way better, yet we don't have the ability to choose him for those other modes. 

Boss fights take some getting used to in this game, and due to the limited amount of life you have you have to be extremely conservative in your decisions. The chain dash upgrade is fun but it is an example of what this game suffers from the most: lack of communication. Unfortunately, this is both a strength and a weakness. I'm all for mysterious "figure it out" type games, but when core mechanics are puzzles themselves it's kind of dumb in my opinion. Chain dash took me googling something else to learn how to actually do it, after countless frustrating attempts in puzzle rooms that required it. 

Overall worth a try if you like challenge, grinding, completing, combat, souls-like, etc.

i don't like the controls. feels so sluggish and unresponsive. art and other shit is cool tho

edit: 
i decided to try this game again and i think it's pretty decent. 

I realize that on my first playthrough that i started in a mid-game area, which attributed to why gameplay felt like shit. Still though, there are issues where the game prioritizes art and aesthetic over functionality and gameplay, like how the map isn't one-to-one to your in-game location. Combat is better than i remember, and i don't think controls are that sluggish and unresponsive; you're just committed an action through animation lock. For bosses, it was more about rushing them down with big attacks than properly learning their attacks and how to dodge. There's not a lot of opportunity or time to punish bosses after they do an attack, they just move on to the next attack. Also, hitboxes feel so unintuitive, which doesn't help.

Another criticism is with the story and npcs. You meet various npcs while exploring, but they felt hollow when interacting with them; i don't even think there are any sidequests to influence them in any way. 114255258.review:
The combat in this game is incredible, every movement, every attack you must make deliberately. This isn't one of those "button-masher" combat games. Most other games when you damage an enemy, they go into a hurt/stunned state, whatever attack they were going to do gets cancelled, but not this one. in this one most enemies will ignore it and continue to follow through with their attack, if you dont move out of the way, you ill get hurt, and YOUR character's actions gets cancelled. you have to pay attention to these details or you'll run out of life very fast, learning all the mechanics and controls will take a little while, but once you know what to do, it is incredibly satisfying to weave in and out of the enemy, it feels amazing.
you are going to die a lot in this game, it's never a "BS death" though, i never felt my death was because of over whelming BS, it was always because of my lack of control and execution or panic that killed me.
Very well rounded game and proof that a fun game can be made from simple mechanics and graphics.

114243995.review:
I’ve been playing video games for a long time now and I’ve always thought I had a general understanding of what makes a great game, well, great.  It’s the gameplay, the story, the atmosphere, the depth and detail, the themes, ext, ext.  But as I’ve grown older I’ve realized that’s not really the case.  We might look for these on a surface level but subconsciously we want something else.

We look for a feeling.  Regardless of the physical quality of the game we want it to evoke an emotion.  Whether it be the cathartic blood pumping action of Doom, the sense of adventure and discovery through Breath of the Wild, the constant stress and disillusionment in Dead Space, maybe even the melancholy and sorrow of walking through the desolate ruins of Bioshock.

Someone who plays Ghost Recon might find its open world to be monotonous and boring while another will get a rush from executing a plan perfectly, becoming one with the environment in a hostile world.  The game is only as good as its ability to invoke that feeling.

Every part of HLD is created to invoke a feeling.  The feeling of loneliness.  Sure you’ll meet a few characters on your journey, you have a hubworld full of them but you never say a word to them.  They all see you, but they don’t know you.  Even your robot companion is little more than a string of code weaved together to keep you alive.

You travers empty cities, abandoned tunnels and temples.  Drifting between the old engines of war, corpses of a long dead world.  There is no dialogue to share with the people there, only pictures.  Short views into the lives of those that remain.  The remnants of that ancient war still tar the fields and splatter the walls.  They awaken from a stilled sleep to inflict misery on the inhabitants left behind, their war is over but the battle still rages behind their eyes.

It is your duty to stop it, whatever it is, before your body shuts down.  A strange illness affects you, causing you to convulse blood.  Were you created for this?  Were you like the dead machines that surround you?  Reanimated to fulfill this one final purpose?  Made whole just to fall apart again?  It’s impossible to say.

Walking between the machinations of war you dredge the ground with another layer of blood.  You march onwards towards the unknown.  Your own mortality weighs heavily on you as with each consecutive fight you grow stronger, and weaker.  The sickness becomes more consistent, your breath more constrained as your blood splatters to the floor below.  Your sickening wretches echo around the empty foundries, the corpses of the past look on in silent judgment.

Stop for a moment.

Amidst the etchings of an old artillery piece sits an outcrop.  A valley sinks forward before you, its lush green canopy spotted with rusted pillars spill out across the plain.  A mountain lifts out of the ground like a grand spire beyond it.  Creating a natural wall to hold in the sea of trees.  A giant mechanical beast rests against its side.  It’s body stilled, eyes rusted and mouth agape.  One hand clasping upward, grasping at battlements long since turned to dust.  Forever stuck in a final moment of pain.

The wind hums by you, whistling softly in your ear.  You feel the soft grass beneath you, its green strands glisten in the afternoon sun, waving back and forth to the silent hymn of the wind.  You sit there a while and listen.  For a moment you almost forget about the dead, the blood you’ve spilled, the visions of destruction.  It’s all beyond you there.  They can’t touch you here.  They can’t hurt you.

But you know you have to keep moving.  To take up arms against the assailing darkness for no other reason then that you were born to.  You pick yourself up.  Your legs ache and your back groans in protest.  The wound on your right shoulder throbs and your sword seems to grow heavier in its hilt.  But still you stand.

Your foot hits the soft soil, kicking up dirt as you dash off.  A sickening but unwavering determination fills you.  You enter into the decrepit city once more, unsure if you’ll ever get to leave.

You can rest when you're dead drifter.

9/10

114138555.review:
A gorgeous game about confronting mortality and not being alone in your suffering, that's also a fun and challenging action-adventure. Hyper Light Drifter has one of the best presentations I have ever seen in the medium - with striking neon colors and an atmospheric soundtrack - all in service of a wordless narrative with some stunning environmental set pieces. I think it leans on its vagueness a little too hard; I didn't entirely understand what was going on until I did some external research, but the game revealed itself as a beautifully personal and touching narrative once I did.

A version of this game that was a bit longer and a bit less vague would be absolute top tier for me, but as-is it's a masterful game worth your time and money. I'm very excited for Heart Machine's upcoming game in this universe, Hyper Light Breaker.

114051906.review: gods gift to this world ngl

114044996.review:
Hyper Light Drifter 	

	Hyper Light Drifter is one of the most beautiful atmosphere-based works of art in the video game medium, but struggles in a story that turns out to be to vague in the end, a heavy leaning on sadness, and hard difficulty even on the easy setting, which is often created by some sloppy design. 

	Hyper Light Drifter is artistically an 8 to 9 out of 10.  It is incredible to behold.  Contour, resolution, colour, sound effect, music, and animation all come together to make an incredible work of art.  The soundtrack by Disasterpeace {Fez, It Follows} emphasizes and also greatly enhances the visuals and animation incredibly!  Animal people talk to you in pictures instead of words, and this emphasizes the ambience of the place, as well as the space this game puts your imagination in.  There are moments the aesthetic falls. After hours of soaking in a unique fantasy setting, bouncy shrunken ninjas certainly seem cartoonishly out of place.  It seems all indie developers can’t live without shoehorning in an out of the blue feudal Japan enemy, because Japan makes video games and animated tv shows [there is also a mini boss like this]. Each place you go has different animal people that got attacked by mean animal people.  This just seems a bit too children’s cartoon for the setting.  Although this does have deeper implications to the emotion of the piece.  

	The entire game leans heavily on pain, sadness, and inescapable despair.  Why?  Is this done in a cool fantastical Bloodborne/Darth Vader/Mordor way?  No, this is because the developer suffers from heart disease, and he wants to spread his pain into you.  Anthropomorphic animals from your childhood being slaughtered, their decapitated bodies lying everywhere, just like like his childhood happiness was taken from him. Each time you make a certain amount of progress you start coughing up blood and watch the same exact flashback you already saw in the beginning of the game over and over, seeing yourself get bloodily stabbed through the chest, with a loud sound effect that suddenly gets clipped.  

	The game progress structure is that of Dark Souls, you are placed in a hub able to choose a few directions to go, and where you go first will shape your experience based on what your learn and what items you get.  This makes the land feel more real, and makes the exploration feel like a real adventure. There are many secrets to find, though there is an annoyance.  There is a subtle symbol on the ground that tells you where a false wall or path may be, but you are never told this.  This leaves you to realize it eventually, giving you that deep frustrating feeling of “wow now I have to back track everywhere I’ve been.”  That just sucks, this could have been told by an npc in town at the very least.  Especially when a lot of the secrets are stone blocks with writing on them that don’t do anything.  After beating the game I found out you were supposed to decode a language yourself to get some vague lore out of it.  This was disappointing.  

	Gameplay is pretty smooth, though don’t expect this to be Bloodborne.  There are a number of annoyances.  Your dash is not tied to your stamina, therefore you don’t know how much you have in an instant, instead it has this odd “you can do 3 dashes in a row and then there will be a cool down we won’t indicate” system that can leave you growling.  Standing around a corner from an enemy could be safe, or that enemy could land a hit.  Hyper Light Drifter seems moody on which it decides for you, and this matters as the game is greatly difficult.  When it first came out there was no difficulty setting, trying to go the From Software route, but there were a huge number of complaints as the gameplay was unfair.  So many times difficulty feels faked by simply swarming you with lots of enemies instead of presenting you with a fun foe.  This lead to the developer giving into an easy mode, which is an outright lie.  There is no easy mode in Hyper Light Drifter.  Why anyone feels the need to lie about having an easy mode is far far beyond me.  If you intend the experience to be hard, you could simply indicate that Hard mode is the intended difficulty, no need to lie to customers about an easy mode.  It doesn’t make you cool or next level.  Oh and they don’t let you change difficulty in a playthrough, so if you chose normal thinking it would be, you have to start all over to play “easy”. This is all compounded by it’s autosave-only system.  It autosaves when you enter a new area, sometimes.  This leaves you backtracking to places you remember it autosaving to save progress in hard areas where you’ve already completed the first part a few times.  The game also refuses to explain how your upgrades work, leading to much frustration in fights and platforming alike. 

	Overall Hyper Light Drifter is one of the most aesthetically pleasing things to come out of the medium.  Though emotionally it feels like a sad lament to memories of a very tuff time in your life, which is as painful as it is nostalgic because of how intense that part of your life was.  It is perverse in its indulgence of fatalist powerlessness.  Ultimately it feels like a cry for help.  

	If the art design interests you, it may be better to watch some game footage, as that will make it easier [due to lack of playing frustrations] to take in the fantastic artwork without absorbing the pain it tries to spread.  
 
-Dinobeam, April 24, 2022

114038900.review: I am hopelessly in love with the aesthetic of this game.

114006826.review:
I just cleared two of the 4 areas, thinking I probably beat around half of it now.
A flawed, but still very good game. Inspired by the trailer for the sequel, I gave this game another chance.
Artstyle and art direction are unquestionably superb, as is the game's unconventional approach to storytelling through mostly visual cues. A very ambitious goal that works - most of the time.
The UI is also very nice, an often overlooked aspect and tied with the attempt to mostly avoid written text and use only pictograms is a cool choice but as I mentioned above, not always without issues.

The game's flaws lie in its controls and level design and a few gameplay mechanics that feel a little off.
Controls and Combat:
Generally very fun, just sometimes it feels like you're fighting the controls more than the enemies.
Chain attacks and chain dashes feel very inconsistent, even after 8 hours of play. Hitting an enemy or getting hit gives a tiny time freeze effect that can really mess up your timing on chain attacks, costing me precious HP because my Drifter just stood there instead of executing the next attack in the chain or dashing.
Some fights are also very visually cluttered that it becomes hard to even see where you character is on screen because it can get very heated and fast paced at times.

Level/World design:
Aesthetically very good, no question but from a player's perspective exploration can be a chore. The first time going through an area is fine because everything is new and fresh. But you will miss things and some secrets can only be found after revisiting an area. - and that can be very tedious. The map - especially the underground map is very barebones and while the aboveground map gives you plenty of landmarks to orient yourself, the underground map is only abstract boxes and lines and your relative positon IS NOT tracked so it's a lot of guesswork. Now getting back to that singlelocked door once you get enough keys can be daunting without a wiki. All enemies respawn, many doors get locked again and there's many one-way street sections where you DON'T unlock the shortcut like you would in Dark Souls for example. 
This means you basically have to completely re-play old areas from bottom to top just to find that one pesky locked door which is impossible to find on the map.
This is very disappointing because the overall exploration and level design IS really good. The levels are diverse in combat and platforming, finding secrets is fun. But since re-visiting areas is such a chore, I'm totally afraid of missing even a tiny upgrade point because I know that I will have to redo entire sections again. Some inspiration from Dark Souls' shortcut mechanic would've improved this with no downside or effort. Some shortcuts are basically already in place, just when you re-visit the area, it's locked again. Why?

Mechanics:
Combat is tight and satisfying to get good at. The upgrade system is kinda meh however. There's basically one very essential upgrade which should've been a default ability because without it, entire areas become inaccessible and you can spend dozens of upgade points elsewhere before using it, essentially locking you out of much of the content. Most other upgrades are situational at best and I end up just using my bread and butter dash/attack/shoot. Deflecting bullets is cool but with the aforementoined chain issues, it's an unncessary risk most of the time. The charge attack sounds cool on paper but the game is too fast to use it in situations where the extra damage would actually help - especially when you can find a gun that does MORE damage than the charged attack but instantly and with no ending lag.
The dash attacks are cool and protected dashes are a nice extra but not really necessary.

Sometimes the picture-only descriptions weren't clear enough either. With every upgrade you get a little animation to show what it does, but for health and gun upgrades you only get more ammo/charges yet the stores show a little animation of the Drifter using the items which made me assume that the actual usage changes with upgrades. That's not the case.

Last but not least: The healing/medkit system is wierd. It feels like they wanted to go down the dark souls route of limiting your healing, yet they make you go look for medkits. Upon going to a warp point, you restore all ammo and health but NOT your medkits. Which is odd because you can just teleport to an easy area and get them there because they respawn and many are in non-hostile areas. So if you wanted to explore a new area with max medkits, you're forced to pick the easy medkits up elsewhere and then return. this is just tedium that could've been prevented by either giving us full medkits on reaching a warp point or by letting us store up medkits over our maximum and take them from there when resting at a warp point.

Edit: Just found out that this used to be a future and with Update 18/04/2016 they took it out for some reason...

This all sounds very nitpicky and like I hate the game but the game is still fantastic despite these flaws. They just bump it down a few notches in my rating and unncesserarily so because many of these would've been very avoidable.
I really hope the devs think of QoL-mechanics with their sequel :)

112680791.review: My Favorite game.  Hyper Light Drifter's biggest draw is it's simplicity.  It's a master class in the fundamentals of game design.  It would be a great tool for people who want to learn how to make games.  Beyond the mechanics, Hyper Light Drifter is an expression of grief from the creator, Alex Prestron.  He has struggled with a heart condition is entire life and has felt that he could die at any moment.  Hyper Light Drifter embodies his feelings toward his own mortality.  His art really shines in the neon palette used to display the games dystopian and alien world.  From the incredible cutscenes to the drifter's fluid animations the game truly feels like Preston's life work.

112571357.review:
I am not sure why I never reviewed this game until now. I have owned this game since it came out and even went as far as to buy the special collectors edition, which is not something I normally do.

I really dig this game, and in fact, I think it's probably on my top 10 list. In an era where "pixel" or "retro style" games are a dime a dozen, this is one that really gets it right. Rather than ride the coat tails of games that came before it, it really builds its own identify through the unique art direction and superb sound design alone. The movement in snappy and really makes the combat pop.

The overall length of the game feels just right. It's not a game I think most would comfortably finish in one sitting, but makes for a week of casual sessions. By the time you finish the game you won't be burnt out, and will likely be just hungry enough for a little more, which I find to be the perfect balance. My only real complaint is that is you want to collect all of the upgrade materials, prepare to spend an eternity or just use a guide, as there are quite a few.

9/10 for me.

112422681.review: hyper light drifter is like the snes adaptation of a 80's splatterpunk OVA directed by Alejandro Jodorowsky with a core premise of body horror and inspired by Kurosawa films. the narrative is entirely based on images and vibes, with no spoken or written language other then distorted electronic grunts and collectable ciphers (i think?), but as a nameless, chronically ill drifter you embark on a bloody journey through the outskirts of a ruined post-apocalyptic city for something to heal the disease eating away at you. there are other characters in the game, such as a nameless mentor-figure of sorts who mimics your journey, but characters aren't the game's focus. when i say "the game's narrative is based on images and vibes", that's not an exaggeration. the music and landscapes inform the tone of the game more then anything else, and it's honestly really awesome that the story comes across *mostly* coherent through these intentional limitations. needless to say, the aesthetics of this game are genuinely incredible, with the Disasterpeace score being a highlight (of which i immediately  picked up after beating the game) but the gorgeous and haunting pixel art and animation work is the core of the game's look and feel, with some vistas and reveals being sincerely breathtaking and giving me moments of awe. if the artwork wasen't up to the task, the game would fall apart, and it dosen't. speaking of which, the mechanics of the game are *so* satisfying. with the understanding that i've never played more then a few hours of dark souls 1, i found the game to be a fantastic example of why it's so fun to play a glass cannon character archetype. the feeling of seeing a room full of enemies that can easily annihilate you if you aren't paying attention, and the realization that *you* are just as lethal, if not more, feels so good. there is nothing as satisfying as chain dashing your sword through some monster's midsection as you blast your energy shotgun into their friends, capping off your opening salvo with a grenade toss at some hideous corrupt war machine. the game is tough but unbelievably fair, and this is coming from someone who cannot play hard games without getting depressed. it's like a violent rhythm game. once you find the beat, you are an unstoppable force of ultraviolence. i should point out that i by no means found everything in the game after 17 hours (though a fair chunk of that was spent trying to master the chain dash challenge) and i didn't touch NG+ or boss rush. i had zero technical issues or bugs on my machine, and i've not seen many reports of problems with the most current version of the game. if you are in the mood for blood-soaked mournful techno vibes, you owe it to yourself to play hyper light drifter.

110467974.review:
I'll offer a blunt review and won't beat around the bush about it. The game has decent highs and some glaring lows. I think it's still an enjoyable experience and the bosses are mostly fun challenges, but there are a lot of flaws in the level design and enemy placement designed solely to be difficult without consideration for whether or not it's "fun" or an interesting challenge.

A lot of areas in the game decide to challenge you by spamming dozens of simultaneous enemies that track you relentlessly and give you very little room to breathe in incredibly narrow platforms while the player has very few tools to handle this once you get overwhelmed - pre-planning and trimming early mitigates this but you aren't afforded that liberty when you're running through an area for the very first time. You might think the grenade would offer crowd control but it often just goes over enemies and is incredibly difficult to properly aim, not that this is a problem itself but it makes the only reliable tool a more casual player has to handle large quantities of blatant enemy spam... Not so reliable. I'm personally not a fan of games that throw gauntlets with you that are designed to kill you the first time you encounter it because you couldn't have prepared until already knew what was coming. In addition to this the controls are great when they work but incredibly clunky and frustrating when they don't, and I often found myself getting caught on terrain or enemies and losing myself in the visual chaos on screen because of it.

Overall in spite of my criticism I'd still recommend the game for its fantastic OST and an interesting world portrayed by some amazing pixel art visuals, as well as an engaging gameplay loop when it does work. The frustrations I had were mostly compensated by the exploration being majorly satisfying though if you enjoy hunting collectibles, and you'll be rewarded for being thorough in every single room.

Those seeking a fairly balanced but challenging experience should probably look elsewhere and come back to this one after you've exhausted your list of alternatives in this same vein. Those looking to play something that's hard for the sake of being hard and want to flex about how much of a masochist you are should look no further (like myself, I'm currently attempting deathless runs in pursuit of 100% just for kicks).

I would say the highs are worth the lows, but I'd personally recommend waiting for a sale.

109417004.review: This is one of the most beautifully crafted games I have ever played. The map and setting are incredibly engaging, with differing environments for every area and dungeon that make every fight seem different and never old. The combat is something you can master as long as you give the time, and this game is incredibly rewarding with every second you get better at it. This game is also filled to the brim with secrets and far more content you'll discover with every playthrough. Resources, objectives, dungeons, are all things you can find that you can totally miss if you're not looking for them, and if you think something is there, it probably is. This game is also sprinkled with beautiful music and a gorgeous art style that I haven't seen replicated anywhere else. This game is full of charm and easily gets you attached, wishing for more to play. If you're a fan of challenges in your video games, and you love games that have what I said earlier, then this is the PERFECT game for you. I'd rate this game a 10/10, but to be honest it'd be something closer to 18/10, because it blew 100% of my expectations clear out of the water. Get this game.

108147938.review:
I really enjoyed Hyper Light Drifter. I bought this game when I started out as a game dev in my first full time job. Took me many years to actually play it haha.
The level design is solid. There's a few moves but they work well together to make really fun gameplay. Dashing, Whacking and occasionally healing, shooting or throwing bombs. Although some of the combat and levels can be frustrating but it's still satisfying. I really hate spikes. Spikes PTSD.. The final boss.. very hard to dodge..
The feeling of finding new pickups is satisfying because you have to search the areas well. But it did add a lot of backtracking to the game. Although there is fast travel, most of the map is made up of respawning monsters and segmented land, so it still feels like when you first played the levels.
The progression is mostly skill based and the upgrades don't feel very satisfying as they don't impact combat much. There's only a couple that had impact.
The art and the level design are the strongest parts. Not a fan of the dash mechanic, because it felt more like luck. You never know which way an enemy will go, and sometimes you dodge twice with a boss and it gets you anyway.
I guess dash challenges did give me rythm? I had to just stop thinking about it and learn the timing using muscle memory. The boss fights were fun, although some I had to retry many times while others I beat straight away. Even in end game it's very easy to die still if you are not careful with dodges and attacks.
Overall, glad I played it, definitely worth a play if you like exploration, tight pact combat segments or collecting things. Or just want to oggle the nice pixel art.

This is a very unique game and is not for everyone. Honestly, I would recommend just buying it and trying it and if you like it keep rolling but if not just return it. I loved this one because the art style and sound design really hooked me. I was surprised at the combat for a game called "hyper light drifter". With a name like that i was expecting more of a hades type combat where you fly around and just smash baddies with a super fast sword. While you can fly around, the combat is much more dliberate and if you go in just button mashing you're gonna have a bad time. You do get a dash move that you can chain but it is difficult to do so and once you lose your dash you skid to a halt, making you vulnerable during that skid. There aren't any invincibility frames and dodging enemy attacks takes some serious precision. However, the game counteracts this with solid respawn spots. However however the game design if very obtuse and leaves you to figure it out on your own through trial and error so I could see why that would turn people off. I did google where to go at the start of the game and that helped me get rolling. 

But yeah. Great game. Not for everyone. I'd recommend trying it out and grabbing it on sale if possible. If this isn't your type of game you're going to hate it. But if it is your type of game then you're in for a real treat as there really aren't any other games quite like this one

Avoid this if you're a casual gamer. This game clearly has a lot to offer, but it's all blocked off by the high difficulty.

It's very pretty and atmospheric and I love how it tells its story without using words. The controller support is great so you can play it on the couch. There's a gun, but using it in combat is very difficult with the controller, and very easy with the mouse. 

I was having fun until I got stuck when the difficulty suddenly jumped upwards, when the game threw large groups of enemies at me.

Having more difficulty levels would help a great deal. I could always crank it up if it got too easy. Currently you get only two, and unlock harder modes once you finish the game. Difficulty can't be changed during play.

Colour contrast could be improved upon, sometimes I couldn't clearly make out what areas I could walk on. The perspective can play tricks on you too, something that appears in jumping distance is actually higher up, so you hit it and fall down.

No Steam Cloud support, you have to manually back up and copy the save game over between computers.

There are no accessibility options.

106869833.review:
Trying to set the tone for Hyper Light Drifter in a review is difficult, as is trying to advise it. How? Because in words its hard to convey the wordless vagueness of the whole experience. While it is a fun little Zelda styled Metroidvania, its absolute dedication to it being completely wordless will be the decider of if its worth it or not for most. There is a lot to unpack and it is an interesting game, but if you want crystal clear information as to what is going on, this may be best avoided.

So, Hyper Light Drifter: a top down, pixel-art stylised adventure where you go about and do… something involving unlocking cores that lets you get to the centre of the world because… to be truthful I’m not fully sure. I’m unsure if the main character, who seems quite ill, is trying to save the world before they die, or are they trying to save themselves? Still, they go around unlocking crystal pods that permit them to move onwards, but even then the vagueness makes even Dark Souls seem clear and to the point as to what is happening. The entire story of the game is presented via images with zero decipherable language being used anywhere. The scant few NPCs who will ‘talk’ with you tend to show one or more panels depicting some form of actions that occurred. Even then, a lot of these text bubbles do little to fully explain what is actually going on or what they want you to do. Granted the action going on in game is usually quite basic, and most interactions are done via combat or simply activating an object, so you can quite happily ignore all the things people try to communicate to you.

Instantly it is very clear: You will likely love or hate Hyper Light Drifter. Its arty flair for letting the player interpret the ongoing events is so self-indulgent, or even smugly self-satisfied, one can imagine the most dedicated playerbase of the title will likely look down their noses at any criticism and simply state “Of course a person as uncultured as yourself would not understand it! This was made for people with refined tastes!” Similarly the aesthetic, which has some phenomenal visual flair, has the pastel colouring that would tie very well with the vaporwave movement, mixed with the warm and fuzzy post-something-or-other synth soundtrack you have to ask yourself: Do you like Vaporwave or maybe are you an art student? If the answer to the prior is either “no” or “I bloody hate that pretentious crap”, then you should avoid HLD.

Despite that rather polarising take, the game itself is not bad. Unlike a number of Zelda / Metroidvanias, HLD here allows the player to more or less explore any area of the world in whichever order they wish to. There are no moments where a section is cut off due to not having the right equipment, so the mystery of not knowing what is up a cliff that seems unscalable is not there. However there are TONS of secrets! So very many secrets that its almost a criticism as a wall passed a tree could well be a secret hiding spot as it could be… well, just a wall. Thankfully these are signposted well if you keep an eye out as they all have a tell-tale mark nearby. These usually contain crystal pods that can help speed up an area, health packs, extra weapons or keys and sometimes upgrade chips to help boost your character. The upgrades are, in a very Dark Souls manner, not essential, but help a lot, ranging from the mundane heathpack upgrades to new dashing moves and attacks.

General gameplay is a mix of ranged and melee. While nothing ground-breaking, and in most cases not massively satisfying, it mixes things up by having the ranged weaponry charge when you do melee attacks. This is a nice twist as it keeps the action moving along and encourages forward movement rather than backtracking for ammo. That said I cant imagine folks would be buying this purely for the combat though.
Overall Hyper Light Drifter is a tough title to advise correctly. As a game its generally fine, and I would say at its core its an interesting game, but its tone in aesthetic and storytelling is so utterly niche you will either love it or hate it. I’m erring on the side or recommend, but just only on one, TL:DR condition:

TL:DR – Can you tolerate something that could be considered “arty hipster indulgence”?

Yes? Grab HLD! You’ll love it to bits!

No? Avoid as its pretentiousness will drive you nuts!

It has minimal story which you only interact with a few times throughout the whole game, features fairly enough loot hunting and sometimes feels flat and repetitive. But, it took me some time to notice any negative aspects on it because I was truly immersed. The visuals really are masterful, and as soon as I got used to the combat system I enjoyed it so much it was purifying. For a combat-centered game with basic, uncomplicated hack-and-slash mechanics, fighting has enough depth in requiring the player to think strategically and count their strikes. You don't need to be a fan of old-school games to love this one.

To me the best thing about this game is the nice looking cutscenes/art. 
The story is weak and too vague to make me feel anything, the gameplay has it's moments but it's nothing special. For me there's simply nothing outside of the "art" that stands out in this game. It's just a medioker 2d game where the art and design choices seems to have taken precedent over gameplay in ways I cannot understand. 

Many things in this game seems to take unnecessary long time and many animations are slow like dying and returning. The color theme of the game is whack to the point where it affects gameplay. Too much single colors that melt together making it very hard to distinguish pathways and different surfaces. I also hated the fact that it's so difficult to see different heights and they way the game uses platforming with this atrocious height/color problem. Hiding secrets into these indistinguishable pathways are just icing on frustration. 

Blocking the view of the character is unforgivable and the game practically forces you to fall off the map again and again when you check behind edges or if you can move on some oddly colored/invisible surfaces.I did not enjoy cheap instant death traps nor the punishment of loosing health from falling down from any gaps in the map. The big square crushing blocks (what civilization would actually build something like that) added as cheap puzzles/traps in the maps environment are laughable relics from games past and stand out in the game as beacons of lazy recycled gameplay from early games when traps/puzzles were made in blocks from limitaions of hardware.

The worst offence of all is the lack of story where you move from area to area without any reason or motivation behind it as a player. The game tries really hard (too hard) to be mysterious giving you no information or backstory at the start. You basically run around and fight things with your nameless avatar you know nothing about while moving through closed corridor spaces in linear fashion without much motivation other than to explore/fight. You then received a complete world map painfully early with every linear corridor marked out revealing the small world of this game, only to discover that the map is drawn in a artsy manner making it completely useless. Dodge used with mouse and keyboard uses the direction the mouse is facing rather then to use the directional keypads. Meaning that you dodge into enemies a lot because you have to "look" at them to attack. A mouse user has to move his/her mouse towards an enemy to attack then quickly swipe away to dodge. Super unintuitive and such a stupid standard setup.

105623869.review:
It's hard for me to overstate how much I've enjoyed this game. The artwork that is both bleak and vibrant, the setting that has such a grand scale in both distance and time.  And everything is underscored by the incredible audio of Disasterpiece. 

The exposition in this game is very subtle. Individual people will tell you their stories, but you have to piece together why everything has gone to Hell. If you're looking for an exploration game with some brutal but stylish combat I can't recommend Hyper Light Drifter enough. It is true that you start off fairly weak, but not weak enough that you don't want to figure out what is going on, or what lies down one more forbidding tunnel. Within a few sessions your Drifter will become an extremely formidable warrior, able to dance around, mow down, or explode large crowds of enemies. Even if you get discouraged at first, trust me, the payoff is incredible.

105614250.review:
Hyper Light Drifter is a top-down action game that, in all honesty, is very difficult to describe in words. This is one of those games that tells you next to nothing about it - besides a few pieces of tutorial text, everything is learned by trying it out. "How do I read this map? What are these yellow things? Where do I get all these keys? How do I get to that area over there?" All of these questions are things the game never gives an answer to. Instead, you explore, figure things out, and learn what does what. It's not just a feature - it's the entire game.

As for the combat, it's a mix of both swordplay and gun fighting. Dealing damage with your melee or breaking objects give your gun ammo, which lets you deal damage from afar. However, precision aiming is a bit finicky, especially since you have to stand still to do so. Because of this, it's often better to just quick-fire, thus making melee weapons a better option overall. Besides this, though, the combat is fun and fast-paced, with dashing around to dodge enemy fire being a key part of it.

There are tons of secrets to find in the game world, although most of them are not necessary. You can beat the game with very few collectibles found, and the minimum you need are marked on your map when they become relevant. Of course, anyone looking for 100% will have to scour every corner of the world to find everything - which also means doing some backtracking once you have something you needed before. Sadly, there is no way to mark the map when you find something to come back to; you just have to remember where it is. This is one of my biggest gripes with the game, but at the same time you need very few of these collectibles to beat the game, so it isn't a big issue for more casual players. If you do go out of your way for 100%, be prepared...

The game also has multiple difficulty options, achievements, Steam trading cards, and all those other goodies you would expect from a Steam game. Unlike what you would expect, though, there are no "progression" achievements - that is, there is nothing for beating certain bosses, nor is there anything for reaching certain points in the story. After my first playthrough, I only had 4 achievements, all of which (except for beating the game) were from miscellanious tasks.

Overall, a fun and enjoyable action game, fitting for anyone who likes pixel graphics and "NES-hard" games. I'm writing this after beating a casual playthrough, so there's probably lots left for me to do, but even then, it's a relatively short game, clocking in at 5 hours (which includes going for lots of side collectibles and deaths).

105612662.review:
I highly recommend this game. It is probably one of my favorite games on Steam to date. After playing every game mode and while I'm still grinding for all achievements, this game has been such a relaxing experience to enjoy. While some may find its simplicity in mapping a hindrance, I find it quite enjoyable. A lot of this game's mystery comes from its exploration factor and the visual tricks played on you as you the player learn more each time you play it. With a lack of dialogue there can be moments of feeling lost if you set the game down for a period of time and pick it up later, however the visuals the NPCs display for the worlds history paint a beautifully graphic and dark story that could be compared to Dark Souls. 

This games combat is very distinguished, akin to other games, it requires precise timing and focus. (Unless you're playing the Alt character, in which case you just kinda spam attack and pistol for the frame cancel and near permanent stun on bosses.) 

Boss rush as a separate entity from the save files is probably the best feature that is external from the core gameplay. Other titles, such as Binding of Isaac or Hollow Knight have the Boss Rush modes as a part of the gameplay or a part of the game save files, making the point of having the boss rush as an inclusive part of the game. Having the boss rush as a separate menu option is very unique and genuinely a nice option as you can change your difficulty and not have it be based on your items or equipment from a specific game file. 

All in all, I truly love this game. I constantly pick it up if i have an hour or two to kill and will speedrun getting to the final boss. As of right now, while it may not be a world record, I can achieve this in 1:15:00. I look forward to playing more of the game to improve this time and share the game with my friends and hopefully make a positive impact on someone deciding to buy the game. 

Enjoy the game!

I just can't with this game.

Whoever made it just feels simply... edgy.

The entire game is loaded with ideas, way too many ideas, and there is no apparent respect for any of the ideas actually put in the game. 
Just as quickly as a mechanic is introduced, it is forgotten about and not given proper time to shine. 
Not only that, but the visual language of the game is muddled, important interactable objects often changing appearance (as the creator didn't like the last one and semi-replaced it) as well as being nearly identical to decor.
To make the problem worse, not only does the creator have little to no respect for their own ideas, but the player is given no time to build up respect for the ideas either. It's a jumbled mess of "I like this cool neon theme and edgy void stuff, so let's just come up with every idea possible and put it into this cool game that relies on kinda ok artwork to sell copies".

If you enjoy a game for the game, and have an enjoyment of genuine works of art, do not buy this game.

105265035.review:
This game is one of the few masterpieces I have ever played. It's visual style of pixel is astoundingly beautiful, and the game revels in this moment by providing moments to just sit and watch. There are hiding places in the game that you can sit down and watch the world move in, the Sea, the snow, the mountains and more are there for your viewing pleasure. The buildings are wonderfully animated and dedicated to each area, nothing feels the same when you go to a new place, everything is fresh, the building style especially. 
The player is a Drifter in a fading world, full of creatures of malice and death, war has long been a tragedy in this land, and that fact hides itself in every corner of the world. The fields outside the hub-world are full of corpses in the gaps, tombs lay abundant about the land, and there's a corpse long dessicated laying in many areas, rotten to bones. The atmosphere of the game is rich and beautiful, hiding darker undertones that aren't built upon but provide backdrop to the story. The vibrant colors and swift and fun gameplay distract from this darker realization.
The gameplay is swift and highly challenging, there are many ways to play the game with the toolset offered. Your sword is a tool of destruction, able to cut through most enemies with ease, however, the same applies to you. Your ranged weapons provide much needed variety that your sword lacks, allowing your playstyle to be varied and flowing between ranged and melee attacks. The enemies are rich and challenging, and everything is out to kill you. Though there is an achievement for dying a thousand times, you may feel like you do so, you won't reach it because though the game pulls no punches, its combat is highly rewarding.
The content in the game is deep and highly rewarding, you can play the game without going into any secrets, and in fact beat it within 8-10 hours, but there's still twice as much content left hidden throughout the game, it's not only a secret filled game, but one worth exploring and cataloging for all it's worth. The challenges within the game are tough, unforgiving, and require sometimes absolute skill to succeed at. But the game never pulled punches with you in the first place. 
The story, while only told through visual dialogue, is rich and complete. It provides a simple narrative, told extremely effectively, it truly encapsulates the themes of what Alx Preston hoped to achieve. You march through the game, hoping to achieve what others have failed to do for a very long time.

103678337.review:
Hyper Light Drifter is brutal and beautiful. The simple yet gorgeous pixel art and musical ambiance drew me in when I first picked up this game, but I knew I was in for a challenge when I watched the intro sequence play.

Tough times had fallen upon the world. I, the Drifter, set out to explore the world for a cure to a disease that infected me and others that came before. I was lucky to find refuge in the village at the center of the world, but the rest of the world would prove to not be so caring. Each expedition into the fringes of the world only increased in risk, as the enemies and the environment only got more dangerous with distance. The crystal beasts of the west, the bird shamans of the north, the floral monsters of the east, the dirks of the south, they all took me as a hostile, and many times did I perish.

Regardless, I persevered. With better gear, stronger abilities, and increased experience, I conquered the four fringes of the world. At the same time, I got to admire even the most terrifying beauty of the world, from the giant crystals of the west, to the snowy cliffs of the north, to the serene pools and waterfalls of the east, to the vast deserts of the south. Even the hostile labs had their own sense of beauty. Also at the same time, I got to enjoy the tense yet calming soundtrack by Disasterpeace, one fitting of the world and the condition I was in.

Get ready for a brutal yet beautiful journey. You won't be disappointed.

103630426.review:
Hyper Light Drifter is a very cool game that I really enjoy. The amount of worldbuilding it does without any actual words is just awesome and the pixel art is beautiful. The actual combat is surprisingly deep with cool techniques like animation-cancelling with the sword and pistol or quickly cycling off of the shotgun to reload it instantly. 

As a whole the game is a lot of fun, but my favorite part was trying to unlock the hardest achievements. Playing through NG+ really forced me to practice and get good at fighting all the bosses and regular enemies, since your max HP is capped at 2 and a lot of enemies can just straight up oneshot you. That might sound like a pain, but it feels good to beat a boss without taking damage and just see all that practice pay off. 

Beating the game without dying was the most difficult achievement, but I really enjoyed planning out the safest route and practicing against all the bosses beforehand. I would practice fighting every boss until I could beat them 3 times in a row without healing, then switch back to the deathless save and fight them for real. I gotta say, every fight feels a lot more tense and thrilling when one slip-up means starting over from the very beginning. 

So yeah, I had a lovely time with this game and I feel like it still has replay value for speedruns or challenge runs like beating it with no upgrades. It definitely deserves a spot among my all-time favorites and I'm happy to give it my thumbs up.

103177148.review:
[table]
    [tr]
        [th]Factor[/th]
        [th]Rating[/th]
	[th]Description[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Gameplay Loop[/td]
        [td]6[/td]
	[td]Very few games capture being atmospheric while also giving an engaging gameplay experience, & HLD def hits those notes. The primary gameplay loop revolves around combat and exploration. Both of them are pretty engaging. The structure is simple, you go in one of the four directions and explore. You kill enemies, find the ground switch thingies, keys, and currency to buy stuff in the hub town, and end it with the area boss. Repeat the same in other 3 directions. I personally enjoyed my first area, East, a LOT, playing 6h at a stretch following almost every secret and going through stuff again with a sense of wonder - but as I progressed into the other areas, that sense of novelty waned into repetition. Apart from that, I found the checkpoint system a little off, with long stretches without one and bursts of too many together - similar with health packs. And apart from some other issues I describe below, this is a solid, solid game.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Narrative[/td]
        [td]7[/td]
	[td]The storytelling is done in a really creative way, replacing dialogues with pictures. The character is looking for a cure to his sickness, as can be seen in some portions in bw, which is actually a parallel to the game's creator having a fatal illness. It certainly has a very personal and warming touch to it, and it almost makes me wish those bits had seeped into the gameplay mechanics in some way too. Loved it.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Visuals[/td]
        [td]7[/td]
	[td]This game is pure atmosphere. The pixel art is gorgeous, the imagery in some of the cutscenes really seem to go into abstract territories which is really interesting. Somethnig that I will later elaborate in the mapping portion doe, is that the visual design can sometimes make it confusing which portions you can actually walk/jump to. Another thing that I felt was that the animations of enemies and the hitboxes themselves felt slightly off in a lot of cases. Apart from those issues doe, a really pretty looking game.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Mechanics[/td]
        [td]5[/td]
	[td]I def enjoyed the movement and combat, but I would be remiss not to mention some issues. The rhythm of the chain dash was initially weird to get ahold of but then I literally had it in my muscle memory. It's a great mechanic that could've made traversal really fun. I say "could've" because the game puts too many roadblocks in bw to actually let you enjoy it. You slip after the 4th chained dash, which makes it non-viable for combat, but even during exploration that can lead to  you just slipping off a corner and dying. I'll describe that in "Mapping" ahead. Another issue I had was that the game has omnidirectional dashing but doesn't let you play with dpad. So I might want to dash into a certain direction but it'll round the direction off, which, again, can lead to fall deaths when trying to navigate the world - but also make you miss enemies during combat. Speaking of, there's certainly a certain amount of input lag, or like a cooldown with the combat mechanics, which to me contrasted with the quick nature of it, the enemies' attacks and quantity. Another thing I failed to understand was why I sometimes crashed into enemies while dashing, but other times I had complete iframes. IDK if I missed something there, but in the end, whatever system it has in place makes it feel a little unreliable.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Challenge[/td]
        [td]7[/td]
	[td]The game can def be pretty engaging when it's at its best. While some deaths can feel out of hand owing to the issues with mechanics/controls - it was still fun. I do think it gets progressively easier doe, as I found it hardest only at the beginning while learning, but that's not a huge deal. I did feel in some instances though that this game's idea of difficulty ended up boiling down to just increasing the amount of enemies, but it contains that to a reasonable level. I did find it really annoying though that you can't destroy the turrets. Like why?? If it wasn't for the mechanics/mapping issues, it could be an even greater experience than it is.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Variety[/td]
        [td]6[/td]
	[td]There's 4 directions the game sends you in. And I personally think that was a great opportunity to explore a lot of regional individuality through enemy variety, terrain challenges etc. And while they were sorta diff, I still noticed the same enemies everywhere, and it all easily meshes into each other rather than feeling like different areas. The core combat is fun. I do think the guns other than the shotgun are pretty much useless during combat though, and I never felt the need to use bombs. The boss fights were fun, not too challenging, but to be completely frank, I really don't remember any of em standing out to me. [/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Mapping[/td]
        [td]6[/td]
	[td]On one hand, I really love the exploration and the atmosphere that it certainly has a place in my heart - on the other there's def some issues I had that came in the way of it enough that I couldn't ignore them. The main one being - fall deaths. The levels are designed in a way that sometimes it's very confusing what places I can actually jump/walk into and which I can't - which ended up making me die by falling much more than during combat lol. For a game that has this dash chaining, the level design had seemingly too many roadblocks to ever actually use it much. Not to mention that the slipping thing I talked about ends up killing you a lot of times as well. While I enjoyed finding the secrets, a lot of times they ended up being medkits which felt counterproductive in both ways - someone who needs em might never find em and someone who does find a secret would be a tad disappointed. But yeah, that's a minor issues vs the map design that leads to one too many fall deaths. Sometimes you can actually go inside bushes/structures that look like a border and fall-die there lmao.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Sound[/td]
        [td]9[/td]
	[td]Loved the music. It certainly has a vibe of its own. The sound design seemed to do what it needed to as well.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Interface[/td]
        [td]6[/td]
	[td]The interface was pretty minimalist, which I appreciate. The control scheme is weird though. It uses the same analog stick for both aiming and movement, which affects game-feel negatively. It wouldn't have been a problem if the game simply allowed me to rebind but I couldn't find the option to do that either. The game does convey its currency, and even the buying of stuff in the shop without the use of text very effectively though, so it easily has a +1 from me for that. What did end up becoming an annoying part for me sometimes was the map. The underground map feels very incoherent to understand, and even the normal one won't update your live location at all a lot of times. IDK if I missed something here, but it def felt like the map was a fairly useless part of the game outside of fast travel. [/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Pricing & Performance[/td]
        [td]8[/td]
	[td]A 4 on each. While the game ran smooth, there were certain issues it had issues reading the controller sometimes if I alt-tabbed or used the second monitor every now and then - which I do a lot. But apart from that, great performance. [/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Replay Value [/td]
        [td]5[/td]
	[td]While I def recommend it as a one-time experience, I don't see myself revisiting the game.[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

102896507.review:
I had Hyper Light Drifter sitting in my library for quite a while, I finally decided to give it a go.  I think I may have it in my Switch library as well.  I'm glad I did.  Hyper Light Drifter is well made, and well worth your time. 

HLD is a three quarters view action/exploration game with impressive pixel graphics and excellent sound design.  There is a central hub area, and the world is broken up into four sections.  Each section has 8 triforce-esque pieces to collect, but you only need to collect 4 to move on.  There are many, many hidden paths, some absolutely deviously hidden away, and you will need to find them all to get all the pieces, and keys, and stone tablets, etc.  

The reason I have to make up names for everything in HLD is because there is no text in the game.  Everything is told via cinemas, or pictures, or diagrams.  It's an interesting choice, and goes along with the spartan/melancholy mood and design of the game, but there are a lot of times it gets in the way.  At times it can be difficult to piece together what is going on, which sort of lowers the stakes of everything.  Additionally, figuring out some of the advanced moves, and what buying certain upgrades does, can be perplexing.  I would say the choice is a net negative overall.

The combat in HLD is great.  You have a dash, a sword, and a gun.  You need to use them well, the combat is difficult, but fair.  The bosses are excellent as well.  

I enjoyed my time with Hyper Light Drifter.  Its post apocalyptic aesthetic is remarkably well done, it is beautiful, and lonely, and foreboding in equal measure, while staying varied as well.  I did not 100% complete the game, as it is difficult to find all the secrets, and I do not like using guides, but I did beat all the bosses and get the credits to roll.  

8/10

102663448.review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
[b]Hyper Light Drifter[/b] is an action adventure with a focus on exploration. It offers a singleplayer and a split-screen co-op.

[h1]Pros & Cons[/h1]
[b]Pros:[/b]
+ Interesting exploration with lots of well-hidden secrets
+ Intense combat encounters
+ Good pixel art, that doesn’t hurt your eyes

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Upgrades only make the game easier without opening paths to new challenges
- Because even the setup of the story is unclear, there’s not enough motivation to overcome difficulties
- If you want to use chain dash ability, you must play on 30 FPS

[h1]Story[/h1]
The story follows a nameless protagonist and his robot side-kick on their quest to restore power to an ancient machine. Or it can be about something else, because the game has no text at all. You can gather something from the pictures some of the characters show you and that’s all you get. Anyway, the story isn’t the focus of the game.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
After a short tutorial you are thrown into an open-world consisting of four locations. You have to find four artifacts in each location and defeat a boss. The game doesn’t hold your hand, so you can do your objectives in any order you like and there are multiple paths to get to each objective as well as some secrets hidden along the way. Some of which are very well-hidden. The combat is very fast paced and has you jumping around battlefield evading enemy attacks and jumping back to do some damage. 

As you progress you can unlock different abilities that will make your life easier. Like the ability to reflect bullets or invulnerability while dodging. There's a very fun chain dash ability that allows you to travel very fast, but it is very hard to pull off. Seems like the problem is tied to FPS, it only works well when you play in 30 FPS mode. Keep it in mind if you have trouble. There aren’t any abilities that unlock new paths in the world or greatly influence your playstyle, which is a bit disappointing.

I was very much in love with this game at first, but around halfway through it became too easy, because of all the abilities I’ve acquired and the game just didn’t want to up the challenge.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
If you like exploration games with a bit of combat, then get it. The playthrough on normal takes about 6 hours and there’s a new game+ mode with a harder difficulty, if you want to get out as much as you can from the game.

102522735.review:
Every part of Hyper Light Drifter feels like a worse version of another game. To be clear, I'm not saying they specifically ripped off any of the games I compare it to, since I think some of them are newer than HLD, but this is just what I felt was similar.
The art is trying to be Celeste but it doesn't actually look good in my opinion, and it's pretty bad in terms of visual clarity where Celeste is amazing at providing information. Also, the pastels feel out of place in the bleak world that the plot seems to portray as far as I can tell.
The gameplay is trying to be Hades with the sword, but lacks a lot of the nuance and the controls don't feel good to use, mostly due to the jarring pauses after every dash or sword swing, and the visuals occasionally making it hard to tell what's going on. The design decision of making the sword charge the gun is interesting, but it's not enough to salvage clunky controls in a game with demanding enough combat to make clunky controls unacceptable, and Hollow Knight did the same idea vastly better anyways. And before you tell me I just need to git gud, I would like to point out that I've beaten Dark Souls, Hollow Knight, and Celeste
The exploration is trying to be hollow knight, but the simpler art style and uninspired level design mean that areas don't stick in the mind as well, leading to a lot of the bad kind of backtracking. Even aside from barely working, the map feature is also unclear enough that it's barely a help in navigation. It also didn't get the memo about what kinds of content are suitable for secrets, as critical progression is often gated behind finding things in the sort of out-of-the-way spots that would maybe net you a Wanderer's Journal or an interesting charm in HK.
The pacing is trying to be Enter the Gungeon, but the characters annoyingly slow walking speed and the amount of time I spent blundering around lost, through areas where the bad guys usually wouldn't respawn between visits meant that I spent most of the time I was willing to invest feeling more impatient than actually tense.
I feel like there's a comparison to be made for the storytelling, but it escapes me at the moment. Suffice to say, they took the idea of "show, don't tell" a bit too literally, and the result is that a story which seems like it might have been interesting just feels like more trouble than it's worth to decypher, and that's coming from a Dark Souls fan. The storytelling seems to present a lot of mysteries that its visual-only style of communication just doesn't seem equipped to answer. Questions like who I'm playing as, what those giant dead people are, what killed them, what I'm trying to accomplish, or why my own vomit keeps trying to kill me. All in all, it made me unwilling to get invested in the game for its plot.

I've enabled comments on this review. If you're one of the people who actually liked this game, could you please explain why? I genuinely don't get how it has a decent steam rating.

[h1] This game is poetry [/h1]

Much of my hype to play Hyper Light Drifter was centered on its backstory: a game created by a man with a life threatening heart disease.

It plays as a simplified pixel-art ARPG with zero dialogues. You play as a mute Drifter who is confronted by a recurring nightmare of death. As you face all the beasts and bosses, you unravel details about your true enemy—your deteriorating health. 

Even if you remove the romanticized narrative of the creator, Hyper Light Drifter’s praise is well-deserved. The cryptic world is beautiful, the gameplay is impeccable, and the scoring is absolutely sublime.

Thankfully, the creator survived. I hope to see more from him and Heart Machine.

5/5

Very well made game, a lot of love and effort was clearly put in. 

On top of excellent game mechanics and world design, the art is simply amazing. Namely the color palette; almost every sprite is inspired by the two primary colors-which are roughly complementary opposites-a sort of cold teal, and a vibrant quinacridone magenta. This makes for a very pleasing looking world. All the cold blues and warmer reds simply add so much energy and life to the world.

They also did a superb job filling the world with all sorts of goodies. Every where the player goes they find something new; whether it be currency, health, new paths-sometimes whole new areas are discovered by accident!-etc, etc. 
Combat is punchy and satisfying. Plenty variety with respect to enemies and room design as well. I have read complaints about 'clunky combat and dash mechanics', however, upon further inspection and more thorough play through-I played a while back, different account-I find such statements unfactual, and with respect to my own understanding, totally nonsensical.

I highly recommend Hyper Light Drifter.
