101673942.review:
When I first played Hyper Light Drifter I was not a fan. I came in straight off of playing hollow knight and wanted to sink my teeth into a world filled with intricate lore and characters and mountains of dialogue to sift through. But instead I got just about the opposite. There was NO dialogue to speak of, the near nonexistant plot only served to move the game forward, and after I beat the final boss I understood just about as much as when I had started. And then that was it. I got hints here and there of what MIGHT be going on and what MIGHT have happened in the past but little more. So I walked away disappointed my first time. the gameplay was fun but I thought that the stripped back storytelling and lack of ANY dialogue was pretentious. I went on to play Celeste, OneShot, and Shovel Knight. All the idie gems. Then one day I found out there was a multiplayer mode and played this game with my brother.

Since then I have 100% this game 6 times. This game is absolutely BRILLIANT in just about every aspect. You play as a wandering medic/warrior of sorts in an unfamiliar land with no means of communicating with anyone, and are plagued by a mysterious ailment. Everything about this game seeks to put you in the shoes of this character as much as possible and immerse you in it's world. The visuals are gorgeous, filled with vibrant pinks, deep blues, and lush greens. The sound design makes unfamiliar and futuristic surroundings into immersive, tangible worlds. And I'd be crazy if I didn't talk about how great the gameplay is. The core mechanics of this game are always the same (drifting, slashing, and shooting) but it's builds on it with upgrades that keep it fresh without being overpowered. It's very tight, responsive, and fast paced. It's difficult but never overwhelming. While fighting the hordes of enemies this game throws at you, you have to strategize and try to keep track of who's doing what in order to methodically chip away at them. It's incredibly rewarding and I never got angry while playing, no matter how many times I died. It's nothing but fun and engaging all around.

All in all I cannot recommend this game enough. Usually, even for my favorite games, I play them through once and rarely come back. This game is different. No matter how many times I comb through the world in this game I always have the same feelings of wonder and excitement whenever I discover a new area or beat a tough battle. And whenever I'm not doing those things, the slow, peaceful ambiance of the worlds keeps me going onto the next thing. And Ironically, by playing the game multiple times I have wound up figuring out some of the lore I was so hungry for in my first playthrough. All just theories and ideas though. Every time I've tried to look up any solid answers it feels wrong somehow. Like knowing more than I've found in the game by myself as the drifter hurts the immersion. 

If you haven't yet, PLAY HYPER LIGHT DRIFTER.

Hyper Light Drifter is my favorite game of all time.

It has amazing visuals and sound design that work with each other to create a detailed post-apocalyptic world. The exploration is rewarding, with well hidden secrets everywhere. The combat is tough, but incredibly fun once you learn the systems. Finally, this game is a masterclass in environmental storytelling; it manages to have a rich and interesting story without using any dialogue or words (at least not words in the English alphabet). For some people this approach to storytelling is a detractor, but I find it incredibly interesting-- the player is required to pay careful attention to the detailed environments to piece together a story, which was very fun for me.

10/10

This game is very good. The gameplay is tight and fairly challenging, the world is fun to explore and and the art is amazing, especially is the couple of vantage points you can observe.

The story is the not very explicit type. Stuff happened and I'm not sure why. You could probably understand better than me by investigating but I enjoyed the ride non the less.

My biggest complain (which is a nitpick and doesn't devalue the base game) is the way 100% the game and finding collectables works.
- First of all, 99% of hidden collectables are [spoiler]marked by a little symbol on the ground[/spoiler]. It's not hard to figure out and once you do, it takes away any challenge from finding them. It's especially boring if you're doing a second run through the map just to find them.
- To complete the game, you need to find 4 out of 8 thingies in each of the 4 regions. The first 4 are marked on your map and there are 4 more you need to explore a little bit more to find. I'm guessing there is some kind of secret once you find them but you have absolutely no lead to find the last ones. I'm at 31/32, I went through the region where I'm missing one all over again and I don't know where to look anymore.
- There are also [spoiler]a couple of hidden obelisks around the map which probably reveal a secret too but there is absolutely no lead to find them. After going through the whole game twice (once for first play trough and once to look for secrets) I have less than half of them and no clue where to begin looking for the others.[/spoiler]

Maybe Supraland spoiled me but I don't like when the road to 100% is just aimlessly running around to see if I missed something. I loved the main game but I kind of wish I stopped there because I spent a lot of time looking for hidden things and I won't get anything out of it without looking online.

100402611.review:
I wish that the review system had a neutral option for recommendations. 

Hyper Light Drifter has a lot going for it. I love the graphic style, which reminded me so much of the game Moonlighter, that I had to check to see if it was the same Developer (it's not). The mechanics for the controller are fairly intuitive, even for someone who prefers turn-based play over active battle. Exploring is interesting, especially trying to determine which platforms you can jump to (and which will end in you falling just short into the abyss). 

Unfortunately, there's also a few sticking points that make it hard to fully immerse me. 

The first issue: What's the Story Here? 
You get an opening cinematic that gives you the sense that you're probably supposed to be doing something important and story-worthy, but heck if I can tell you what that is. I know the character coughs blood intermittently, and that there's an NPC that you're somehow connected to, as he saves you in the start of the game when you pass out, and shows up in the different areas, having slaughtered a section of mobs. I can't even figure out what's going on by talking to townspeople, as they just talk in 1-3 symbols in response. The most explanation I've gotten about what I'm supposed to do is having a projection in my house show me that I'm supposed to get some triangles, and it seemed to want to point me in a certain direction to start the hunt, but with zero context, it made no sense, so I'm flying blind through the North, East, South, and West sections, with no clue if one is meant to be played first.

Battle: For the most part, random encounters are feasible, but too often the game throws 10+ mobs at you, especially in fights where they've locked the room on you. Heals seem interruptable, if you take an impact while trying to "inject" yourself, which can be a particular pain. Aiming the gun can be clunky, and wish that it had more of a "auto lock on nearest target" function with the ability to switch through available targets.

Map: The overland map is pretty, but the underground maps are...utterly useless. Just neon lines, and there's no clear way to delineate on the map which sections I've visited and which I haven't. 

Overall, I really want to like Hyper Light Drifter, and I'll probably try it out again at some point, but it throws you into the game with little to no sense of direction, and no way to gain a sense of direction within the game.

100118470.review:
First things first - a warning. This game is heavy in the emotions it carries. The game was originally designed on the idea of the inevitability of a heart disease (hence the name of the developer - Heart Machine), and some of the cutscenes can be, as best as I can describe it, brutal. If impalement, hallucinations, grief, or seeing scenes along those lines could be triggering, please be aware that this game includes them if you decide to play it.

With that out of the way, I cannot put into words how much I adore this game. HLD is a challenging, combat-oriented adventure through a mysterious landscape where all of the story is shown through imagery instead of dialogue. You have your sword, a gun (eventually guns!), and the ability to dash at your disposal, that each and every fight will see you using all three fluidly and reactively.

The world is gorgeous, the story compelling, the enemies somber and horrifying, and I absolutely adore this game so much.

disclaimer: as i can't give a middle ground rating, i'll put a "not recommended" only because the game has 94% positive review as i'm writing this.

Design is good, music is great, world is engaging and you are rewarded for exploring.
So here is the catch:
Everything is awfully slow: basic movements, every damn elevator, every door that opens. respawning also, of course, but the worst part was the "money" gathering: you need to collect 4 pieces to make a coin, and there is another bloody slow animation every time you get that 4th part.
As if it wasn't enough, you're also slowed even more every time the game reminds you how doomed your character is.

Core mechanics were (for me) a chore from start to finish: hitboxes and animations make for a rather clunky business, the timing were the worst and i couldn't get used to them up to the last boss.
I honestly felt like i was fighting my controller more than any enemy.

For the story, i honestly don't know why everyone mention it, as i didn't saw any. Some NPCs seems to have memories to share, but why did anything happened, i cannot say. Maybe if you search long enough it eventually make sense but i couldn't bother as i didn't have much fun. 
I still wasted some time trying to get an achievement that requires you to press a button a 1000 time (for real). Combined with the punishing timing, needless to say i gave up eventually.

Again, i wouldn't say the game was awful, but i definetely had not much fun.

99636465.review:
Overall:
Hyper Light Drifter is a gorgeous looking, beautiful sounding action-adventure game with very satisfying combat. It borrows a lot of its core concepts from Zelda, while changing enough to not be considered a clone. However, it has a couple of annoying flaws that kept it from keeping me engaged enough to explore it fully and discover all its secrets. 

7/10

The good:
There are lots of impressive things about Hyper Light Drifter. Starting from the visuals, Its pixel art is very detailed, especially in the cutscenes, its animation is fluid, and the art style and character designs are very good. The combat is based on a genius mechanic, which incentivizes switching back and forth between melee and ranged attacks, and the dash move is very satisfying. The pace of the combat is very fast, and the controls are precise enough to facilitate that. These things are best exemplified in the bosses, who are all very fun to fight. The music is very fitting to the world of the game, and definitely one of the game's greatest assets. It's not very memorable in terms of melodies, or rhythms, but its ambiance really adds to the melancholy of the setting. All these things are not just good in this game, they are TOP NOTCH.

The bad:
They say that a picture is worth a thousand words, and that was probably the mantra behind the narrative design of the game. Hyper Light Drifter does not have a single line of dialogue, no text within the world, leaving a huge chunk of the story to be inferred by the player. The few characters that you can talk to speak in sets of 3 pictures, which although interesting and ambitious, left me grasping for meaning, and context to what I was doing, why I was doing it. I understand that the developers wanted to leave things vague, and open to interpretation, and some people really like that, but the total lack of information kept me from becoming invested in the game's world, and the narrative. Another major gripe was the map screen. Hyper Light Drifter is a game that's heavy on exploration, and finding secrets, so a detailed map is to be expected. However, in a baffling choice by the developers, the map screen only shows the room the player character is in, with no accurate positioning available within it, no details and a very confusing layout, that made traversal very tedious, as I struggled to find my way to each area's boss.

The meh:
This point might be valid for some players, and not for others, depending on a number of factors, so it lands its spot here. Hyper Light Drifter is non linear, in the sense that you can take on the 4 main areas and their respective bosses and any order you want, with the game only hinting at one of them as the preferred first area. This non linearity leads to some very wonky difficulty, especially when you factor in character upgrades, which affect the core gameplay significantly. Some areas can be hell to traverse through with lots of enemies to fight at once, dodging projectiles all over the place, only to make it to the area's boss and beat him easily on your second try. Due to the non linearity, the game's difficulty doesn't progress linearly with character progression and player skill, making it feel somewhat unbalanced.

A classic title, its minimalistic narrative and creative art direction aged well. Music is also nice and very fitting. Core combat mechanics like dashing or deflecting/parrying projectiles can be a bit hard to learn at first on keyboard and mouse but doable. Enemies and bosses play out like Dark Souls enemies in which they are difficult and punishing of mistakes but it's done so in a fair and rewarding manner for the most part. It's a nice game but it's also relatively short, BUT it does come with some challenge modes for replayability like Boss Rush and New Game +.

Get this game if you enjoy: 
+ a beautiful, colorful world and standout character designs
+ synthwave and post-apocalyptic aesthetics
+ metroidvania indie games.
+ dark souls style influenced boss fights
+ minimalist story telling where the story is up to interpretation

99396417.review:
Edit: Remembered something else. You'll notice the game doesn't support cloud saves on any platform. It's even worse than that. The game makes it so each save file is specific to a single computer. You can't copy a save from one PC to another. Want to play in two places, or upgrade your machine? Tough, you have to start again (or look up the tedious method of hex editing the data). This is completely inexplicable BS for a single-player game. Just unfathomable. No surprise the devs turned to satan, really.

I loved elements of this and hated others. Couldn't be bothered to do the final fight or hoard mode as the combat, while good at times, is also deeply flawed and annoying at other times, like both of those. The main thing to enjoy in the game is the exploration and finding secrets, but there's no more of that once you reach that stage, so why bother?

The exploration really is great, although it's tempered by asking you to take loads of leaps of faith where if there's nothing quite where you jumped then you take damage (and health packs are a PITA to get back at times, while ridiculously abundant at others).

The story, and a lot of the game mechanics, are not presented in a way you can make any sense of without going outside of the game. This made me not care about the plot, but the fact I had an ability that was needed and yet I didn't know I could do that thing or how to activate it until I gave up in a part that required it and looked on forums... that's just bad game design. There's being obscure, and then there's failing to give the player information they need.

It's a little ridiculous that the game has a fairly broken input system that completely ignores button pushes at times, yet also requires you to maintain sub-second accurate rhythm to do certain things. It just felt broken in that regard. (And it really is broken, not just me. I used an AutoHotkey script to do a certain challenge which is a complete piss-take with the broken controls, and found it was impossible to get beyond a certain point, whether using the script or doing it by hand, if I was moving up and down instead of side to side on the screen, which shouldn't matter. Something is wrong with the game, yet it has challenges which are essentially impossible without exploits or outside knowledge.)

Really nice music by DisasterPeace. If you've played Fez, you'll instantly know it's by the same person.

The developers have taken Satan Sweeney's money and made their next game exclusive to his personal games shelf that no one wants to use because Sweeney is an ahole and his store is even more half-baked than Steam (which is saying something!), so the devs and anything else they ever do in their careers is all dead to me anyway. I wouldn't have even started the game had I known this initially, but since I already had it and was 1/4 the way through I kept going.

I caught the 'roni and thought I'd pick up this game while recovering. I found out about it through the gun in Enter The Gungeon, another game I thought was awesome.

I typically love metroidvanias, pixel graphics and games with good soundtracks, but ultimately I didn't have fun with this game. The intro was a bit too slow. The choice to tell the story through only images and exploration was incredibly creative, but I often found the lack of clarity frustrating and it was clear to me that it would be a long time before I got any answers about what I was playing through.

The gameplay wasn't remarkable either. In regards to the difficulty (which is seemingly a popular topic of discussion), I wouldn't say this game is particularly hard or easy. It follows that typical pattern of dodge and response, which I found to be a bit repetitive considering the other creative liberties this game takes. Because of the lack of narrative direction and the simplistic nature of combat, I couldn't find any incentive to play this game. 

There aren't a lot of bad things to say about this game, but there aren't a lot of things I can praise about it either. Perhaps the better qualities of this title just went over my head. Overall, I wouldn't recommend it.

98037350.review:
Fun game with some frustrating elements. Recommending it as exploration and combat are fine and challenging at times.

Graphics and music are normal, but imho not great.

Story... beginning looked fun and mysterious but after that there was almost nothing except for some visual storytelling and some pictures given by characters in the world. Overall story was not interesting or engaging.

Exploration is interesting as there are lots and lots of secrets. At the same time map is shit-tier and almost completely useless. Looking for doors you could not open in previous locations is not fun and you cannot mark them on your map when you encounter them for the first time.

Combat is fast paced and bosses are mostly fun and challenging, but combat itself felt strange sometimes. I-frames and stunlock on being hit are bad and you can die almost instantly without regaining control. Shield dash is not well explained, thus it felt inconsistent as I did not understand how it really works for the most part of the game (and even knowing how it works I do not think it is implemented well, Hades-one feels better). Not being able to dash through enemies also sucks due to amount of enemies on some arenas. Timings on chain dash felt somewhat too harsh.

97365198.review:
VERY good game. It's a mix of old-school top down zelda games (multiple dungeons with a boss at the end that gives you a new weapon, some non-linear overworld exploration) and dark souls (bonfires, limited heals, respawning enemies, challenging stamina-based combat, environmental storytelling). The combat in particular is quite challenging. The game has a somewhat limited upgrade system, so you will need to master the base abilities of the drifter to evade enemies' attacks and get your damage in safely. It's quite fast-paced too.

The story has no words whatsoever. It's purely based on images and environment. World is gorgeous with hand-drawn pixel art. The controls are snappy and very responsive. Animations are very fluid. World has quite a few secrets to uncover with hidden power-ups and alternate armors. Overall an amazing experience. Only complant is that it's a bit short, but totally worth 15€.

10/10 would buy again

96860598.review:
Hyper Light Drifter is an indie action adventure game made by Heart Machine, and it's a perfect example that telling less is more.

Pros:

- A heartfelt, mysterious story that reveals more the more you explore, and it derived from what you perceive. Everyone has their own story in this, because while there is a canon, most things are just summarized so you can have your own interpretation.

- Player Exploration: It's rare to see games from this decade without quest logs, indication on where to go, or even dialogue. It's like combining the old Kings Quest games from the 80s and Hollow Knight. Hollow Knight especially seems like a good canditate on a similiar game designs, because a player driven, non-hand-holding, open for interpretation games are kindof a goner these days. Most games of this era are often rely on straight narratives, telling what you need to fight, why and showing no contrast between all of them. They're there to be killed without hesitation. Yes, this game also has enemies but they make you think as to why you fight them, most of them are the same species or just neighbouring animals gone rampant. It's genuinely an ingenious design that is dead in most cases, and mostly found in other indie games such as the aforementioned Hollow Knight. There isn't much of a boundry in this one either. You can go where ever you want to go exept the last 2 areas. You don't see this design either, even in Hollow Knight there were boundaries that the whole "Metroidvania" genre made up, but here it's glorious. Everyone has a different first experience because of it.
Also on the exploration note: lots of things to find, so many in fact that I just couldn't find it all. Many collectiables and such, outfits, weapons, keys etc.

Graphics: Not going into a long tangent, this is one of the most beautiful games I've played in a while. You, have to experience it. It would be a downplay on all levels to just try and say: "oh it good looking because". But yeah absolutely toptier Design.

Music: Also not going to describe this: you have to hear to make conclusions. It's very good though.

Gameplay: Fast, skill based, perfectly blended gun and sword combat. Hard bosses and enemies, parkour and mostly exploration. It's genuinely amazing. Not spoilering much in this aspect either.


Neutral:

The whole exploration and collecting is amazing at first, then it gets repetitious, amazing again, and then you either give up or just google the rest. Some of them are so hidden that I couldn't even find the way to get to them, but this changes person to person. You might like it, I liked it, and it got kinda boring.


Cons: Very, VERY short story mode without the whole collecting aspect and other difficulties. It differs to most, but I would estimate around 6-10 hours. Maybe a few more contients would've made it better, or just more replayability, but right now and I guess forever it will be way too short.

Dashing with mouse is kinda bad, might be preference but yeah.

Some places are very cheap, such as the whole parkour dodging thing before the [spoiler] Heirophant [/spoiler] boss.

Getting everything without google is a chore, so I didn't.

[spoiler] The Judgement boss while cool and kinda difficult could've been much better, like imagine if he reactivated a titan and you could reenact the opening scene [/spoiler]


Conclusion: A Beautiful, vast and ruined world full of dangers and lost technologies. Good story, graphics, gameplay, music, and emotional attachment. It's like Hollow Knight, but a wee bit shorter. i guess if you really are a maximizer I would recommend full price, but a sale would would be much better. Buy it mate.

Hyper Light Drifter: if From Software remade A Link to the Past starring Strider Hiryu. It looks, sounds, and plays like a lost SNES gem from a seperate reality where Out of this World was a commercial success. 

if you look at some of the reviewers here you'll notice a pattern; the more glowing a review, the longer the playtime. Forty, fifty, even 70+ hours on some of them. This is should tell you a lot about the type of game this is. Not that it takesa long time to reach the ending per se, but more so to the fact that Hyper Light Drifter has depth and replayability to spare. Exploration, puzzle solving, and plenty of indirect story-telling round out tight, skill-based combat, with a soundtrack wrung from the dying throats of a MOOG and C64 in an incestous union. 

If this game looks like something you might play just get it it. If you're not enthralled in the first two hours then Steam has a relatively simple and expedious return policy.

96222335.review: YES, get the game, is good. but on a more descriptive note Hyper Light Drifter (Or HLD if you think that's a mouthful) is an absolute masterpiece. The game's story telling point of view is ambiguous visions that your character gets along with the tales of people who have been affected by the recent events in world. No words are Spoken in HLD, the NPC's that do tell you things do it in pictures vignettes if you will, and the vibe of the story that is the surface level obvious stuff is that, well everything is just bad everywhere: you have the hierophant and their cultists, the hermit and the whole deal with the otters, the last general who probably has lost it all ready and believes that you are the enemy, and then you have the things created before the decline designed to trick you, or other's with similar goals and to kill them. Then you have the specter of death, Judgement, who follows you in your visions and murders you in every one of your dreams, who seems to not want you to complete the task set out for you by the character refered to by the fandom as Anubis, or as I like to call him, Space dog, who wants you to end this strife and turmoil and remove the pestilence that is Judgement from the world. That's just the story and only the barebones, if you dig deeper there is much more, a tail about imortality and hubris, about a civilization that lived before the events of the game but does no longer. Every aspect of this game is as finely crafted, the beautiful atmospheric music that elicit the themes of the game, the gorgeous art style and color palet which can only be describe as watermelon / sunset. The unforgiving (at times) gameplay and bosses who drive home that this is not a story you're meant to live to tell, and the somber and beautiful ending wherein you can finally sit down and rest by a fire, your quest, and your hard work, finished. 1000/10 get this game now yall

Alright- here's the thing. I have been meaning to write a review on this for awhile, and I finally think I should do it. 

I really liked this game at first. The story was enticing, the intro sequence completely hooked me. The art is gorgeous, and the combat is fun and challenging (but not too hard). It seemed like the perfect game to just sit at my computer and enjoy alone. 

But there is one thing that makes this game COMPLETELY unplayable. And maybe it's just me, because the other reviews seem to be good, and I know I'm a bit.... navigationally challenged. But the map is completely unusable. It seems to serve moreso as an artistic rendition of the cities, rather than a usable tool. 
So, while I still check it often (and realize how little it's helping me), I switched to just trying to remember where I was and where to go. I soon realized after an unbearable amount of time wandering around over the dead bodies of enemies I defeated hours ago in areas I had already explored, that I would never be able to progress. I figured that perhaps I was just not MEANT to progress in that city yet (maybe I just needed an upgrade) and moved onto another one. Alas, the same thing happened and I gave up in a fit of exasperation. 

I WANT to like this game. I came back to it many times because it really just seemed so fun, but I can't for the life of me understand how to DO anything. 
If anyone has tips, please let me know. I will change the review. I am desperate.

95603997.review:
This game is absolutely fantastic, for a number of reasons.

This game is beautiful, both visually and audibly. Disasterpiece has produced yet another masterpiece in music, alongside FEZ. The pixel art graphics are some of the most beautiful I have ever seen, they bring a tear to my eye with the colors and readability of the sprites, it is simply gorgeous.

This game has very little story, and not a single word of dialogue to tell it. It is all told through visuals and music. And what a wonderful job the developers have done. Even when the NPCs talk in simple pictures, you can imagine an entire tale being told about whatever it is they're talking about. Usually they you about a boss that you need to look out for and eventually conquer, but sometimes they talk about lore.

The gameplay is incredibly intuitive and clean, and (usually) the controls are very snappy and feel really great. You can move really, really fast in this game if you want to and you can just plow through dungeons with enough experience, but that requires a great understanding of the enemies, dungeons, and all of the moves available to you at any given time. All of the enemies have such striking designs, I love them all. After one, maybe two encounters, you know exactly how they work and how they will attack you, and none of them fight you in a similar way to any other enemy.

Bosses are also a great challenge. While at times they can be frustrating and feel very unfair with their attacks, it can still be very fun to fight them over and over. I personally recommend defeating the East boss first as I found that one to be the easiest. And just like the enemies, I absolutely love the designs. They each feel so distinct and share virtually nothing in common other than that they can hurt you.

But even with all this praise, there's still a number of issues I have with this game. First: It has a collect-a-thon element. There are items scattered all throughout the world that let you gain new abilities, but some of them you REALLY need to search for. If you don't search every nook and cranny using every ability you have up until that point, I guarantee you are missing at least half of the collectibles the game has to offer. I wouldn't recommend grabbing them all unless you are the Completionist, as they mostly serve as "bragging rights" after you get most of the abilities in the shops.

The main issue I have with the game is that sometimes the controls absolutely fuck me over. I'm not sure if it was because I decided to use a controller over bluetooth or if it was the game, but sometimes I got so incredibly frustrated that I had to quit the game and do something else.

I do highly recommend this game. 9/10

95376673.review:
Hyper Light Drifter is a really cool game with a great art style even with being 8-bit or 16 bit idk it still looks great and has several locations that look amazing. The soundtrack is absolutely god-tier and the gameplay is really fun and it's an enjoyable game to play through a couple times. It’s really amazing to see how great this game is as it was a Kickstarter funded indie game and imo is a lot better than various bigger titles from bigger development companies. Basically what I’m trying to say is this game has a lot of great detail and heart put into it and is really fantastic. Various portions of the game and just in general at numerous times the game is quite challenging which I initially didn’t expect and on a normal playthrough no problem but doing several of the side activities and additional gamemodes serve to be very frustrating at times.

+Great art style even with being a low bit game several locations and the cutscenes look really good and if anything is one of the best looking 8-bit and or 16 bit games
+God tier soundtrack just completely amazing
+Lots of secrets hidden all throughout the game
+Collectibles
+Different outfits
+Multiple save files
+Boss Rush mode which is an alternative gamemode after beating the game which allows you to just fight all the bosses as fast as you can
+Horde Mode which is a hidden challenge unlocked after beating the game where you have to fight against waves of enemies and try to survive as long as possible
+Tons of upgrades, various guns, and lots of attack styles
+Remote Play
+Local co-op which if anything seems to make the game 100x easier as the co-op partner and just keep respawning again and again
+Full controller support which imo this game is better with a controller
+Short but has a lot of side activities and side gamemodes you can do

-Initially struggled to get the chain dash upgrade to work properly as now I can do it so easily but I was pressing A… A and it wouldn’t activate and I understand that you have to sort of pause and or press the button slower than normal beside mashing it yet, still struggling initially to get it to activate. This was one of the things I liked and disliked about the game is how vague and ambiguous it is on explaining things in the game as it pretty much expects you to figure out everything yourself with no real tutorials besides the initial one in the beginning. Yes it tells you to press the A button twice but it still wouldn’t work for me at times and struggled as several other discussions and YouTube videos did a great job at explaining how to do it poorly.
-The West Side boss as a whole made me cry more than I’d like to admit
-NG+ reduces your health to 2 health states and about the vast majority of the enemies and bosses can use an attack that deals 2 damage basically making the entire NG+ playthrough an insta kill playthrough. It was just really frustrating at times, especially going against the Northern boss who just felt completely unfair on NG+ as he would attack so fast and every attack was a 2 damage hit so you had to go through his entire fight without taking any damage whatsoever. He would use multiple attacks at once and leave barely any room to deal any damage to him. Just a god awful fight imo hated every moment of it every other boss on NG+ I had no legit issues with.
-In regards to certain achievements the hidden one to “tame” an animal I feel may be broken and doesn’t seem to unlock or the requirements don’t seem to be explained well enough, the achievement to die 1000 times is a nice waste of time imo as even after playing through the game 3 times and doing several side related content I still didn’t get it which simply required me to just keep running into a room and killing myself about a couple hundred times which was a lot of fun. Then of course you have the infamous “beat the entire game without dying once” achievement which I think in any game is just the developers way of torturing their players and anyone trying to 100% the game as I don’t see how anyone could really find an achievement like this fun imo. After doing a similar achievement in Outlast 2 and giving 30+ attempts and spending about 10+ hours for a single achievement I really just hate achievements like this lol
-Horde Mode is cool however, I just wish they didn’t spam the 2 damage enemies everywhere which just made things so difficult as there would also be 2 enemies spamming projectiles and about 1-2 charging you at the same time. Even better was when they’d spawn and immediately charge into you giving you no time to react or prevent being hit.

I really liked Hyper Light Drifter I remember seeing it on the store page awhile ago and it just looked so cool and knew I had to get it even though it doesn’t seem like the typical kind of game I usually play but, I’m really glad I got it as it’s really fantastic in pretty much every way although several portions I would say are very difficult. Don’t buy this game if you aren’t expecting a challenge as this game is definitely frustrating when regarding several of the additional content besides just playing the game normally which is for the most part no problem. The game even has a “Souls Like” tag so yeah I guess this game is similar to Dark Souls. I also think this game feels a bit overpriced imo as I’m sure most players probably just play through the game once and quit so 3-4 hour game for $20 seems like a lot even with its additional content. Ik that it's an indie game and I’m not bashing it for being so much I personally just feel like it's kinda a lot.

95022014.review:
Ominous, calm and ruthless. This game is all about the atmosphere, discovery and brutally realistic difficulty.

The game is set in a post apocalyptic world, presumably ruined by war and colossal humanoid robots. You explore the ruins of a technologically advanced civilization with a protagonist plagued by a fatal illness. The few creatures still standing alive fight for survival, land and resources, with backstories more sorrowful than the last. OST made by Disasterpeace is, well, amazing and fits the game like a glove. It is a world of captivating beauty brimming with secrets, death, but strangely, hope as well.

The game is hard, not too hard, but hard in any case. The movement system is responsive, fluid and allows for mastery for those who seek it, enabling the player to chain dashes to a point of resembling that of a "Hyper Light Drifter". You will be able to get new weapons and equipment, but the arsenal will never get complicated and filled with useless garbage. Rather the complexity emerges from choosing the best weapon, tools and approach for a combat situation. No i-frames here! You are a glass cannon, deadly and mortal. You will have to be careful and decisive in you actions.

Hyper light drifter is the diamond in the rough, a gem of artistic inspiration. It left me in a silence.

94981772.review:
I want to thank Heart Machine for introducing me to the blue/pink colour combo. Probably one of the best art styles for an indie game ever.

There is also a game with this artstyle too. So that's a bonus.

94864479.review: Incredible game with a great soundtrack, stunning visuals, and crunchy combat. This game demands patience, and I sometimes found myself taking long breaks between play sessions, but it always drew me back in. The worst thing about this game is the lack of invincibility frames. While this seems to be an intentional design choice, it can lead to you getting stunlocked and cause cheap deaths. Checkpoints are fairly generous, though, so you never feel too angry. Most of the time you can be back where you died in under a minute. The soundtrack is incredible, changing and adapting to in-game elements. I personally listened to the soundtrack before I played the game, so every time I heard a song I recognized it felt like a grand revelation, and going back and listening to them, now knowing the context behind them, was almost like hearing a different song. The story is told entirely through visuals; the only written text is in the tutorial and menus. This might not work for everyone, but I found it deeply impactful. Almost nothing is overtly explained, but I liked it that way. The ending knocked my socks of and literally gave me chills. Overall, this game is a masterful combination of beautiful visuals, immersive soundtrack, mesmerizing atmosphere, crunchy combat, and minimalistic style, all coming together to make a truly incredible ride from start to finish. Highly reccomended.

94844413.review:
I don't understand the reverence people have for this game, it is deeply mediocre across the board. 

The creature, boss, and player mechanical complexity was just utterly lacking, and the game was over before it felt like it even really began.

94770513.review: Beautiful, poignant. A pixelated, post-apocalyptic tale par excellence. The only things that prevent me from giving it a perfect 10 is 1) the positive effects of the drifter's deeds are implied rather than shown and 2) the late game content feels somewhat unfinished.

94718503.review: Very pretty graphical style, to the detriment of the gameplay. Because nothing is explained in words or even visually highlighted (to preserve the color scheme) I struggled throughout to understand where I was meant to go and what I was meant to do. I ended up stumbling around, backtracking through the same areas multiple times in search of the plot thread. Also, poor game design means it is often the correct tactical choice to revert to a far back save in order to preserve a wasted life or consumable, forcing the player to choose between tedious gameplay or potentially handicapping themselves in the future. I only made it a few hours in before getting frustrated and moving on.

94708277.review: 4/4 fun and atmospheric. Hits the spot. A simple concept, extremely well-executed.
